title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Elsa Dorfman, a Polaroid Portraitist, Is Retiring at 78
description: She is among an exclusive group of photographers, including Chuck Close and William Wegman, to spend long periods with the 20-inch-by-24-inch Polaroid camera.

title: With Film Supply Dwindling, a Photographer Known for Huge Polaroid Images Is Retiring
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  To make a good portrait, the photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson once counseled, you have to try and put your camera between the skin of a person and his shirt. It would be tricky for any portraitist, but especially daunting for Elsa Dorfman. Her camera is taller than she is, weighs as much as an N.F.L. linebacker and looks, from certain vantage points, like a 1970s liquor cabinet.

title: Fitbit Shares Tumble 18% as Apple Watch Gains Market Share
description: Shares of Fitbit, the maker of popular fitness tracking devices, sank 18 percent on Tuesday as investors worried about its ability to compete with Apple and other makers of wearable technology.

title: Who Are the Bundys?
description: Ammon Bundy, the leader of the group of armed protesters in Oregon, has a family history of fighting the federal government.

title: Adele Album Resists the Streaming Trend in Music Sales
description: For the last few years, the prevailing theme in the recorded music business has been that CD and download sales were plunging while streaming has shot up quickly, as listening habits shift online.

title: The Hear-Nothing Gun Crowd
description: Sometimes in American politics it seems as if we are all talking past each other, that whatever one side says about an issue like, say, taxes zooms right past the other side. The current fight over gun control is not one of those moments. It is a howling storm of misrepresentation, sadly almost entirely from one side. This weeks developments fit the pattern.

title: Michigan: Emergency Declared Over Flints Water
description: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan declared a state of emergency for the Flint area on Tuesday as concerns grew about the health effects of lead-tainted water there. His order, which followed emergency declarations by the city and county governments, came on the day federal officials announced an investigation of the contamination. Mr. Snyders administration has been criticized as slow to respond to residents concerns about their water. Last week, he apologized and announced staffing changes at the state agency that oversees environmental quality. Flint, which had long received water from Lake Huron provided by Detroits water utility, began drawing its water from the Flint River in 2014 in an effort to save money while a new pipeline was built. Residents soon complained about rashes and strange odors from the river water, but city and state officials mostly insisted that it was safe to drink. Last year, elevated levels of lead were found in childrens blood, and in October, Flint switched back to Detroits water system. Mr. Snyder, a Republican, said Tuesday that the emergency declaration would allow for more state resources to be used in addressing the effects of the tainted water.

title: Judge Rules for Cosbys Wife
description: Camille Cosby will not have to sit for a deposition Wednesday in a lawsuit filed against her husband, the entertainer Bill Cosby, a federal judge in Massachusetts ruled Tuesday, as he granted Mrs. Cosbys request to postpone any deposition until her lawyers have a chance to appeal.

title: A Mafia Captain Turned Informer Gets a Reduced Prison Term
description: During their hour-and-a-half outdoor sessions at the super-maximum security prison in Florence, Colo., Gregory Scarpa Jr. struck up a friendship with an important prisoner: Terry L. Nichols, the co-conspirator of the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Wear Orange Campaign Enlists Youth Basketball Players to Spread Message on Gun Violence
description: As President Obama spoke on Tuesday about acting against gun violence, Jim Fox was on the phone, trying to make sure that every one of the 3,000 or so players in his basketball league, Lightning Basketball, would have a jersey with an orange patch.

title: Pickups and S.U.V.s Lead Way to a Record Year for Automakers
description: Six years after plunging sales during the recession forced automakers into bankruptcies and painful restructuring, the industry has roared back to achieve new heights.

title: Ted Cruz Ad Envisions an Influx of Bankers Crossing the Border
description: The campaign of Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has begun to air a new television advertisement in New Hampshire, a slightly tongue-in-cheek, 60-second spot that focuses solely on illegal immigration.

title: Why the Government Owns So Much Land in the West
description: The United States government owns 47 percent of all land in the West. In some states, including Oregon, Utah and Nevada, the majority of land is owned by the federal government. Of course, it used to own nearly all of it.

title: Las Vegas News Staff Advised on Covering Adelson
description: Ever since the billionaire casino mogul Sheldon Adelson acquired The Las Vegas Review-Journal last month, the newspapers reporters and editors have agonized over whether their coverage of Mr. Adelson and his business interests would be compromised.

title: This Land Is Your Land. Or Is It?
description: Since last weekend, armed men have been in control of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon. Incensed by the sentencing of local ranchers to jail time for burning public lands, the protesters want the federal government out of the land business. Their stated goal is to return the refuge to the locals so that people can reclaim their resources. But this raises an important question: Why does justice demand that the land and resources belong to the locals instead of the commons? What makes property private?

title: Bank Rule Distorting Performance Is Repealed
description: An Alice in Wonderland accounting rule that allowed stressed banks to book huge gains simply because they were stressed has been overturned.

title: Venezuela Opposition Takes Reins of Assembly as Tensions Rise
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Change came to the National Assembly here on Tuesday in very Venezuelan style  with a lot of shouting.

title: To San Bernardino, Obamas Gun Plan Goes Too Far or Falls Short
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif.  The fear comes up in discussions in line at the movies, where a group of mothers say there are too many guns on the streets for them to feel safe. For others, the mass shooting that killed 14 people here last month has prompted a rush to buy a gun for the first time, suddenly convincing them that only a firearm can protect them.

title: 40 Alumni Assert Sexual Abuse at a Rhode Island Prep School
description: BOSTON  The scope of a sexual abuse scandal at St. Georges School in Rhode Island widened substantially on Tuesday as lawyers reported that at least 40 former students had made credible reports of sexual abuse, and in some cases rape, by seven former staff members and four students over three decades.

title: A Dream With Cooperstown Ties Wasnt to Be for the Crafty Mets
description: It was never happening. Not the way it unfolded, anyway. But that did not stop the Mets from pushing aggressively to bring baseballs most electrifying player to a team on the rise. Imagine Ken Griffey Jr. and Mike Piazza, who might make up this years Cooperstown class, sharing the middle of the lineup in Flushing. The Mets sure did.

title: Saudi-Iran Feud Poses Threat to Iraqs Effort to Combat ISIS
description: BAGHDAD  The fighting has finally stopped in Ramadi, a major city in the Sunni heartland. The Islamic State has been ousted, and the Iraqi flag is flying once again.

title: Jeb Bush Drops Guard to Share Family Account of Addiction
description: HOOKSETT, N.H.  Jeb Bushs elder son, George P. Bush, is the land commissioner of Texas and is nicknamed 47  a look ahead to when, many joke, he will become the 47th president.

title: Bowl Ratings Havent Burst New Years Eve Trial Balloon
description: In the morning leading up to last years national championship game, ESPN executives met in Dallas with Bill Hancock, the executive director of the College Football Playoff, to make a sensible proposal.

title: Cuomo Revives Long-Stalled Plan to Add Track to L.I.R.R.
description: In his latest proposal to improve the regions infrastructure, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Tuesday he wants to jump-start a long-stalled plan to expand a key stretch of the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Protesters inOregon Seek to End Policy That Shaped West
description: BURNS, Ore.  They used to call it Bundyville, a dot of the arid Wild West where in 1916, a Mormon pioneer named Abraham Bundy staked out a homestead in a sea of northern Arizona sagebrush. Settlers caught rainwater in tanks and grazed their livestock across public land that had yet to be brought under government control.

title: Paul Bley, Adventurous Jazz Pianist, Dies at 83
description: Paul Bley, an obdurate and original pianist who began his career playing bebop and eventually became a major force in experimental jazz, died on Sunday at his home in Stuart, Fla. He was 83.

title: Hillary Clinton Pitches Her Qualifications, With Only Hints of the Opposition
description: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa  On Tuesday night, at the last event of a two-day stretch of events across Iowa, Hillary Clinton delivered her most direct closing argument yet as she approaches the final weeks of campaigning before the states Feb. 1 caucuses.

title: For 2 Days at Least, Bloomberg Is Just Another New Yorker
description: The potential juror in seat No. 5 played down his rsum when the judge asked him about his occupation during jury selection on Tuesday for an assault trial. I manage a company, he said, a financial information company.

title: See Also Notations
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Some of us complain about cross-referenced clues in crossword puzzles. Its mostly because when youre in the solving zone  that elusive feeling where you start solving and your writing implement hand doesnt stop moving or your hands dont stop typing until the entire grid is filled  its frustrating to have to stop and look for another clue somewhere else in the grid. It interrupts ones solving CHI, as it were.

title: North Korea Says It Has Detonated Its First Hydrogen Bomb
description: WASHINGTON  North Korea declared on Tuesday that it had detonated its first hydrogen bomb.

title: As Denmark Succeeds, the Goal Moves
description: HELSINKI, Finland  After a 10-2 loss to Canada in the preliminary round in the 2012 world junior championship in Alberta, a handful of Danish players put on a mock news conference while waiting for the team bus to the hotel.

title: Eugenie Schwartz, Artist From New Orleans, Dies at 64
description: Eugenie Schwartz, an artist who found popularity and renown in her native New Orleans for her surreal, darkly humorous pieces, died on Dec. 30 at her home in the Bywater neighborhood there. She was 64.

title: Elizabeth Swados, Creator of Socially Conscious Musicals, Is Dead at 64
description: Elizabeth Swados, a composer, writer and director who fashioned a unique style of socially engaged musical theater, drawing on a global menu of musical styles and a street-level engagement with the politics of the dispossessed, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 64.

description: A Jamaican cricket star who propositioned a female television reporter during a live interview on Monday night was fined by his team in Australias KFC Big Bash League after offering an apology that failed to satisfy many observers.

description: Rangers center Derek Stepan punctuated his first goal with a mighty whoop, but he merely plucked out his mouthpiece and took a right turn toward the bench after pounding in a rebound for his second goal  as if his six-week scoring drought was now old news.

description: ATLANTA  Carmelo Anthony was leaning against a cinder-block wall inside the noisy visitors locker room in Philips Arena late Tuesday night. He seemed to be in a buoyant mood.

Skelos, the former Republican Senate leader, was convicted in December on bribery and extortion charges.

title: 2 Brooklyn Schools in Gentrifying Area Will Get New Zones
description: Education officials on Tuesday approved a plan to redraw two Brooklyn school zones, shifting a neighborhood of rising wealth from a mostly white elementary school to a mostly black and Hispanic one.

title: New York Public Library Invites a Deep Digital Dive
description: Mansion Maniac, a whimsical online toy created by the New York Public Library, may seem like envy bait for the real-estate have-nots. With the help of a Pac-Man-like icon, users can explore the floor plans of some of the citys most extravagant early-20th-century residences, culled from the librarys archives.

description: American Idol gives us a reason to watch again in its 15th  and final  season. So does the anthology series American Crime, whose second installment cries rape. And for those who havent caught on yet, its time to binge on Netflixs River.

description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo issued a surprise executive order over the weekend about homeless people in freezing weather. It was a little confusing.

title: Up With Extremism
description: From its very inception, Donald Trumps campaign for president has been life imitating Twitter. His candidacy is built on Twitter bursts and insults that touch hot buttons, momentarily salve anxieties and put a fist through the face of political correctness, but without any credible programs for implementation.

title: Putins Year in Scandals
description: GOING into 2016, Vladimir V. Putin is a very different politician from the one he was a year ago. His most significant changes have little to do with what he has done in the last 12 months. Instead they were wrought by the justice systems of two foreign countries  Britain and Spain  and a slew of Russian and Western journalists and activists. Thanks to all these disparate efforts, there has emerged a vivid, comprehensive and, most important, public picture of allegations of corruption and connections to organized crime that in the past had been the province of rumors or maverick investigations publishers wouldnt dare to print.

title: In Oregon, Myth Mixes With Anger
description: TO outsiders, one of the puzzling aspects of the anti-government militias takeover of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge is its location. Twenty-five million birds a year visit the refuge in the high desert of southeastern Oregon, but few people have heard of it. Yet Malheur is a place of bitterly contested human histories that remain potent today.

title: Purity, Disgust and Donald Trump
description: What has Donald Trump tapped into that other Republican candidates are missing? I posed this question to some of my best sources.

As many have complained  yours truly included  CES long ago devolved into a noisy parade of puffed-up announcements that usually amount to nothing.

Instead, she spent the month among the areas youth, letting them dictate the subject matter.

title: Jaden Smith for Louis Vuitton: The New Man in a Skirt
description: If 2015 was the year unisex became a trend in fashion, 2016 may be the year the question of gender and dress enters an entirely different dimension, at least judging by the style soothsayer Nicolas Ghesquire, the artistic director of Louis Vuitton, whose ability to sense social change and give it form has made him one of the most successful designers of his generation.

title: Retiring a U.N. Building Not Quite Fit for the World Stage
description: UNITED NATIONS  In New York, temporary train stations, temporary art installations and temporary sidewalk sheds can endure for a decade or more. So it is a marvel to report that an interim building will turn out to be just that.

title: In Iowa, Ted Cruz Savors Lead Role
description: ONAWA, Iowa  Senator Ted Cruz of Texas insists he does not want to be seen as the front-runner in the Iowa caucuses. The only way I know how to run is as an underdog, he said here after a speech on Tuesday, waving off any Joe Namath-style guarantee of victory.

description: The north-central New Jersey town offers a lively, pedestrian-friendly, walkable community.

title: Morristown, N.J., Historic With a Lively Downtown
description: Mike Knapp, 25, was a systems analyst living in Hoboken, N.J., and working in Basking Ridge, N.J., a 45-minute slog to the west. He wanted to move closer to the office but hang on to the lively Hoboken vibe.

title: An Artist Stands Before Her Fun House Mirror
description: LOS ANGELES  On a recent Friday afternoon, Genevieve Gaignard, a photographer, collagist and installation artist, was sitting on her bed in the room she rents in the Echo Park neighborhood. For the last year, Ms. Gaignard, who takes self-portraits costumed as various alter egos she imagines, then builds fictional domestic spaces for them, has lived in this nondescript, book-filled and thoroughly carpeted apartment with a professional couple in their late 20s, their chatty lime-green parrot and three cats.

title: Security Council Condemns Nuclear Test by North Korea
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council condemned North Korea for its nuclear test on Wednesday, but there was no evidence yet that the Norths most powerful backer, China, was willing to stiffen sanctions in a way that could push the unpredictable country to the point of collapse or slow its nuclear progress.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing.

title: Supporters Seek to Persuade Democrats to Ditch and Switch for Donald Trump
description: At a campaign event for Donald J. Trump in Mississippi last weekend, Lynette Hardaway and Rochelle Richardson  two African-American YouTube stars who go by the names Diamond and Silk  rallied the roaring crowd with a plea. Ditch and switch! Ditch and switch! they yelled.

description: All three Democratic presidential candidates are expected to attend a dinner in Las Vegas on Wednesday hosted by the Nevada State Democratic Party and Senator Harry Reid, the minority leader.

title: Senator Chris Murphy Says Obamas Actions on Guns Are Necessary but Totally Insufficient
description: For Senator Chris Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut, gun violence was not an issue he ran on: It chose him. The massacre at Newtown Elementary School in Sandy Hook happened a month after he won his seat.

title: My Marriage Didnt End When I Became a Widow
description: When my husband died from cancer last March at age 37, I was so grief-stricken I could barely sleep. One afternoon, I visited his grave  in a field high in the Santa Cruz Mountains, overlooking the Pacific Ocean  and lay on top of it. I slept more soundly than I had in weeks. It wasnt the vista that calmed my restless body; it was Paul, just there, under the earth. His body was so easy to conjure limbs that had linked with mine at night, soft hands that I had grasped during the birth of our daughter, eyes that had remained piercing even as cancer thinned his face  and yet, impossible to hold. I lay on the grass instead, my cheek against the ground.

title: Avoiding the Dreaded Second-Term Curse
description: Two years ago, as President Obama wrestled with an array of political challenges, pundits and partisans reached for a familiar explanation: the second-term curse.

title: Why Do We Feed Wild Animals?
description: White-haired, with a faintly aristocratic glamour, Mrs. Leslie-Smith lived alone in a wooden bungalow full of books and glossy houseplants a few doors from my childhood home. One warm autumn evening more than 30 years ago, she invited my mother and me to watch her nightly ritual. She scattered broken cookies outside her garden doors, where they glittered dustily under the light of an outside lamp. We sat in the darkened room and waited. A striped black-and-white face appeared at the edge of the illuminated lawn. Then, out of the night, two badgers trundled across the grass to crunch up the cookies, so close to us that we could see their ivory teeth and the patterned skin on their noses. They werent tame  if we had turned on the light, they would have bolted  but I wanted to press my hands to the glass to get closer to them, to somehow make them understand I was there. The space between us in the house and these wild creatures in the garden was filled with unexpected magic.

title: Debbie Wasserman Schultz Thinks Young Women Are Complacent
description: After the Bernie Sanders campaign improperly accessed voter data, the Democratic National Committee was swift with its punishment, suspending his campaign from having access to the database. How did you come up with that sanction? Quite honestly, we are putting this behind us. The American people deserve an intelligent debate, and this isnt one.

title: Judge John Hodgman on What Makes a Caesar
description: Jillian from Quebec writes: My husband and I have had a decade-long dispute about my putting cauliflower in Caesar salads. My husband thinks its a mistake. I wrote to Dan Pashman of WNYCs The Sporkful, and he sided with me.

title: The Mystic, the Monk and the Play Brought to You by Powerball
description: It sounds like the setup for some kind of droll joke: A lottery winner and a rhinoceros arrive at the birthday party for a dead mystic. Art, and a blowout brawl, ensues.

title: Do We Have to Send Our Kid to a Bad Public School?
description: My wife and I are an interracial couple living in Oakland, Calif. We are both first-generation college graduates for whom solid public-school educations made all the difference. We are struggling with choosing a public school for our son, who will enter kindergarten this year. State test scores came out recently, and our neighborhood public school, which is filled with some of the citys poorest kids, scored very low. I have to believe there is something seriously wrong with how the school is educating kids. (Otherwise, the school, which we know fairly well through volunteering, seems perfectly fine.) My wife and I both work full-time and also care for her mother and disabled sibling, so we know that we cant put in the kind of time that would be required to turn the school around. We also fear that we cannot teach our son enough outside school hours to make up for a significant deficit in his education.

title: The Lawyer Who Became DuPonts Worst Nightmare
description: Just months before Rob Bilott made partner at Taft Stettinius & Hollister, he received a call on his direct line from a cattle farmer. The farmer, Wilbur Tennant of Parkersburg, W.Va., said that his cows were dying left and right. He believed that the DuPont chemical company, which until recently operated a site in Parkersburg that is more than 35 times the size of the Pentagon, was responsible. Tennant had tried to seek help locally, he said, but DuPont just about owned the entire town. He had been spurned not only by Parkersburgs lawyers but also by its politicians, journalists, doctors and veterinarians. The farmer was angry and spoke in a heavy Appalachian accent. Bilott struggled to make sense of everything he was saying. He might have hung up had Tennant not blurted out the name of Bilotts grandmother, Alma Holland White.

title: Charlotte Rampling and Those Dolly Birds
description: Charlotte Rampling, the elusive, slow-burning British actress, astounded audiences this season with her performance opposite Tom Courtenay in 45 Years, about a long-married couple struggling with a revelation about the husbands girlfriend from long ago. While overlooked by the Golden Globes, Ms. Rampling, 69, collected a slew of awards and nominations for her portrayal, and is predicted to garner her first Oscar nod when the nominations are announced on Jan. 14. Last month, in the lounge of the Soho Grand Hotel, Ms. Rampling spoke with the Bagger about avoiding dolly bird roles, wandering men and her endless admiration for Cate Blanchett. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: How the Daily Fantasy Sports Industry Turns Fans Into Suckers
description: Full disclosure: I am a 36-year-old dude who bores easily, drinks I.P.A.s and wears sports-themed T-shirts, especially ones with faded, nostalgic logos that suggest better times. In my early 20s, I developed a gambling problem that Ive since learned to spread out over a variety of low-stakes games  Scrabble, pitch-and-putt golf, my stock profile on ETrade. I watch somewhere between six and 20 hours of basketball per week. I try to keep up with the usual cultural things  documentaries about conflict in South Sudan, Netflix binge shows, memes  but whenever I find myself awake in the early morning and there is no email to answer and no news to track, I watch SportsCenter, or I scan the previous nights N.B.A. box scores to check up on Porzingis, or I read some dissertation on Johnny Cuetos unusual ability to hold runners on first base. Its not the most glamorous way to spend my time, but what can I do? My mind, at its most aimless, obsessively seeks out sports information. I am, in other words, the target demographic for the daily fantasy sports industry.

title: Pierre Boulez, Composer and Conductor Who Pushed Modernisms Boundaries, Dies at 90
description: Pierre Boulez, the French composer and conductor who helped blaze a radical new path for classical music in the 20th century, becoming one of its dominant figures in the decades after World War II, died on Tuesday at his home in Baden-Baden, Germany. He was 90.

title: A Day of Policy, Dropped Guards and Rancor
description: In a campaign that has been overshadowed and altered by Donald J. Trump, the debate has focused heavily on immigration and on a general disgust with Washington. But Tuesday was a rare day that was thick with policy substance and increased tensions among candidates.

title: Did North Korea Detonate a Hydrogen Bomb? Heres What We Know
description: North Koreas claim that it set off a hydrogen bomb on Wednesday  in what would be the fourth time it has tested a nuclear weapon since 2006  has stirred concerns among governments around the world. Below is a brief primer on some of the central issues at stake.

title: Roche Leads a $175 Million Investment in Flatiron Health
description: Even with some recent wobbles in the start-up world, big sums are continuing to roll into technology start-ups.

title: Art Dealers Fraud Trial in Paris is Delayed
description: PARIS  A French court on Wednesday delayed the tax fraud trial of the international art dealer Guy Wildenstein until May to examine constitutional questions raised by his defense lawyers.

title: Jeremy Corbyn, British Labour Leader, Finishes Shadow Cabinet Reorganization
description: LONDON  The leader of Britains opposition Labour Party, Jeremy Corbyn, completed the first reshuffling of his shadow cabinet early Wednesday morning, producing only minor changes after two days of internal argument.

title: Bird-Watching, Patriotism and the Oregon Standoff
description: In 1965, at the height of his substance abuse, Johnny Cash was called in to make a deposition, but not about possessing drugs. Instead, the singer was in trouble for leaving a burning truck at the side of a road in Los Padres National Forest in California. The flames had started a forest fire that jeopardized not only the refuge itself, but the lives of nearly 50 critically endangered California condors, which at that time made up a sizable portion of the global population. Facing the prospect of a lawsuit, and filled with amphetamines and arrogance, as his autobiography put it, Cash defiantly told his government questioners, I dont give a damn about your yellow buzzards.

title: Bookshelf: Small Delights
description: New board books include Good Night! and Who Done It?

title: Equality Under the Law? Investigating Race and the Justice System
description: Have we reached a point in our nations history when all citizens receive equal protection under the law, as guaranteed by the 14th Amendment?

title: Free Same-Day Tickets to Hamilton
description: Dear Diary:

title: 1941: Roosevelt Urges Arms Loans
description: WASHINGTON  President Roosevelt, delivering in person his annual message to Congress on the state of the Union, recommended today [Jan. 6] that Congress appropriate billions of dollars for the manufacture of warplanes, tanks, guns and ships to be lent to nations resisting aggression, such as Great Britain, China and Greece. The President specified that our most useful and immediate role in the second world war is not to send man power overseas, but to serve as an arsenal for the nations which are defending themselves and looking to us for material assistance. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 7, 1941

title: North Koreas Hydrogen Bomb Claim Strains Ties With China
description: BEIJING  North Koreas test of a nuclear bomb on Wednesday seemed aimed at antagonizing a familiar adversary, the United States. The army spoke of the need to ward off imperialist aggressors, and a television commentator warned that foreigners were intent on destroying the countrys way of life.

title: Donald Trump Keeps Pushing Ted Cruz Citizenship Issue
description: Donald J. Trump continued to fan the flames of doubt over Senator Ted Cruzs citizenship on Wednesday, suggesting that his Canadian roots might be a problem if he won the Republican presidential nomination.

title: What You Get for  $1,350,000
description: A timber-frame house in Montana, a contemporary in San Diego and a farmhouse in Massachusetts

title: $1,350,000 Homes in San Diego, Massachusetts and Montana
description: WEST YELLOWSTONE, MONT.

title: Starboard Value Calls for Shake-Up at Yahoo and Shift in Strategy
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoo, already on its back foot after abandoning one plan to break up the company to pursue another, is closer to facing a new challenge: a potential fight over its own board.

title: Valeant Names Howard B. Schiller Interim C.E.O.
description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International said on Wednesday that it had named an interim chief executive as its leader remained in the hospital, where he is being treated for severe pneumonia.

title: The Biggest Challenges of 2016
description: At the end of 2015, we asked what you felt was the greatest challenge facing the United States in the coming year. Over a thousand readers responded, and while their answers varied widely, a few common themes emerged. Below are some of the issues readers brought up the most frequently:

title: Antarctic Life: No Dogs, Few Vegetables and a Little Intense in the Winter
description: VILLA LAS ESTRELLAS, Antarctica  Children at the schoolhouse here study under a portrait of Bernardo OHiggins, Chiles independence leader. The bank manager welcomes deposits in Chilean pesos. The cellphone service from the Chilean phone company Entel is so robust that downloading iPhone apps works like a charm.

title: A Clifftop Villa in Tobago
description: The 7,000-square-foot Indonesian-influenced house, which overlooks the ocean, is on the market for $4.43 million.

title: House Hunting in ...Trinidad and Tobago
description: A CLIFF-TOP VILLA OF BALINESE-STYLE PAVILIONS IN TOBAGO

title: Daily Report: The Limitations of 4K TVs
description: High-resolution 4K TVs are hardly new. Theyve been around for a few years  and each year, marketers say this is the time to buy one.

title: Charlie Hebdo, Known for Its Satire, Commemorates Attack Accordingly
description: PARIS  A special issue of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo went on sale in France on Wednesday, amid a week of official commemorations and other events paying tribute to the 17 people who were killed one year ago in attacks last January at the newspapers office and other locations in the Paris area.

title: Setting Up Tabs to Open Automatically in Microsoft Edge
description: Q. Is there a way to make the Microsoft Edge browser in Windows 10 open multiple preset tabs when the program is started?

title: Seeking Higher Ground After Inundation
description: After a flood in 1993 destroyed much of Valmeyer, Ill., its residents decided to leave it behind and move the town elsewhere.

title: A Town Drowned and Resurrected on a Bluff Misses Its Old Home
description: VALMEYER, Ill.  This little town on the Mississippi River nearly drowned in the Great Flood of 1993. Houses filled with 16 feet of muddy water. Streets disintegrated and washed away. After Valmeyers 900 residents surveyed the wreckage, they vowed, tired and grieving, that they would not let it happen again.

title: Father Charged With Murder in Death of Pregnant Daughter
description: At five months pregnant, Andrea Caruth was counting down the days until she learned the gender of her baby. She had arranged to meet her best friend for a shopping trip after a doctors visit on Wednesday, another step toward motherhood for a woman who had looked forward to it for years as she took care of young children at a day care center in her home in the Bronx.

title: Donald Trump Is Also an Outlier in Political Science
description: Donald Trump has confounded politicians, pundits and political scientists as he runs a most unconventional  and so far successful  campaign to win the Republican presidential nomination. Heres the way we think these things are supposed to play out: Party leaders shape and guide the nomination process. We call it the invisible primary, and it was described in an influential 2008 book, The Party Decides. I asked David Karol, a University of Maryland associate professor of political science and one of the books four authors, whether Mr. Trumps rise reveals a fundamental shift in party control. He thinks not. Heres our conversation, slightly edited.

title: Life in the Sleepy Oregon County Where Armed Protesters Have Occupied a Wildlife Refuge
description: A small group of armed protesters have seized parts of a wildlife sanctuary  putting a rural Oregon county in the spotlight.

title: Taxpayer Advocate Warns of Pay to Play I.R.S. System
description: Under pressure from Congress to do more with less, the Internal Revenue Service is planning to increase its reliance on technology and tax preparers. But this push threatens to create a pay to play system where the only taxpayers who will receive personalized service are those who can afford to pay for it, the agencys taxpayer advocate warned.

title: 1966: India and Pakistan Near Truce
description: TASHKENT, U.S.S.R.  India and Pakistan have virtually agreed on an agenda for their conference here and have made progress toward a nonaggression pact that may be signed in the next few days, authoritative diplomatic sources said today [Jan. 6]. The agreement was reportedly hammered out today during separate talks that Soviet Premier Alexei N. Kosygin held with Pakistani President Mohammed Ayub Khan and Indian Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri. The two Asian leaders are also considering an agreement to withdraw occupation troops from both countries. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 7, 1966

title: Georgia Town Teaches Fight Back as Option in Mass Shootings
description: DOUGLASVILLE, Ga.  When the police held town hall meetings here in the past, they were lucky to see a half-dozen people. But the topic of the most recent one was Active Shooter: A Citizens Guide to Planning for Survival. And the place was packed.

title: France Forfeits Its Own Values
description: HOUSTON  IN French, the word dchance has several meanings, all of them bleak. It can refer to the fall of a civilization, or the degradation of the social fabric. More formally, it means the forfeiture of a right or a possession  ones citizenship, for example. All three meanings, carrying echoes of the countrys experience under Vichy, resonate in a political drama unfolding in France.

title: Chipotle Is Subpoenaed in Criminal Inquiry Over Norovirus Outbreak
description: Chipotle Mexican Grill said on Wednesday that it had been served a federal grand jury subpoena as part of a criminal investigation seeking information about a norovirus outbreak at a California restaurant.

title: Lauren Gunderson on I and You, a Play With an Explosive Twist
description: A playwright who makes a living writing plays is an anomaly in any city, but its especially rare to build a viable career almost entirely outside New York. It has worked for Lauren Gunderson, whose plays have been steadily produced by theaters around the country, including in her current home base, San Francisco, since she received a masters in dramatic writing from New York University in 2009.

title: Great Recipes for the Middle of the Week
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Chiefs Enter Playoffs as N.F.L.s Hottest Team
description: Not that long ago, the Kansas City Chiefs season appeared to have gone badly awry. With a loss to the Vikings on Oct. 18, the Chiefs fell to 1-5. Their star running back, Jamaal Charles, was out for the year with a torn anterior cruciate ligament. Coach Andy Reid was under fire, notably for a puzzling decision to hand off to Charles at the end of regulation in Week 2 against Denver, which led to a fumble and a loss.

title: Samantha Bee Prepares to Debut Full Frontal
description: It was crunchtime for Samantha Bee.

title: The Power of Documentaries on the Oscar Trail
description: Its way too easy to feel jaded about Oscar season. The forced pomp, the moneyed campaigns, the boggling repetition of dozens of awards fetes could jaundice any eye. But its tougher to be cynical about the documentary category, where an Oscar nomination, let alone a win, can have mighty ripple effects.

title: North Korea Blast Revives Question: How Do You Contain Pyongyang?
description: WASHINGTON  Early in his first term, President Obama conducted some quick triage on how his administration would face a gamut of nuclear challenges: Focus on stopping Irans nuclear program before it succeeded in building a weapon, but do not waste a lot of energy trying to roll back a North Korean program that had already built a small arsenal that the desperately poor country had little incentive to give up.

title: Two Workers Charged in Hay Theft
description: Angel H. Parra Penafiel and Hugo Ramirez-Morales have been charged with felony grand larceny in the theft of about $30,000 worth of hay over nearly three years in Westchester County.

title: Chris Christie Taking High Road in Ad Responding to Marco Rubio
description: Finding himself the target of numerous attack ads in New Hampshire, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is responding with an ad titled We Need to Keep Our Eye on the Ball, running only in the Granite State.

title: Michael Weatherly Leaving NCIS
description: Michael Weatherly, who plays the roguish agent Tony DiNozzo on NCIS, confirmed Tuesday night that he was leaving CBSs popular crime procedural after 13 seasons. He will leave the show at the end of the current season, which concludes in April.

title: In Lois Colley Murder Investigation, 2 Are Accused of Stealing Hay From Farm
description: Investigators trying to solve the murder of a Westchester County socialite on her familys 300-acre horse farm have yet to unravel a killing that has captivated and mystified residents in one of the New York City regions most affluent and tranquil communities.

title: Pinterest Hires Its First Head of Diversity
description: Like much of corporate America, Silicon Valley has long had a workplace diversity problem. That is leading to the emergence of a new job title: chief diversity officer.

title: Edit Tweets? Users Debate a Missing Twitter Feature
description: Never mind longer tweets, many Twitter users are saying. What about an editing function?

title: Iraq Offers to Mediate Dispute Between Saudi Arabia and Iran
description: CAIRO  Iraqs foreign minister on Wednesday offered to mediate the fight raging between Saudi Arabia and Iran over the Saudi governments execution of a dissident Shiite cleric, saying that we need to stop the escalations.

title: Home Entertainment Sales Remain Stagnant
description: More of the same is what the Digital Entertainment Group reported in its year-end summary of home entertainment sales in the United States. Total sales of films and television shows in home entertainment formats are still treading water, having risen less than 1 percent for the year, to about $18.1 billion in 2015 from about $17.9 billion in 2014, according to the organizations preliminary numbers released on Wednesday.

title: Emma Rice Bringing a New Take on Cymbeline to Shakespeares Globe
description: LONDON  Emma Rice will kick off her first season as artistic director of Shakespeares Globe this spring with one of Shakespeares best-loved classics and one that has never been seen.

title: LOral Takes the Wearables War to the Beauty Counter
description: LOral is not a name usually associated with International CES, the annual consumer electronics show, but Guive Balooch, global vice president of LOrals Technology Incubator, was in Las Vegas on Wednesday to unveil the beauty giants new foray into wearable tech  and its not a bracelet (thank the heavens).

title: Oculus Rift Will Cost $599
description: Facebooks Oculus is finally offering clarity on how much of a premium a virtual reality experience will cost.

title: Political GIFs Are the New Sound Bites This Campaign Season
description: Every few decades, a piece of technology comes along that alters political campaigning.

title: Why People With Mental Illness Are Able to Obtain Guns
description: A major background check loophole, variation in state laws and incomplete record-sharing leave openings for people with mental illness to purchase guns.

title: Samuel L. Jackson Defends Use of Epithet in Hateful Eight
description: One of the parlor games this winter movie season has been counting the number of times a certain racial epithet is uttered in Quentin Tarantinos new film, The Hateful Eight. The answer, according to Gawker, is about 65 times, which is less than in his last film, Django Unchained, where he recorded his all-time high, of sorts, for the words usage onscreen.

title: Where Home Brewers Tell Their Tales
description: Bitter & Esters, in Prospect Heights, sells equipment for the growing home-brew industry, holds classes and has educational tastings.

title: A Bright Idea Among Wall Streets European Pay Disclosures
description: Wall Streets disclosure of European pay practices combines the useful and the useless.

title: MDLSX, From the Troupe Motus, Comes to La MaMa Downstairs
description: MDLSX: At first glance, the title of the latest offering from Motus  a boundary-defying international theater troupe that honestly and ardently aspires to the revolutionary  brings to mind an optometrists eye chart. But look again, a directive that is implicit in all Motus productions; imagine these letters connected by vowels. Now, perhaps, you start to see Middlesex, with its suggestions of indeterminate gender (and the title of a Pulitzer Prize-winning novel on just that subject by Jeffrey Eugenides), or muddle or medium, large, small.

title: Review: In When Breath Becomes Air, Dr. Paul Kalanithi Confronts an Early Death
description: When Dr. Paul Kalanithi sent his best friend an email in May 2013 revealing that he had terminal cancer, he wrote: The good news is that Ive already outlived two Bronts, Keats and Stephen Crane. The bad news is that I havent written anything. It was a jokey way of dealing with the unthinkable but also an indication of Dr. Kalanithis tremendous ambition. He had led a fascinating life and was not about to leave it unchronicled.

title: CologneMayors Arms Length Advice on Sexual Attacks Stirs Outcry
description: BERLIN  The mayor of Cologne has inflamed a debate in Germany about migrants and sexual harassment by suggesting that women can protect themselves from men on the streets by keeping them more than an arms length away.

title: Gilbert E. Kaplan, Publisher and Improbable Conductor, Dies at 74
description: Gilbert E. Kaplan, a financial publisher who had an accidental second career as an international symphony conductor  despite the fact that he could scarcely read music and possessed a concert repertoire of exactly one piece  died on New Years Day in Manhattan. He was 74.

title: Ted Cruzs Iowa Bus Tour: The Crazy Nutcase With the Nuclear Bomb
description: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016s first proper campaign bus tour.

title: Cuomo Proposes $22 Billion to Improve New Yorks Roads and Bridges
description: As part of a broader push to modernize New Yorks infrastructure, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Wednesday proposed spending $22 billion to improve state roads and bridges.

title: Younger Ages Into a Second Season on TV Land
description: For women stung by ageism in the workplace, Younger, the Darren Star series on TV Land, might at first have seemed like a lame joke. Not the part where Liza, a divorced 40-year-old with an Ivy League degree played by Sutton Foster, struggles to re-enter the publishing world after a long absence taken to raise her daughter  that rang all too true. Rather, the part where she hooks up with a 26-year-old tattoo artist who eyes her fresh face and killer body and assumes shes in his demographic. Which sparks the notion that, with a bit of cosmetic tweaking and online purging, she can shave off enough years to begin anew. Right. If only job security were as simple as calling your hair stylist.

title: Enrique Marquez Pleads Not Guilty in San Bernardino Massacre Case
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.  Enrique Marquez pleaded not guilty Wednesday on charges of supplying two assault weapons that Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik used to massacre 14 people at the Inland Regional Center in San Bernardino last month. Mr. Marquez, dressed in a white jumpsuit, his legs and hand shackled, spoke in a clear voice as he entered his plea on that charge, as well as on counts that he and Mr. Farook had conspired on an earlier terrorist plot that was not carried out. Answering a series of questions from the United States Magistrate, Sheri Pym, Mr. Marquez said he had been informed of his constitutional rights and read the indictment. The hearing for Mr. Marquez, who is 24 and was a longtime friend of Mr. Farooks, lasted just over four minutes. Ms. Pym set the trial for Feb. 23.

title: Hindu Heroes, Savored Through Fantastical Masks at the Met
description: Its a short step from religious ritual to theater, and barely any distance at all in the case of certain popular Hindu dramas of southern India. Performed during seasonal festivals, they are epic in length  they go on for hours, often through the night  and fantastic in character, telling the stories of gods who have the adventure-filled lives of superheroes. You get a vivid sense of this proto-Star Wars mood in Encountering Vishnu: The Lion Avatar in Indian Temple Drama at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Met recently acquired five large 18th-century wooden masks created for a play about the god Vishnu who, in the guise of the lion-man called Narasimha, visited earth to defeat an evil king and restore order to the universe. The masks are stupendous, and paintings and prints that the Met has placed around them flesh out a tale that, even today, can inspire devotional rapture under the stars. (metmuseum.org)

title: Bone Tomahawk Gets Another Look
description: Patrick Wilson had a memorable 2015 in Season 2 of Fargo, the much-admired, marvelously off-kilter FX television series, but he was also part of another unorthodox project last year, the horror western Bone Tomahawk. The movie received a limited theatrical run in October but deserves much more, and the Museum of Modern Art is doing its part by giving it a showing at 7:30 p.m. on Tuesday, Jan. 12, in a series it calls The Contenders, which spotlights films of significance from last year that went relatively unnoticed.

title: Big Opera or Cozy Concert? Take Your Pick
description: Grand and intimate square off across 65th Street this week. At the Metropolitan Opera, Franco Zeffirellis gargantuan production of Puccinis Turandot returns with the formidable soprano Nina Stemme in the title role. (She portrays Strausss Elektra in April.) The experienced Paolo Carignani conducts, Marco Berti is Calaf, and Anita Hartig is Li. But the real star is the Zeffirelli spectacle, alternately cheesy and enchanting. (7:30 p.m., Monday, Jan. 11, and 8 p.m., Friday, Jan. 15; metopera.org.)

title: Fed Minutes Show Some Concern on Economic Outlook
description: WASHINGTON  Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, marshaled a strong consensus among Fed officials for the momentous decision to raise the central banks benchmark interest rate last month, but concerns among policy makers about the strength of economic growth could slow the march toward higher rates.

title: Fixing Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Futurist Cocktails in Milan
description: The citys Surfers Den is at the forefront of a crop of bars reimagining recipes from the freewheeling, century-old art movement.

title: In Milan, a New Spin on a Century-Old Cocktail
description: More than a century ago, the Italian artists of the Futurist movement issued the first of their provocative manifestos  a call for art that would shock the countrys bucolic peasant society into the industrialized age. The artists broadcast their message in paintings of speed and flight, in antagonistic theater pieces that frequently ended in fistfights and eventually  as would happen perhaps only in Italy  in a cookbook. We will now establish the way of eating best-suited to an ever more high-speed, airborne life, declared their leader, Filippo Tomasso Marinetti. The Futurist Cookbook, published in 1932, detailed multisensory scenarios and the anarchic dishes and drinks that composed the artists dinners  events for curious guests and journalists, witnesses to the Futurist demands to refashion Italy from art to plate.

title: Why Experts Doubt That North Korea Tested a Hydrogen Bomb
description: North Korea claimed on Wednesday that it had tested a hydrogen bomb, the most powerful kind of nuclear weapon.

title: Nearly Eternal, a Subversive Take on Food
description: The photographer Norbert Schoerner and the art director Steve Nakamura explore the boundaries between the real and artificial.

title: Demanding Action on Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: A Subversive, Uncanny Look at Food
description: Whether its a raw egg yolk gripped by levitating chopsticks or sugar magically sprinkling over a juicy grapefruit, the images in the new book Nearly Eternal are a surreal  and slightly sinister  take on food.

title: Robert De Niros Caribbean Resort Plan Draws Criticism
description: In the year since the government of Antigua and Barbuda and investors led by the actor Robert De Niro announced plans to open a luxury resort on the smaller of the dual-island nation, protests have surfaced and the project has stalled, though the government vows construction will begin this year.

title: In Fiddler, a Balancing Act to Rival Tevyes
description: Fiddler on the Roof is about balance. The idea is there in the title image and at the start of the show, when the dairyman protagonist, Tevye, explains that the people of his shtetl maintain their balance by relying on tradition. Much of the plot challenges him to keep his footing while adapting to new ways.

title: Latinos and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Compassion for Syrian Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Marco Rubios Cute Boots and Other Campaign Issues
description: It was a quick Tweet, dashed off in a few seconds, observing an (unimportant) moment of fashion on the presidential campaign trail. Then it went viral, triggering endless speculation, campaign attacks and a series of news stories illustrating how mysterious, powerful and, yes, trivial, social media can be.

title: At CES, Netflix Adds Over 130 Countries to Streaming Service
description: Netflix went live with its streaming television service in nearly every country across the world on Wednesday, an unexpected acceleration of the companys aggressive quest for global ubiquity by the end of 2016.

title: Robert H.B. Baldwin, Transformer of Morgan Stanley, Dies at 95
description: Robert H. B. Baldwin, a Wall Street maverick who presided over the transformation of Morgan Stanley from a prestigious but staid old investment bank into a modern, competitive financial services corporation in the 1970s and early 80s, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Skillman, N.J., near Princeton. He was 95.

title: Prison Guards Contract
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Capital Fund-Raising Goal Rises to a Record $946 Billion
description: The number of private capital funds raising money from investors is on the rise, and the amount they are seeking to raise is a record $946 billion at the beginning of the year. That surpasses the previous high-water mark in terms of fund-raising goals set at the beginning of 2009, according to new data from Preqin.

title: Grindr, the Gay Dating App, Hooks Up With Fashion
description: When the monthlong marathon of mens fashion shows kicks off this week, so will the scrimmage to cover it: the race by newspapers, magazines, television networks, social media platforms and blogs to get a piece of the action for themselves and their viewers.

title: Alex Gordon,Leader of Royals Title Run, Signs 4-Year Deal
description: When the Mets and the Kansas City Royals meet on opening night in a rematch of the 2015 World Series, many of the faces across the field from the Mets will look familiar, and the group will include Alex Gordon, the face of the franchise. On Wednesday, Gordon unexpectedly re-signed with the team for four years and $68 million, with a $23 million mutual option for a fifth year or a $4 million buyout.

title: Former Walking Dead Producer Blasts AMC
description: The original show runner for the hit AMC series The Walking Dead has painted an unflattering depiction of that networks executives, accusing them of slashing the budgets for the horror drama just as the show was finding success and of failing to adequately appreciate the often grueling work of its cast and crew.

title: Ted Cruzs Iowa Bus Tour: Coffee, Cookies and a Song
description: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These arethe places, faces and culinary selectionsof 2016s first proper bus tour.

title: A Beloved L.A. Chefs Restorative Turmeric Tonic
description: Ask your body what it needs and know when its satisfied, says Jessica Koslow, the chef-owner of the wildly popular Sqirl restaurant in Los Angeles. Thats the mantra. When she broke her ankle a few years ago, Koslow says she went looking for anything to help this lady who stands in the kitchen all day. She found turmeric, a native rhizome of India known for its anti-inflammatory properties, and incorporated it into a healing elixir. I enjoyed it so much that I played around with a recipe for it that I could serve daily at the restaurant. For the new year, she created a new tonic  a take on the traditional hot toddy, and what she calls a healthy, digestive sleep aid. Others might just call it delicious.

title: China Weighs Ban on Manta Ray Gills, Sold in Traditional Market as Modern Panacea
description: GUANGZHOU, China  Depending on ones point of view, the huge Qingping market here offers either one of Chinas largest selections of natural healing ingredients for traditional Chinese medicine or a vast array of desiccated and dismembered animal carcasses hawked by little better than snake oil salesmen, some of whom actually sell snake-based remedies.

title: Six Steps to Teaching Children About the Stock Market
description: In the first three trading days of the new year, the stock market has fallen far enough and fast enough that it has prompted news alerts on phones and shouting heads on television. So why would you want to expose your children to any of that?

title: Wheaton Professor May Be Fired for Pro-Islam Stance
description: A college professor in Illinois who is at risk of being fired for her remarks on Islam and Christianity spoke out on Wednesday, saying she was grateful for her supporters.

title: Obama to Nominate Joseph Votel as Head of U.S. Central Command
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will nominate Gen. Joseph L. Votel, the head of Special Operations Command, to replace Gen. Lloyd J. Austin as the next leader of United States Central Command, Defense Department officials said Wednesday.

title: Rules for Police Use of Deadly Force
description: To the Editor:

title: You Asked, Donald Trump Answered
description: During a visit to the editorial board, the candidate took a moment to answer a question from a Times reader.

title: You Asked, Donald Trump Answered
description: On Tuesday, we asked you to submit questions for Donald Trump. During his visit to the editorial board, he picked one of your questions from a hat to answer on camera. Watch his response below:

title: Commuter Transit Benefit Becomes More Generous
description: The new year is bringing some good news for workers who participate in their employers commuter benefits program to help pay for the cost of going to work by mass transit.

title: Top Alabama Judge Orders Halt to Same-Sex Marriage Licenses
description: ATLANTA  The chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, Roy S. Moore, on Wednesday effectively ordered probate judges in the state not to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, a move that could cloud the carrying out of the United States Supreme Court decision that legalized same-sex unions.

title: From Lulu to Madama Butterfly, Tragedy Transcended by a Visceral Truth
description: Is there a bleaker opera than Bergs Lulu, with its wrenching 12-tone score and sordidly depressing story? It tells of a calculating femme fatale who can also be seen as a victimized young woman getting ahead as best she can in a male-dominated society. The opera would seem guaranteed to leave you shattered, almost sickened.

title: J.P. Morgan Securities Fined $4 Million for False Statements to Clients
description: Regulators have fined J.P. Morgan Securities $4 million for making false statements on the client website of its private bank and in its marketing materials about how its private bank advisers are paid.

title: Talking Hops at Bitter & Esters in Prospect Heights
description: Except for maybe that final celebratory phase, home brewing seems to be a solitary endeavor. But at Bitter & Esters, a home-brew shop in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, hopeful brewers discuss all parts of the process with like-minded beer aficionados, from the minutiae (and there is quite a lot of detail) to the merrymaking when an especially good batch is turned out.

title: Kamoinges Half-Century of African-American Photography
description: A new book takes a look at the collectives groundbreaking work in speaking of our lives as only we can.

title: More Than 180,000 Drone Users Registered in F.A.A. Database
description: The Federal Aviation Administration on Wednesday said that about 181,000 drone users had registered in the two and half weeks since the agency began requiring registration of the popular machines.

title: Report of Orgy at Brussels Police Station Is Unfounded, Officials Say
description: PARIS  Reports of an orgy involving two female Brussels police officers and a group of Belgian soldiers on a night when Brussels was on high alert for a terrorist attack are unfounded, a Brussels police spokeswoman said Wednesday.

title: Pictures of the Day: Serbia and Elsewhere
description: Serbia and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

title: Jan. 6, 2016  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Serbia, Yemen, Syria and the United States.

title: An Art Performance That Takes Stock  Literally
description: A Wharton graduate with an M.F.A. from Yale, Sarah Meyohas has impressive credentials  but its her extracurricular activities that put the 24-year-old artist ahead of her class. This Friday night, Meyohas kicks off a 10-day residency at 303 Gallery with a performance on financial markets, which she describes as a pseudo-lecture on the current state of affairs. (A related project is her cheekily named art-world cryptocurrency, one unit of which equates to 25 square inches of photographic print.)

title: Rumors of Immigration Raids Stoke Fear in New York
description: The rumors had been flying in the New York area since Saturday: Officials from Immigration and Customs Enforcement had swooped into churches and public schools, dragged away an undocumented family at the Staten Island Mall, pulled over drivers on the Southern State Parkway and set up blockades in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, and at the Staten Island Ferry.

title: You Asked, John Kasich Answered
description: During a visit to the editorial board, the candidate took a moment to answer a question from a Times reader.

title: Ebola Treatment Using Plasma From Survivors Is Not Effective, Study Says
description: A treatment once considered among the most promising for Ebola patients was not found to be effective in a study performed in Guinea, researchers reported Wednesday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Girls Will Say Goodbye After Sixth Season
description: Four years after Hannah Horvaths parents cut her off in the first episode of HBOs Girls, the network has announced that Lena Dunham and the shows other creators will be doing the same thing to their audience. The shows sixth season, scheduled to be broadcast in 2017, will be its last, the network said.

title: A Fresh Start at Dover Street Market, and an End-of-Season Sale atTotokaelo
description: Out with the old, in with the new. This week, Dover Street Market has a special installation featuring 10 unique sculptural forms encrusted with tactile materials like terrazzo, clustered rocks and semiprecious stones with healing properties from the New York design practice Amoia Studio ($5,000 for a 15-by-18-inch column) and Anndra Neen cage clutches ($675). At 160 Lexington Avenue.

title: At Morgan Stanley, a Promotion and a Departure in the Top Executive Ranks
description: A shuffle at the top of Morgan Stanley has led to the departure of Gregory J. Fleming, an executive who was once seen as a leading candidate to run the Wall Street firm.

title: Review: Blackstar, David Bowies Emotive and Cryptic New Album
description: Blackstar

title: Paiute Indians Assert Legacy on Occupied Wildlife Refuge Land
description: BURNS, Ore.  Hundreds of residents crammed into a building at the Harney County Fairgrounds here on Wednesday night, far surpassing the capacity of the rows of brown metal folding chairs set up on a concrete floor, to talk in often deeply emotional terms about their community  and just who should be in charge of its destiny.

title: Review: Rachel Platten Experiments With Wildfire
description: Wildfire

title: Texas Trooper Who Arrested Sandra Bland Is Charged With Perjury
description: HEMPSTEAD, Tex.  The state trooper who arrested Sandra Bland, the Chicago-area woman who three days later was found hanged in her cell at the Waller County jail, has been indicted on a perjury charge, a special prosecutor here said Wednesday.

title: N.F.L. Owners Find Fault, Take Action and Steer Clear of Blame
description: In September, after watching the Giants beat Washington to earn their first win in what was to be Tom Coughlins final season, I cautioned disgruntled fans.

title: Shinola Takes Its Detroit Cool Message on the Road
description: DETROIT  When I first saw this neighborhood, I thought: You want to put a store here? You kidding me? said Tom Kartsotis, the Shinola founder, recalling his initial tour of Detroits Cass Corridor, where he opened his companys flagship two and a half years ago, with a couple of colleagues. While there were signs of resurgence, he said, This was a rough part of town.

title: Global Brands, Taking Cue From Tinkerers, Explore Crowdfunding
description: The Opal Nugget Ice Maker machine had all the usual hallmarks of a crowdfunded hit, aside from one tiny bit of fine print.

title: Review: Jane Lynch as the Angel From Hell (With a Drink in Hand)
description: Jane Lynchs lanky frame and wolfish grin are so ubiquitous on screen that its easy to forget that she hasnt had her own television show. That deficit is corrected on Thursday night when CBS presents Angel From Hell, a sitcom in which she plays Amy, a guardian angel whos essentially a well-meaning, pathologically needy stalker with a drinking problem and a tendency to overshare.

title: Allegiance Announces Broadway Closing Date
description: Allegiance, the new Broadway musical about the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II, will close Feb. 14, after 37 previews and 113 regular performances.

title: State Challenges Plan to Revive City Opera
description: Is the plan to revive the late, lamented New York City Opera feasible?

title: Review: Protin and Lang, 800 Years Apart, at Trinity Church
description: Times Arrow is the theme of this seasons ambitious Twelfth Night Festival, during which Trinity Wall Street presents an array of old and contemporary music. It was a particularly fitting title for Tuesdays concert at Trinity Church: The program paired vocal music written by Protin, a master of the Notre Dame school of medieval composers in Paris, with works by David Lang, the Pulitzer Prize-winning master of Downtown New York Post-Minimalism.

title: NBCs Seeso Looks to Be Must-See TV
description: Must-see TV was once the slogan NBC used to promote its prime-time series, the idea being that viewers simply had to watch its shows if they wanted to be part of the television conversation. Today that phrase might be a good measuring stick for the assortment of streaming services asking for our attention and money: Is anything on them must-see TV?

title: Recalling Pierre Boulez, a Conductor-Composer With an Ear to the Alternative
description: In June 1969, the stunning news broke that the New York Philharmonic had appointed Pierre Boulez to succeed Leonard Bernstein as its music director. The decision understandably rattled the classical music establishment: Mr. Boulez was not just an uncompromising Modernist composer, but he had also first come to attention as a polemicist dismissive of those writing music beholden to tonal harmony.

title: The Face of North Korean Television
description: Ri Chun-hee, a host for North Korean state television for over 40 years, returned after a four-year absence to announce, despite international doubts, the countrys test of a hydrogen bomb.

title: Governor Declares Emergency Over Los Angeles Gas Leak
description: LOS ANGELES  Natural gas has been spewing into the air in the Porter Ranch neighborhood here since late October, sickening residents, prompting thousands to evacuate their homes and pouring greenhouse gas into the atmosphere.

title: You Asked, John Kasich Answered
description: On Monday, we asked you to submit questions for John Kasich. During his visit to the editorial board, he picked one of your questions from a hat to answer on camera. Watch his response below:

title: Review: Intensio Suggests a Self-Portrait, With Help From Friends
description: The boy in the home movie, practicing at a ballet barre, has serious eyes flecked with fear. When the adult he became  the American Ballet Theater principal dancer Daniil Simkin  tells us that what he really wanted to be was a dentist, its both funny and sad. Mr. Simkin is the son of Russian ballet dancers; his mother home-schooled him in their art. The dream of dentistry never had a chance.

title: Coca-Cola Retreats From Social Media War Over Crimea
description: Coca-Cola withdrew a cartoon map of Russia from the web on Wednesday, after managing to anger both Russians and Ukrainians by first excluding and then including Crimea in Russias territory.

title: Review: Growing Up Hip Hop Shares the Perks and Perils of Progeny
description: In the premiere episode of Growing Up Hip Hop, a new reality series about the scions of several prominent hip-hop figures, Angela Simmons  a daughter of Rev Run of Run-DMC  is fretting about a coming fashion show shes orchestrating. Then she gets interrupted.

title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Chipotle, Marco Rubio, Donald Trump
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: House Votes to Send Bill to Repeal Health Law to Obamas Desk
description: WASHINGTON  As its opening move in the newly convened Congress, the House voted Wednesday to repeal the Affordable Care Act, the 62nd such vote but the first time that a bill will make it to President Obamas desk, forcing a rare veto to protect his signature domestic achievement.

title: Ken Griffey Jr. and Mike Piazza Trot Into Baseball Hall of Fame
description: Ken Griffey Jr. and Mike Piazza, two of the most prolific sluggers of the high-scoring 1990s, were elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame on Wednesday. Griffey, who slammed 630 home runs, was elected on the first ballot with a record 99.3 percent of votes cast by members of the Baseball Writers Association of America. Piazza, whose 396 homers as a catcher are the most for anyone at the position, got in on his fourth try, with 83 percent.

title: Fear Factor Rising for Federal Workers as Refuge Occupation Goes Unchallenged
description: Jeff Ruch, who directs Public Employees for Environmental Responsibility, sent a fresh note about an under-appreciated risk thats building as long as federal authorities dont directly challenge the anti-government zealots whove taken over Oregons Malheur National Wildlife Refuge. The lack of response, while wise in many ways (as I wrote yesterday), could send a signal to other extremists that they can challenge the government with impunity. This puts federal employees at risk, particularly those in agencies that are a popular target in the West, particularly the Bureau of Land Management.

title: Ted Cruzs Iowa Bus Tour: Loaded Pizza, and Loaded Guns
description: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These arethe places, faces and culinary selectionsof 2016s first proper bus tour.

title: Complaint on Yik Yak
description: A complaint to the Department of Education against the University of Mary Washington over a Yik Yak-related episode contains graphic language.

title: Putting the Heat on Yik Yak After a Killing on Campus
description: Despite pressure to reform what has been variously described as its misogynist, racist and bullying nature  Yik Yak, the anonymous, localized free messaging app, remains the rage on college campuses across the country.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: TransCanada Seeks $15 Billion From U.S. Over Keystone XL Pipeline
description: OTTAWA  TransCanada said on Wednesday that it would seek $15 billion in damages over the Obama administrations decision to cancel the companys Keystone XL pipeline project.

title: The Pill Not Tied to Birth Defects
description: Some small studies have suggested that oral contraceptive use may be associated with an increased risk of birth defects, possibly by altering vitamin levels in the blood. But a large new study has found that taking oral contraceptives around the time of pregnancy did not increase the risk.

title: Mexican Soda Tax Followed by Drop in Sugary Drink Sales
description: A tax on sugary drinks implemented in 2014 in Mexico appears to have had a significant impact: After one year, sales of sugary beverages in the country fell as much as 12 percent while bottled water purchases rose 4 percent, a new study found.

title: Video Feature: Apps Give Journal Writers Inspiration, and Maybe a Nudge
description: KEEPING a journal is something many of us try to take up at the start of a new year, but it can be a hard habit to stick with. To make it a bit easier, you can keep a digital journal or diary with you wherever you go, and many are set up to encourage people to keep typing away day after day.

title: App Smart | Digital Diaries
description: A look at apps that help you document your daily life, through words, pictures and social media.

title: I.M.F. Breakthrough Is Seen to Bolster U.S. on World Stage
description: WASHINGTON  A string of agreements between the White House and Congress, capped by last months surprise accord that ended a five-year impasse over the International Monetary Fund, has eased, though not dispelled, concern that America is retreating from global economic leadership.

title: United Airlines Chief, Oscar Munoz, Has Heart Transplant
description: United Airlines said on Wednesday that its president and chief executive, Oscar Munoz, had heart transplant surgery earlier in the day and was in recovery.

title: U.S. Sends TwoGuantnamo Detainees to Ghana
description: WASHINGTON  The United States on Wednesday transferred to Ghana two Yemeni men who had been imprisoned at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, for nearly 14 years, the Pentagon said. The transfer marked the start of what is expected to be a flurry of 17 departures in early 2016.

title: Cuomo Lays Out Renovation Plan for Penn Station and Farley Post Office
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo continued laying out his vision for a modernized, statewide transportation network on Wednesday afternoon with one more ambitious project: the renovation of Pennsylvania Station, one of the busiest transit halls in the Western Hemisphere, and the creation of an adjunct train and retail hub within the walls of the blocklong general post office across Eighth Avenue.

title: Morgan Stanleys New No. 2
description: Colm Kelleher, named Wednesday as president of Morgan Stanley and the heir apparent to its current chief executive, James P. Gorman, has spent much of his career at the firm moving up the ranks through its trading and capital markets operations.

title: After Mass Shootings, Some on Wall St. See Gold in Gun Makers
description: In the days after the Paris terrorist attacks last November, world leaders denounced the shooting massacres. On Wall Street, the money manager Louis Navellier saw a buying opportunity.

title: Macys to Cut 4,500 Jobs, After Holiday Sales Slump
description: Macys said on Wednesday that it would eliminate about 4,500 jobs, or about 3 percent of its work force, in a major restructuring drive. It said slumping holiday season sales had hurt its bottom line.

title: Todd Bowles Makes Changes to Jets Coaching Staff
description: Todd Bowles expressed his dissatisfaction with the Jets poor special teams this season by firing the units two coaches. Gone are Bobby April, who spent one season in charge, and his assistant, Steve Hagen, who had previously worked with the teams tight ends.

title: Bill Cosby Inquiries in California to Be Dropped
description: The Los Angeles County District Attorneys Office announced Wednesday that it would not pursue sexual assault charges against Bill Cosby, saying investigators had decided that any criminal charges based on the complaints of two women there were blocked by the statute of limitations or lacked sufficient evidence.

title: A Publisher Puzzles Staff With His Role in Las Vegas
description: When a relatively obscure newspaper publisher showed up in photographs last month addressing the staff of The Las Vegas Review-Journal, his appearance baffled journalists  in Connecticut.

title: Under Gun Rules, F.B.I. Will Receive Health Data
description: WASHINGTON  Responding to Republicans who have repeatedly tied gun violence to mental health issues, President Obamas new gun control plan will allow state agencies and the Social Security Administration to provide certain protected health information to the F.B.I. to help crack down on weapons sales to people who pose a danger to themselves or others or are unable to manage their own affairs.

title: Guns, Anger and Nonsense in Oregon
description: It is a familiar claim by many Second Amendment defenders  and, during the Obama administration, an increasingly popular one  that unfettered gun rights are necessary to protect American citizens against the threat of a tyrannical government.

title: Venezuela: New Lawmakers Defy Supreme Court
description: Lawmakers on Wednesday swore in three legislators who were blocked from taking their seats by the Supreme Court last month, setting up a showdown with the presidents Socialist party. The opposition won a supermajority in the National Assembly on Dec. 6, ending the United Socialist Partys 16-year-long grip on power. But before the new legislature could take charge, the Socialists approved 13 new Supreme Court justices, and days later, the court blocked four opposition lawmakers from taking their seats. That decision has created uncertainty about the supermajority, which the presidents rivals need to gain added powers, including the ability to remove Supreme Court justices and change the Constitution. On Wednesday, three of the four politicians were sworn in over objections of the Socialists. Whats happening today is a flagrant violation of the Venezuelan Constitution, said Diosdado Cabello, a Socialist lawmaker and the former leader of the Assembly. He said that the Socialists would ask the Supreme Court to find the Assembly leadership in contempt of the court order that blocked the politicians from taking their seats.

title: With Giants Job Open, Sean Payton Reaffirms Vow to Saints
description: New Orleans Coach Sean Payton, who as a former Giants assistant seemed a potential candidate to replace Tom Coughlin as Giants coach, reaffirmed his desire to stay with the Saints on Wednesday.

title: Sampling the Work of Pierre Boulez
description: The critics of The New York Times offer a selective, subjective guide to the career of Pierre Boulez, who died on Tuesday at 90, suggesting just a few samples of his work as both a composer and conductor.

title: Baltimore Officer Must Testify in Colleagues Trials in Freddie Gray Case
description: BALTIMORE  Officer William G. Porter, whose trial in the death of Freddie Gray ended last month in a deadlocked jury, must testify in the trials of two fellow officers, a judge here ruled Wednesday, in a novel twist to an increasingly complicated prosecution.

title: Pentagon Will Extend Military Honors to Drone Operators Far From Battles
description: WASHINGTON  For years, the militarys drone pilots have toiled in obscurity from windowless rooms at bases in suburban America, viewed by some in the armed forces more as video game players than as warriors.

title: Founders Fund Leads a Financing Round for Nubank, a Brazilian Start-Up
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The billionaire and prominent Silicon Valley financier Peter Thiel has returned to investing in Brazil, even as the country remains mired in recession and faces almost weekly political upheavals.

title: Carmakers Forge Ahead With Electric Vehicles
description: LAS VEGAS  Although sales of electric and hybrid vehicles have struggled, automakers are charging ahead to bring new battery-powered vehicles to market.

title: Florida Professor Who Cast Doubt on Mass Shootings Is Fired
