description: Almost from the day that the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center opened in 1986, exhibitors and hotel operators complained that the black glass complex along 11th Avenue in Manhattan was too small, too hard to navigate and perpetually damp from a leaky roof.

title: St. Georges School Agrees to Inquiry Into Sexual Abuse
description: BOSTON  St. Georges School, an elite Rhode Island prep school embroiled in a widening sexual abuse scandal spanning decades, said Thursday that it would commission a new, independent investigation into allegations of misconduct against former staff and former students.

title: Obamas Gun Initiative Seen as Having Limited Effect on Unlicensed Dealers
description: Jack Strahan has been a small-time trader of guns and gun parts for years, and he is not stopping now.

title: No Short-Term Fix for California Methane Leak
description: To the dismay of thousands of residents of Porter Ranch, Calif., whose lives have been upended by a huge natural-gas leak from a nearby well, the local utility says it will take at least another month and a half to shut it down.

title: Blunt Political Assessments in Bill Clinton Transcripts
description: WASHINGTON  He thought George W. Bush was perpetrating a fraud on America as a presidential candidate, Vladimir V. Putin had enormous potential, and the people of Wyoming would be shooting at me if he visited.

title: Samsungs Operating Profit Rises 15%, a Sharp Slowdown
description: HONG KONG  Last year, with smartphone sales sagging, Samsung Electronics said it would orchestrate a turnaround using the components that power electronics  things like chips, screens and circuits.

title: Sandy Alderson, Recovering From Cancer, Defends Mets Moves
description: Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson, who has been undergoing cancer treatments, joined a contingent of club executives at the New York Athletic Club on Thursday for Mike Piazzas Hall of Fame news conference.

title: Obama Administration Optimistic About Health Plan Goal
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Thursday that 11.3 million people had signed up for health insurance so far during the Affordable Care Acts third open enrollment period, with indications of a strong desire for coverage among young adults and others who were not enrolled last year.

title: Pat Harrington, the Super on One Day at a Time, Dies at 86
description: Pat Harrington Jr., an Emmy-winning character actor best known as Schneider, the building superintendent and would-be Lothario on the popular sitcom One Day at a Time, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 86.

title: Response on Hillary Clinton Email Incomplete, Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department provided an inaccurate or incomplete response when a watchdog group asked in 2012 whether Hillary Clinton had used any alternate email accounts, saying it had no relevant records, even though dozens of top officials knew that she relied on a private email address for official communications, an independent investigator reported Thursday.

title: Guatemalan Judge in FIFA Corruption Case Is Released on $4 Million Bond
description: Hctor Trujillo, a Guatemalan judge and soccer official charged by the United States in December with accepting andlaundering hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes,was held in solitary confinement at a detention center in Brooklyn for the past week until he was released Thursday on a $4 million bond.

title: Donald Trump Supporters Turned Away From His Rally
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.  It was about half an hour into Donald Trumps speech that the police here made it official: No one else in line, which still snaked around the block, was getting in.

title: Removal of Chvez Images From Venezuela Capitol Raises Tension
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  With triple-digit inflation showing no signs of retreating and the new National Assembly vowing to remove the president, Venezuela over the last few days careered toward crises both economic and political.

title: Index-Card Financial Advice
description: A selection of trimmed-down financial advice from financial experts and personal-finance writers at The New York Times.

title: An Idea by Moynihan Rises Like a Phoenix: Relocating Pennsylvania Station
description: A ride on the Times Square shuttle nearly 30 years ago.

title: Campbell Labels Will Disclose G.M.O. Ingredients
description: Breaking from its industry rivals, Campbell Soup will become the first major food company to begin disclosing the presence of genetically engineered ingredients like corn, soy and sugar beets in its products.

title: Her College Dreams Delayed, She Slept at Airports
description: With no bed of her own to sleep in, Karen Carter took a friends advice to seek shelter at the airport. Every night for nearly three weeks, she went to a different terminal so that she would not be recognized for regularly returning.

title: Transcripts of Phone Calls Between Bill Clinton and Tony Blair
description: President Bill Clintons library released transcripts of phone conversations with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, offering a revealing look at Mr. Clinton. Here is selection of documents pulled from the full 532 page release.

title: With Two Homers, Emotions Go Deep for Ken Griffey Jr. and Mike Piazza
description: Ken Griffey Sr., proud veteran of the Big Red Machine, likes to say that his son got the records, but he got the rings. Fair point: Ken Griffey Jr. was elected to the Hall of Fame this week but never did play in the World Series. Mike Piazza, who will share the stage in Cooperstown this summer, made it there once and lost.

title: West Bank: Israelis Kill 4 Attackers
description: Israeli forces fatally shot four Palestinians in the West Bank on Thursday as the assailants tried to stab soldiers, the military said. Three Palestinian cousins from the village of Sair, near Hebron, were spotted approaching the heavily guarded Gush Etzion junction, Palestinian news reports said. The military said that all three were shot after they tried to stab soldiers who approached them. A short time later, a 16-year-old Palestinian from the same village was killed at the Beit Einoun junction near Hebron, the Palestinian news agency Wafa reported.

title: Short Passes Fly, More Picks Are Set, and Penalties Follow
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The crowd roar at Gillette Stadium soared last month with each tackle Patriots running back James White broke  sprinting past a linebacker, spinning away from a safety, stiff-arming a cornerback  before weakening in disappointment when he was brought down inside the 10-yard line.

title: Aramco Share Sales Would Help Transparency, Saudi Official Says
description: Saudi Arabia is reviewing whether to sell public shares in its state-owned oil company, Aramco, with a decision coming in the next few months, the countrys defense minister and deputy crown prince told The Economist in an interview published Thursday.

title: F.B.I. and Police Task Force Arrests 3 for Armored-Car Robberies
description: Three men, including a state prison guard, were arrested on Thursday for participating in three brazen daytime robberies of armored cars in the Bronx over the past several months, the authorities said.

title: Mike Richards Happy to Be Back After Signing With Capitals
description: A contrite Mike Richards met the news media on Thursday for the first time since signing a one-year contract with the Washington Capitals.

title: Central African Republic: Runoff Is Set for Presidential Candidates
description: The top two presidential candidates are likely to meet in a runoff election later this month, officials announced Thursday. Both candidates are former prime ministers. Anicet-Georges Dologul, an economist, received about 24 percent of the votes, according to provisional results. He will face Faustin-Archange Touadra, a former mathematics professor, who received 19 percent. The two men emerged from a field of 30 in an election that, while peaceful, involved logistical problems and prompted allegations of fraud. Candidates can appeal to the Constitutional Court, which has 15 days to review any appeals and validate the final results. The runoff is scheduled for Jan. 31. Sectarian violence between Christians and Muslims in the past several years has caused nearly a million people to flee their homes.

title: 2016 Alternate-Side Parking Rules
description: The days on which alternate-side street-cleaning rules will be suspended in New York City in 2016.

title: Make Ones Head Spin
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Ah, Friday, the day we cast off structured exercises like themed crosswords. Or do we? Todays puzzle by Peter A. Collins begins and ends with Broadway shows  DREAMGIRLS and JERSEY BOYS  that sound like the beginnings of a spiffy theme.

title: Chinese Markets Rise After Volatile Opening
description: HONG KONG  With Beijings grip slightly looser, Chinese markets steadied on Friday.

title: Muslims in Queens Welcome Shift in Scrutiny to Police
description: Ahmad Alsalkhadi, an immigrant from Jordan, has never had a run-in with the police, but he works in a section of Astoria, Queens, that has come under police surveillance in the years after the Sept. 11 attacks because of the concentration of Muslim-owned businesses.

title: Overflow Crowd for Donald Trump in Bernie Sanderss Backyard
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.  Donald J. Trump touched down in one of Americas most progressive cities Thursday night, bringing the bombastic message that has captivated Republican voters into the backyard of a Democratic opponent, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont.

title: Confident Capitals Blitz the Islanders in a Rematch
description: As Alex Ovechkins wrist shot slithered past Jaroslav Halak to give the Washington Capitals a 2-0 lead late in the first period, Halak, the Islanders goaltender, shook his head in frustration as he hunched in front of his net.

title: Iraqi Refugees in Texas and California Accused of Terrorism Ties
description: HOUSTON  Two refugees from Iraq were arrested on terrorism-related charges on Thursday in California and Texas, where the governor called for an end to the resettlement of refugees from countries overrun by terrorist groups.

title: Ted Cruzs Iowa Bus Tour: A Misfired One-Liner
description: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These arethe places, faces and culinary selectionsof 2016s first proper bus tour.

title: Spare Times for Children Listings for Jan. 8-14
description: Baseball season may be only a distant memory, but on Sunday young fans can still see players suit up in Yankee uniforms for a game. A few lucky children will even join the team.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | partial
description: partial  \pr-shl\  adjective and noun

title: Spare Times for Jan. 8-14
description: One Step Beyond (Friday) The American Museum of Natural Historys two biggest after-hours programs for the 21-and-over crowd are, in a way, antithetical. First are the occasional adult sleepovers, in which people pay hundreds of dollars to live out childhood fantasies of roaming empty museum halls and curling up in sleeping bags under the famous life-size blue whale. Then there is the much less expensive ($25 in advance) One Step Beyond, where partying trumps nostalgia, and the Rose Center for Earth and Space becomes a dance club that brings in big names in techno, electronica and hip-hop. (Above, a previous party inside the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Hall of the Universe.)

title: Ashraf Pahlavi, Twin Sister of Irans Last Shah, Dies at 96
description: Ashraf Pahlavi, the twin sister of the last shah of Iran, known equally for her work with the United Nations on behalf of womens causes and her opulent lifestyle, died on Thursday at her home. She was 96.

title: New Yorks Week in Pictures: Jan. 1
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City include a plunge in the Atlantic Ocean and a golf outing in which the players wear fur coats.

title: What to Watch Friday
description: Downton Abbey fans bemoaning the absence of Lady Rose this season can get their fix when the actress who played her, Lily James, steps out of the ashes and into the glass slipper in Cinderella. A White House concert commemorates the act behind the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities. And the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami drives around Tehran in Ten.

title: Corrections: January 8, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Homes? There are no homes.

title: The Self-Reliant Generation
description: Last month Fox News released a poll showing Hillary Clinton leading Bernie Sanders in Iowa by 14 points. But the amazing part of the poll was the generation gap. Among likely caucusgoers under 45, Sanders was crushing Clinton 56 to 34 percent. Among the older voters, Clinton was leading 59 to 24.

title: Donald Trump Drags Bill Clintons Baggage Out
description: Donald Trump seems to view his role as the person who dredges up what nobody else wants to talk about. And so he has dragged out Bill Clintons marital infidelity.

title: When China Stumbles
description: So, will Chinas problems cause a global crisis? The good news is that the numbers, as I read them, dont seem big enough. The bad news is that I could be wrong, because global contagion often seems to end up being worse than hard numbers say it should. And the worse news is that if China does deliver a bad shock to the rest of the world, we are remarkably unready to deal with the consequences.

title: Crackpots in Cowboy Hats, and in Congress
description: Most of the ranchers I know are decent folks, men and women of a few well-chosen words, slow to rouse, distrustful of a show horse on four legs or two. And then theres the armed gang who seized an Oregon bird sanctuary  Yall Qaeda, as the twittersphere has dubbed them.

title: Stopping North Koreas Nuclear Threat
description: DURING nuclear negotiations in 2005, a North Korean diplomat let slip an unexpectedly candid comment, offering valuable insight into his governments nuclear policy: The reason you attacked Afghanistan is because they dont have nukes. And look at what happened to Libya. That is why we will never give up ours.

title: What Donald Trump Owes George Wallace
description: Donald J. Trump, reality television star and real estate mogul, is different in many ways from major political figures in our past. But there are striking similarities between Mr. Trump and George C. Wallace, the Deep South politician who ran for president each opportunity he got from 1964 through 1976. The connections between the two  their rhetoric and their ability to fire up crowds  give us a better sense of what Trumpism will mean once he is gone from the campaign stage. After all, political losers as well as winners can shape the future.

title: A Shameful Round-Up of Refugees
description: President Obama once said this about his administrations deportation priorities: Well keep focusing enforcement resources on actual threats to our security. That means felons, not families. That means criminals, not children. It means gang members, not moms who are trying to put food on the table for their kids.

title: The Depths of Injustice in Chicago
description: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago built his career on the claim that he is at his best in times of crisis. But it will take more than political showmanship to calm the discontent that has roiled the city since November, when a Police Department video showed a white officer executing a black teenager named Laquan McDonald and exposed a cover-up by officers who had been at the scene. Chicagoans were still protesting the McDonald case on Christmas weekend when police officers responding to a domestic dispute killed two more African-Americans, one of whom was a bystander and a mother of five.

title: Bath Looks to Shift Its Momentum at European Rugby Champions Cup
description: LONDON  A trip to the South of France has long been reckoned a perfect antidote to the gloom of the British midwinter, but the rugby players of Bath are unlikely to get much rest or tranquility from their visit this weekend.

title: News Qs | North Korea Blast Revives Question: How Do You Contain Pyongyang?
description: The following lesson activities are based on the News Analysis North Korea Blast Revives Question: How Do You Contain Pyongyang?

title: Robust Hiring in December Caps Solid Year for U.S. Jobs
description: The last time the American economy registered such a prolonged stretch of impressive job creation, Facebook didnt exist and Beyonc was still a member of Destinys Child.

title: Brooklyn Houses Clad in Metal
description: The day a tire popped off a car, flew off the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and hit his house with a loud bang, Vardon Owen Marshall was in disbelief.

title: A Rush of Central AmericansComplicates Obamas Immigration Task
description: DILLEY, Tex.  When mothers and children streamed across the Texas border in 2014, the Obama administration devised a strategy to manage the influx, putting them in detention centers to convince others that illegal crossers would be caught and sent back.

title: Kitson, Where Kim Kardashian and Britney Spears Shopped, Sees the End
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  On the day after Christmas, a familiar mother-daughter spat was playing out at a Kitson boutique on South Robertson Boulevard.

title: One Man, Five Designers
description: Duckie Brown made me do it.

title: Braving the Elements Atop the New Tappan Zee Bridge
description: Igino DIppolito is no Philippe Petit, the high-wire artist who famously scampered between the twin towers of the original World Trade Center in 1974.

title: Marvin Newman Beyond the Single Image
description: Over the years, Marvin Newman has repeatedly fixated on everything from old womens calves and men sprawled out on park benches, to sewer covers and mannequin heads sporting hats.

title: When Opposites Attract
description: Hannah Eddy asked her boss if her new job came with a boyfriend. In fact, she ended up marrying this colleague, Rodney Andrews.

title: She Went to a College for a Job, and Found a Husband, Too
description: If there is a punctuation mark that reflects Hannah Eddys personality, it is the exclamation point. She is tall, thin, vivacious and perpetually positive.

title: Currency Devaluations by Asian Tigers Could Hinder Global Growth
description: Chinas decision to push the value of its currency lower has opened a new front of worry for global investors: a potential wave of currency devaluations among the so-called Asian tigers  South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan.

title: What New Tech Ideas Does the World Need?
description: The International CES, the annual consumer electronics show, is going on in Las Vegas, and, as the Times technology columnist writes, lots of potentially groundbreaking ideas are just around the corner  even if theyre not quite there yet.

title: Tour and Hotel News: Hamiltons Homes, Culture in Palm Beach
description: HAMILTON, THE TOUR

title: Having Friends Is Good for You, Starting in Your Teens
description: Having friends is good for your physical health, and the benefits appear to start early in life, according to a new study.

description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: All the Toil, None of the Credit
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Bernie Sanders Makes Swing Through Iowa to Remind Supporters to Vote
description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont begins a four-day swing through Iowa on Friday, hosting multiple events intended in part to motivate people to attend the caucuses in the first state in the nominating process to vote.

title: My Virtual Life at Techs Big Consumer Electronics Show
description: LAS VEGAS  Over the last few days, Ive repaired a robot, driven a Rover across Mars and zapped objects with a laser gun.

title: Ask Well: Health Benefits of Red Wine vs. Grape Juice
description: Question:

title: New York Today: In Case of Cabin Fever
description: Updated at 10:30 a.m.

description: Heres what you need to know to start your day.

title: Morning Agenda: Capping Week of Turmoil, Chinese Markets Rise
description: CAPPING WEEK OF TURMOIL, CHINESE MARKETS RISE | After plunging and bringing trading to a halt for the day after a mere 29 minutes, Chinese markets rose on Friday, Amie Tsang reports in DealBook.

title: G.O.P. Senator Summons Loretta Lynch to Testify on Legalities of New Gun Measures
description: Congressional Republicans seem to be very unhappy with President Obamas new executive actions on guns, though they are probably quite happy that the actions provided them such a juicy issue with which to stir up voters in an election year.

title: Fingerprint of Fugitive in Paris Attacks Is Found in Brussels Apartment
description: PARIS  Belgian investigators searching a Brussels apartment have found the fingerprint of a fugitive wanted in connection with the Nov. 13 terrorist attacks in Paris, as well as material that might have been used to assemble suicide belts and traces of an explosive used in the assaults, officials announced on Friday.

title: The 12.27.15 Issue
description: RE: THE LIVES THEY LIVED

title: Sex and the Saudi
description: One winter day a few years ago, I met a girl I really liked. I saw her at a park in Qatif. We were looking at each other, so I went up to her and said, Hi, you look beautiful. She thanked me, and I handed her a piece of paper with my number on it. We should talk more, I told her. Im interested in you. Then I left immediately.

title: How to Hold a Heart
description: There is an adage that says a good surgeon needs a lions heart, an eagles eyes and a ladys hands. Kathy Magliato, the director of womens cardiac services at Providence Saint Johns Health Center in Santa Monica, Calif., can palm a basketball  but, she says, anyone can hold a heart: Dont worry about the size of your hands. Instead, concentrate on not dropping it; a heart covered with blood is very slippery.

title: Gulf
description: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.

title: Ian McKellen Will Take That Seat, if Youre Offering It
description: Ian McKellen, the venerated film and stage actor who received an Oscar nomination for playing a wizard (in The Lord of the Rings) a decade after being knighted by the queen, returned to the awards conversation this year, though perhaps too quietly. In Mr. Holmes, Mr. McKellen plays the famed sleuth Sherlock Holmes, his depiction toggling between a fit middle-ager and a doddering 93-year-old.

title: Obama and Trump Events Highlight a Central Divide on Guns
description: As President Obama held a town-hall-style event in Virginia on Thursday evening to discuss his executive actions on gun control, one of his loudest critics, Donald J. Trump, promised a crowd of more than 1,400 people in Burlington, Vt., that he would eliminate gun-free zones in schools on his first day in office.

title: A Germans Video Likens Mao to Hitler, and China Wants Him Punished
description: BEIJING  When Christoph Rehage, a German writer and online satirist on Chinese affairs, joked on Weibo in July that the Communist hero Lei Feng and the female warrior Mulan could have a great baby together, reaction from some quarters was swift.

title: Teenagers in The Times | December 2015
description: Our latest round-up of articles about young people that have appeared in The Times includes several high-profile stories, including the disappearance of Ethan Couch, 18, who used an affluenza defense in a fatal drunken-driving case and was found in December in Mexico with his mother.

title: China, in Rebuke, Suggests U.S. Worsened Ties With North Korea
description: BEIJING  China has rejected criticism from the United States that its policies toward North Korea had failed, suggesting on Friday that it was the Americans, not the Chinese, who were largely to blame for the Norths embrace of nuclear weapons.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: What to Eat, Manta Rays and Resolutions
description: Take the Quiz

title: Turkey, Which Sought Middle Ground, Enters Saudi-Iranian Dispute
description: ISTANBUL  As the Middle East has descended into bitter sectarian conflict in recent years, Turkey has tried to remain above the fray, posing as an honest broker and peacemaker. Increasingly, though, it is being drawn into the conflict, and its preferred status as disinterested mediator is slowly becoming untenable.

title: A Self-Appointed Herald of Hip-Hop in China
description: Almost from the moment he moved from California to Shaoxing in Chinas Zhejiang Province in October 2014, Tsalta Baptiste enjoyed a sense of notoriety. That happens when youre an African-American man suddenly living in a nation with a population of more than 1.3 billion. Mr. Baptistes passing resemblance to Kobe Bryant also helped in a country that reveres the Los Angeles Lakers star.

title: Steve Israel: Confessions of a Congressman
description: Washington  ITS now safe to pick up your phones and read your emails. Thats right, I wont be calling to ask you to donate to my congressional campaign. As I announced on Tuesday, Ill be leaving Congress at the end of this term  sentimental about many things, but liberated from a fund-raising regime thats never been more dangerous to our democracy.

title: Golden Mao Statue in China, Nearly Finished, Is Brought Down by Criticism
description: ZHUSHIGANG, China  Just two days after images of a giant gold-colored statue of Mao in the bare fields of Henan Province spread across the Internet, the statue was gone  torn down apparently on the orders of embarrassed local officials.

title: Its Payback Time for Women
description: A COUNTRY that gives every citizen enough cash to live on whether she needs it or not: Its got to be either a fools paradise or a profligate Northern European nation. And lo, in November, the Finnish government proposed paying every adult 800 euros or about $870 a month. Fits of this seemingly irrational generosity, called a universal basic income or U.B.I., are becoming surprisingly common. The Swiss will vote in a referendum on basic income this year. The Dutch city of Utrecht will soon  start a basic-income pilot program. Canadas ruling Liberal Party recently adopted a resolution calling for a similar experiment.

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Suresnes, France

title: Crimea to Face Power Shortages for Months, Officials Say
description: MOSCOW  Crimea will experience power shortages until at least May, the Kremlin-appointed government of the region announced after a meeting in Simferopol, the capital, on Thursday.

title: Where History Buffs Should Go in 2016
description: In 2016, Britain takes the cake celebrating the births of several famous writers, and the death of one illustrious playwright; in the American West, an icon of contemporary bohemia approaches middle age; victory and defeat are commemorated on French battlefields; and the struggle for independence is cause for celebration in Central America.

title: Where Foodies Should Go in 2016
description: The renowned chef Ren Redzepi of the two-Michelin-starred Noma in Copenhagen wasnt exaggerating when he said, People will travel anywhere for good food  its crazy. Indeed, food lovers are now trooping around the world to both accessible and remote destinations. Perhaps Mr. Redzepi should have added that overindulging is almost certainly the case with  and maybe the point of  any culinary-inspired trip.

title: Where Music Lovers Should Go in 2016
description: What does the rhythm of life sound like in 2016? Drums are keeping traditions alive in Basque Country and Burkina Faso; California is calling on the voices of strong women to inspire new music; and in Montreal, jazz lovers are preparing for what is sure to be the classiest Battle of the Bands in history.

title: Where Sports Fans Should Go in 2016
description: Whether your game is golf, soccer, snow biking or Ping-Pong, 2016 is shaping up to be a flag-waving year among fans.

title: How Should You Manage Your Money? And Keep It Short
description: Editors note: Heres one of our favorite stories from the archives, now being featured in our Smarter Living collection.

title: Speed Date on the Fifth Avenue Bus
description: Dear Diary:

title: This Weeks Movies | Jan. 8, 2016
description: The New York Times film critics review The Treasure, Anesthesia and Lamb.

title: ISIS Militant Kills Mother on Groups Orders, Activists Say
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  An Islamic State militant killed his own mother in front of a post office in the northern Syrian city of Raqqa this week, Syrian activists said on Friday, with one monitoring organization adding that the episode began when she tried to persuade him to leave the extremist group.

title: Maggie Smith Shifts From Dowager to Down and Out for The Lady in the Van
description: LONDON  Old friends, Maggie Smith and the playwright Alan Bennett sat on a sofa at a chic hotel, lobbing lines at each other as they recalled how they first met. Then she vaulted right over the pig, Mr. Bennett said. Ms. Smith threw herself back on the sofa and laughed uproariously. It was terrifying, she said, wiping her eyes. Mr. Bennett looked at her, straight-faced. For the pig, too, I imagine, he said.

title: 1916: Tsars Troops Push Forward
description: Czernowitz has not yet fallen, but from the continued successful development of the Russian operations in this region and from the further slow though important progress made, it would appear that the event cannot now be long delayed. The tsars troops have forced their way through yet another fortified line, and, according to latest reports, four miles or less separate them from their goal.

title: 18 Asylum Seekers Are Tied to Attacks on Women in Germany
description: BERLIN  The German authorities on Friday tied asylum seekers for the first time to the wave of violent assaults on women in Cologne on New Years Eve as debate intensified over whether the country had made a mistake in opening its doors last year to more than a million migrants.

title: Runaways to Be Revived This Summer
description: The death of Elizabeth Swados on Tuesday prompted much reminiscing in the theater community about the composer/authors breakthrough show, Runaways, which was staged at the Public Theater and then on Broadway in 1978.

title: What I Love | Jane Bryant Quinn
description: The personal finance expert lives on the Upper West Side with her husband, Carll Tucker.

title: Jane Bryant Quinns Upper West Side Home
description: Every marriage has its deal. Here, to give just one handy example, were the terms of the deal struck by the personal finance expert Jane Bryant Quinn and her second husband, David: Ms. Quinn would put up with the suburbs and Mr. Quinn would put up with her.

title: Mein Kampf, Hitlers Manifesto, Returns to German Shelves
description: MUNICH  At a time when nationalist and far-right politics are again ascendant in Europe, a team of German historians presented a new, annotated edition of a symbolic text of that movement on Friday: Mein Kampf, by Adolf Hitler.

title: New Year, Old-Fashioned Investment Strategy
description: THE beginning of the year is the time when many people sit down with their financial advisers or otherwise seek out advice about their finances. And with stock markets rocky start to the year, that impulse may be greater this time around  that is, if people dont run and hide.

title: Mein Kampf: From Best-Seller to Blacklist
description: The manifesto of Adolf Hitler, Mein Kampf was first published in 1925. A second volume followed in 1926. This year, the book will be reprinted and sold in Germany for the first time since World War II. Below, a few excerpts from the European editions of The New York Herald and the New York Herald Tribune, which followed the manifesto from best-seller status to blacklisted label.

title: When Collecting Wasnt All About the Money
description: LONDON  A documentary released last year revealed fresh insights about the life of the 20th centurys most celebrated female art collector.

title: More Context Needed in Article on Haifa Culture
description: The recent article about a burgeoning social scenein Haifa was intended as a slice of life, a window into a place that Times readers dont often see.

title: VW Refuses to Give American States Documents in Emissions Inquiries
description: Citing German privacy laws, Volkswagen has refused to provide emails or other communications among its executives to attorneys general in the United States, impeding American investigations into the companys emissions-cheating scandal, according to officials in several states.

title: Topman Design: Fall 2016
description: The fall 2016 show from Topman Design.

title: Winter Jazzfest Returns With a Marathon
description: Maybe youve heard somewhere that jazz roared back to life in 2015. Its a boldfaced claim rooted in a shaky premise, but if you seek supporting evidence, look no further than Winter Jazzfest. An early-January bonanza that has kept expanding since the mid-2000s, its a place to catch up on important new conversation-starters.

title: Independent Spirit in Many Flavors at the Out of Israel Showcase at 92Y
description: In dance as in politics, Israels visibility and influence are remarkably disproportionate to its size. For years, dance aficionados have celebrated the adventurous physicality coming from that small country, making it one of its most popular and exciting cultural exports. The familiar ambassadors have been big companies like Vertigo, Kibbutz Contemporary Dance and, of course, the Batsheva Dance Company, whose signature gooey movement style, known as Gaga, has swept the dance world.

title: A Fighters Hour of Need
description: On Nov. 2, 2013, Mike Perez defeated Magomed Abdusalamov in a heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden. This is a reconstruction of the hour after the fight, based in part on the transcripts of two dozen interviews given under oath and conducted by the New York State Office of the Inspector General as part of its continuing investigation into the fight and the operations of the State Athletic Commission.

title: Daily Report: Samsung Continues Looking for the Big Bump
description: Samsung has been looking for ways to prod growth for many quarters now. It is still looking.

title: 2015 Was a Great Year for Jobs. 2016 Will Have a Hard Time Matching It.
description: The newest numbers on the state of the American job market are good news on almost every front and show that 2015 was a blockbuster year for jobs. That raises some important questions  and doubts  about what will happen in 2016.

title: Relocating Old iPhoto Events in Photos for OS X
description: Q. When I migrated from iPhoto to Photos for OS X on my Mac, all of my iPhoto Events were converted into albums and buried in a parent folder called iPhoto Events. This makes reaching them very time-consuming. Is there a way to move all these old events into the main Albums tab?

title: Unexpected, but Not Unusual, Expenses Thwart Efforts to Save
description: MORE than 70 percent of Americans say they find it hard to save because of expenses they didnt plan for, according to research published on Thursday by the Pew Charitable Trusts.

title: The Importance of Being Prepared for a Natural Disaster
description: AS hot, wind-fed wildfires swirled around her town in early September, Darlene Simmons, 76, was busy cooking spaghetti in her kitchen. As a resident of Middletown, a small town in Northern California, she had been through wildfires before. But her home, where she had lived for 45 years, had never been harmed.

title: 1941: Anti-Aircraft Drills Scare Ducks
description: CAMP UPTON, L.I.  Ducks, for the second time in less than a month, have been the cause of changes in anti-aircraft training here. The first time it was wild ducks, which interfered with firing of anti-aircraft batteries. Now, because of the nerves of market ducks on the south shore duck farms, anti-aircraft searchlights of the 198th Coast Artillery Regiment will be directed only north and west of the camp.

title: Government Declassifies Passages in Three Surveillance Reports
description: In response to an ongoing Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by the New York Times, the federal government has declassified and revealed additional passages of three inspector general reports related to surveillance. The government previously released versions of these reports, but decided to reprocess them and remove further redaction markings. The newly visible portions are marked.

title: British Man Admits Past in Terror Cell in Yemen
description: A man who prosecutors say received military training in Yemen from Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born radical Muslim cleric who was later killed by the United States in a drone strike, pleaded guilty on Friday in Manhattan to three terrorism-related counts.

title: Rahm and His Party
description: The fall of Rahm Emanuel, seemingly a politicaldead man walking because ofhis alleged role in covering up the video showing Chicago cops shooting a black teenager, has united right and left in schadenfreude. The right is delighted because Emanuel is a prominent overclass Democrat, an enforcer forthe last two Democratic presidents, the man who led the midterm thumping that undid George W. Bushs congressional majorities in 2006, and the mayor of a city thats a case study in one-party misgovernment. The left, meanwhile, is happy to see him fall because Emanuel is a prominent centrist Democrat, whose role in both the Clinton and Obama White Houses involved prodding his bosses to temper their liberalism and tack somewhat to the right.

title: Stuff We Liked: Following the Flows of Migration
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Ratings Agencies Still Coming Up Short, Years After Crisis
description: The mistakes that led to the 2008 mortgage crisis cant happen again, right?

title: Bengals Andy Dalton, Sitting Out on Saturday, Could Still Return
description: The Cincinnati Bengals have had a season to remember, winning their first eight games and finishing 12-4, their best record since 1988. But in a wild-card playoff game on Saturday night, they will be underdogs at home to the Pittsburgh Steelers, whom they beat for the A.F.C. North crown. The reason is the absence of their starting quarterback, Andy Dalton, one of the leagues top passers this season.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Murray Hill, Battery Park City and Boerum Hill, Brooklyn.

title: Fitbitten (Personal and Trivial)
description: This strikes me as going overboard: Users Are Suing Fitbit Over Inaccurate Heart Monitors. Maybe theres a legal case, but people should know better. The laser system supposedly works OK for moderate exercise, but it stands to reason that it would have trouble dealing with the sweat and jiggling of hard cardio.

title: When Teamwork Doesnt Work for Women
description: Economics remains a stubbornly male-dominated profession, a fact that members of the profession have struggled to understand.

title: Gov. Paul LePage of Maine Says Racial Comment Was a Slip-Up
description: A combative Gov. Paul R. LePage of Maine, who has a history of making blunt, sometimes racially tinged remarks, found himself in a familiar position on Friday as he sought to walk back a comment that had drawn widespread condemnation for its racial overtones.

title: Beaver Hides, Bear Grease and The Revenant
description: Designing the costumes for The Revenant was both a physical and metaphysical challenge for Jacqueline West. This story of early-19th-century trappers stranded in the American wilderness was filmed largely outdoors in the Canadian Rockies during fall and winter, when temperatures sometimes reached 40 degrees below zero, so keeping the actors warm  and alive, she added  was a serious concern.

title: Beyonc Will Join Coldplay at Super Bowl 50 Halftime Show
description: After just a two-year absence, Beyonc is coming back to the Super Bowl.

title: Cuomos Multibillion-Dollar Wish List
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has been busily announcing big projects, but he hasnt exactly said where the money will come from to pay for them.

title: Creating a Cuteness Empire in Japan, One Fuzzy Bear Suit at a Time
description: MIYAZAKI, Japan  FOR some of Japans most adored celebrities, the journey to fame starts in a converted Internet cafe above a bowling alley in this sunny southwestern city.

title: HBO Eyeing a Deadwood Return and Game of Thrones Extension
description: HBO is looking to bring back a gone-but-not-forgotten fan favorite and extend its current top series further than even the shows creators originally hoped.

title: New York Police Sergeant to Face Internal Charges in Eric Garner Confrontation
description: A New York City police sergeant was served with departmental disciplinary charges on Friday for her role in the confrontation that led to the death of Eric Garner in 2014.

title: Letters: The Year in Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: Recipes for the Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE NAZIS NEXT DOOR: How America Became a Safe Haven for Hitlers Men, by Eric Lichtblau. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $15.95.) Drawing on interviews and a trove of released documents, Lichtblau, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter for The New York Times, recounts how America accepted approximately 10,000 Nazis in the wake of World War II. Many of these were recruited to work as scientists or as spies for the United States government, while others immigrated as refugees.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE BLIZZARD, by Vladimir Sorokin. Translated by Jamey Gambrell. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) A doctor struggles through a snowstorm to aid the victims of a zombie plague in this combination satire and dystopian tale set in the near future.

title: Inside the List
description: Sugar and Spice: Every year around this time, when people are still recovering from the holidays and the main hardcover lists have settled into deep-freeze mode  a single new entry in the past four weeks!  it has become traditional for Inside the List to wander a little afield. Sometimes we reprint a list from years past. Sometimes we ask best-selling authors for their book-related wish lists or resolutions. This year, we bring you cookies: specifically, Rosanna Pansinos atom cookies, from The Nerdy Nummies Cookbook, at No.5 in its second month on the food and fitness list (available online). Pansino belongs to the growing club of YouTube stars who have crossed over into publishing; her online baking show, also called Nerdy Nummies, has more than three million subscribers who watch her take goofy delight in treats like doughnut waffles. (These are, literally, store-bought glazed doughnuts, heated and pressed in a home waffle iron. Im not sure that qualifies as baking, but it sounds amazing.) If you suspect that Pansinos appeal has as much to do with charm and presentation as with the actual recipes, her book probably wont change your mind. But she is charming, in her way. Heres how she introduces those atom cookies, which are just six-pointed sugar cookies iced and decorated to resemble a science classs atom model, with an M&M nucleus and candy pearl electrons: Atoms are the building blocks of every type of matter in the universe  even you! My grandfather was a nuclear physicist, my uncle followed in his footsteps, and my dads old high school even had an atom on its emblem. I guess you could say we have an atomic bond. I decorated my atoms green, blue and purple, but you can make your atom cookies any color you want. Just remember: Never trust an atom ... they make up everything!

title: In the Presence of History
description: This week, Brent Staples, an editorial writer at The Times, reviews The Defender, a history of that pioneering black newspaper in Chicago, which was founded in 1905.

title: Moonlight Drives Zooplanktons Winter Migrations
description: During the dark winter months in the Arctic Ocean, zooplankton migrate by the light of the moon, a new study reports.

title: Suspect in Tel Aviv Rampage Is Killed in a Shootout With Police
description: JERUSALEM  The man suspected of killing three Israelis last week in a shooting rampage in Tel Aviv was killed on Friday in a shootout with the police near his home in northern Israel, according to police officials.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: Angry Birders: Standoff at Oregon Refuge Has Riled a Passionate Group
description: Noah Strycker was in a hotel room in Ethiopia when he saw news that Oregons Malheur National Wildlife Refuge had been occupied by an armed group protesting the federal governments imprisonment of two local ranchers. He had just completed a record-breaking Big Year of birding, in which he often spent 18 hours a day, without taking a day off, observing some 6,042 species of birds in 41 countries on seven continents. Mr. Stryckers obsessive pursuit had taken him to the ends of the earth, but news of the occupation brought Malheur to mind as the place where he first fell in love with birding.

title: Economists and Inequality
description: Im a few days late on this characteristically lucid Justin Fox column on why it took so long for economists to focus on income inequality. But as one of the economists who did write about inequality  especially the rise of the one percent  pretty early, I think Fox has missed one important aspect: its a hard issue to model.

title: On the Market in New York and New Jersey
description: This weeks properties include a four-bedroom in Ocean Grove, N.J., and a six-bedroom in Laurel Hollow, N.Y.

title: A Costume Makers Unlikely Star Factory
description: Hiromi Kanos factory turns out some of Japans most popular mascots  the smiling, dancing animals, mutated foodstuffs and saucer-eyed humanoids that promote every conceivable thing in the country.

title: The Sleep of the Righteous, by Wolfgang Hilbig
description: The brutality, betrayals and deadening conformity of East Germany have provided fodder for a long list of celebrated writers. Christa Wolf won acclaim for her nuanced critiques of the now defunct Communist dictatorship, though her reputation took a beating with her admission that she had served as a Stasi informant. Heiner Mllers scathing dramas challenged the authoritarian regime and earned him scorn as a historical pessimist. Then there was Wolfgang Hilbig, born in Saxony in 1941, who shoveled coal in a factory boiler room before discovering his true calling. Permitted to resettle in West Germany in 1985, he began attracting attention for his evocations of the Easts apocalyptic postwar landscape and the dislocations of a Cold War-era migr who felt like an outsider in both societies.

title: Paradise City, by Elizabeth Day
description: Novels in which separate story lines collide often give the impression that even the most disparate people are somehow connected. And when that collision occurs through an act of violence, its sometimes assumed that other differences can be ignored  because, after all, what life has been lived without some pain and suffering? At best, such stories come across as saccharine odes to our shared humanity. But in a novel like Elizabeth Days tale of contemporary London, Paradise City, they can seem to exploit the circumstances of the less fortunate and the marginalized.

title: Defenders of the Unborn, by Daniel K. Williams
description: Among those of us who wish to protect access to abortion, its easy to feel that right to life language is a cover for an attack on feminism. Its a feeling supported by a common story about history: The anti-abortion movement began after Roe v. Wade, because conservative evangelicals were threatened by womens newfound power over their bodies. What else could explain the movements swift rise in the decade following the Supreme Courts decision, if not a widespread reaction against equal rights?

title: Dave Hickeys 25 Women: Essays on Their Art
description: Most of my favorite people are women, Dave Hickey proclaims in the introduction to 25 Women. This statement, and indeed the whole book, can be read as a response to the accusations of sexism that have followed Hickey since the culture wars of the 90s, when he published The Invisible Dragon, a series of cantankerous essays attacking the academic art establishment. According to Hickey, beauty, once the handmaiden of art, had been sacrificed on the altar of political correctness by a censorious ring of tenured apparatchiks. Hickeys antagonists fought back. For the feminist critic Amelia Jones, his revival of an abstract notion of beauty served to validate a particular group of critics (almost all white men) as having access to the truth. For its critics, beauty was hardly innocent or self-evident, but hampered with cultural baggage: the objectification of women, the exclusion of minorities and the meretricious seductions of the marketplace.

title: New Health Advice for Britons: No More Than Six Pints a Week
description: LONDON  Good wine is a good familiar creature, if it be well used, the villain Iago says in Shakespeares Othello.

title: Words Unwired
description: Whats the point of a literary magazine today? Thats a question I heard a lot five years ago, when my colleagues and I decided to relaunch The Paris Review.

title: Fake Missed Connections, by Brett Fletcher Lauer
description: For people still willing to get romantically involved with a Brooklyn writer, the poet Brett Fletcher Lauers memoir, Fake Missed Connections, may send them back to the shuffleboard bars of Gowanus for less troublesome freight. Lauer, the deputy director of the Poetry Society of America and author of the poetry collection A Hotel in Belgium, begins his memoir with a ringing phone; the call (or, as he later refers to it, The Phone Call) is from a woman he doesnt know, informing Lauer that his wife is having an affair with her husband. Who was that? Lauers wife asks from the couch, and the memoirs first story line  an archaeological dig in the ground of marital infidelity and its aftermath  is underway.

title: New York City
description: CITY ON A GRIDHow New York Became New YorkBy Gerard Koeppel296 pp. Da Capo, $29.99.

title: Christopher Hitchenss And Yet . . . and Roger Scrutons Fools, Frauds and Firebrands
description: In The New York Intellectuals, his seminal 1968 essay looking back on the coterie of writers who burst on the scene in the late 1930s and exercised an outsize influence on the American mind until the rise of the New Left in the early 60s, Irving Howe nicely captured what is distinctive about intellectuals in all times and places.

title: Golden Globe Awards Parties Off to a Cold, Rainy Start
description: LOS ANGELES  Its been rainy and cold here, with nighttime temperatures in the 40s, and the Beverly Hilton, where the Golden Globes will be held on Sunday, isnt looking glamorous at all, thanks to a new 12-story hotel going up in front of it. (Its to be a Waldorf Astoria.) Things feel topsy-turvy, but, then again, its been a topsy-turvy awards season.

title: Alex Haley: And the Books That Changed a Nation, by Robert J. Norrell
description: In 1977 Alex Haley, the author of the best-selling Autobiography of Malcolm X, achieved world renown after ABC broadcast an eight-part version of his book Roots, published the previous year to great acclaim. Roots, which chronicled Haleys search for his African ancestors (and in doing so created a template for the genealogical boom reflected in popular series like Finding Your Roots, with Henry Louis Gates Jr.), became an international phenomenon that turned the financially insecure Haley into an icon. Yet Haleys newfound celebrity and wealth proved to be a double-edged sword. Allegations of plagiarism and historical inaccuracies scarred him, diminishing his literary reputation, and, argues the historian Robert J. Norrell in his briskly paced Alex Haley: And the Books That Changed a Nation, unfairly tarnished the author of the two most influential books on African-American history in the second half of the 20th century.

title: One Child, by Mei Fong
description: Readers would be forgiven for thinking that the announcement, on Oct. 29, 2015, that China was changing its one-child policy would have turned this book from an account of the daily lives of Chinese people into a work of history. Not so. The event itself came rather late for Mei Fongs One Child. But she makes disconcertingly clear that the repercussions of population control will continue to reverberate throughout China. The policy itself remains a monument to official callousness, and Fongs book pays moving testimony to the suffering and forbearance of its victims.

title: The Idealist: Aaron Swartz and the Rise of Free Culture on the Internet, by Justin Peters
description: On a late autumn day in 2010, Aaron Swartz, an open-information advocate and early partner at the website Reddit, sneaked into a basement closet at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and surreptitiously connected his laptop to the schools high-speed Internet network. Using the schools credentials, he gained access to JSTOR, a database of academic journals, and began to illegally download thousands of files. Once a promising entrepreneur, Swartz had eschewed the traditional Silicon Valley career path for an unorthodox campaign of radical public-interest activism. He believed that the five million documents behind the JSTOR paywall were a common good and that they needed to be liberated by guerrilla action.

title: Shame and Wonder, by David Searcy
description: When people talk about style they are always a little astonished at the newness of it, F. Scott Fitzgerald once wrote, because they think that it is only style that they are talking about. But uncommon literary style is always integrative, both the mother and the daughter of invention, wrought from a writers desperation to express a new idea with such force that it will have the originality of the thought.

title: The Geography of Genius, by Eric Weiner
description: In the early 1960s, the Soviet Union tried to make a version of Silicon Valley from scratch. A city called Zelenograd came to life on the outskirts of Moscow and was populated with all manner of brainy Soviet engineers. The hope  naturally  was that a concentration of clever minds coupled with ample funding would result in a wellspring of innovation and help Russia keep pace with Californias electronics boom. The experiment worked as well as one might expect. Few people will read this on a Mayakovsky-branded tablet or smartphone.

title: Dictator, by Robert Harris
description: Cicero, the Roman statesman whose talent for oratory was such that he remains to this day a byword for eloquence, has always divided opinion. A key player in the death agony of Romes traditional republican system of government, he was lauded by his admirers as a defender of constitutional propriety and dismissed by his foes as a vacillating opportunist. Posterity has proved similarly conflicted. While Americas founding fathers revered him as a model of civic duty, he was excoriated by the most formidable German classicist of the 19th century, Theodor Mommsen, as a precursor of that lowest class of writer, a newspaper columnist. A persons attitude to Cicero can often be most revealing.

title: Martin OMalley Could Get Excluded From the Next Democratic Debate
description: Former Gov. Martin OMalley of Maryland, who has argued most strenuously for more Democratic debates, is at risk of not qualifying for the next one under criteria laid out by NBC, the network hosting the Jan. 17 debate in South Carolina.

title: French Tax Authorities Investigate Karl Lagerfeld Over Tax Evasion Claims
description: The new year may have begun, but one old trend seems to be refusing to go out of fashion: luxury industry big-hitters who run afoul of the law for alleged tax evasion.

title: Affluenza Case Mother, Tonya Couch, Appears in Texas Court
description: The mother of the Texas teenager known for using an affluenza defense in a fatal drunken-driving case appeared in a Fort Worth court on Friday to face a felony charge related to helping her son flee to Mexico.

title: Hillary Clintons Twist on Paid Leave: She Plans to Tax Wealthiest
description: Hillary Clinton explained her proposal for paid family leave for the first time on Thursday, and it shared a lot with other politicians plans: 12 weeks of paid time off to care for a new child or a sick family member or to recover from an illness or injury.

title: A Welcome Move on Police Surveillance
description: More than 30 years have passed since the federal courts reacted to the New York City Police Departments disregard for the Constitution by limiting how far the department could go in conducting surveillance on constitutionally protected activity. The court-ordered guidelines were loosened after 9/11 to give the police more flexibility. But over time, the tendencies that had forced the courts to act in the first place began to reassert themselves. In 2013, for example, the Associated Press showed that the department was using the terrorism designation to spy on law-abiding Muslims  and to ignore court-ordered limitations on investigations of constitutionally protected activity.

title: New Clinton Emails Show Mixed Concerns on Security of Information
description: WASHINGTON  On a Friday morning in June 2011, after Secretary of State Hillary Clinton had waited more than 12 hours for a set of talking points to be sent to her, a top aide told her the delay was because staff members were having problems sending faxes that would be secure from probing eyes.

title: With Nuclear Test, North Koreas Leader Asserts Role of Instigator
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The young leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un, has often been dismissed as inexperienced, erratic and even clueless. But with the Norths test of a nuclear bomb this week, he appears to have mastered a strategy that has served his reclusive country well: playing one big power against another.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Seattle Seahawks Defense Stands Out, Even Across Eras
description: The Seattle Seahawks have allowed the fewest points in the N.F.L. in each of the last four seasons. No team during the Super Bowl era has matched that feat. In fact, the only other team to lead the N.F.L. in points allowed for such a stretch was the Cleveland Browns, who did it in five consecutive seasons from 1953 to 1957.

title: New Jerseys Private-Sector Retirement Plan Moves Forward
description: Employees who work for private businesses in New Jersey are one step closer to receiving a relatively low-cost retirement savings plan, which would be run by the state but offered through employers.

title: Governors Ball 2016 Books Kanye West, the Strokes and the Killers
description: In its quest to compete with Coachella, Bonnaroo and Lollapalooza, New Yorks own big summer festival, Governors Ball, is going with Kanye West. The rapper has received top billing for the 2016 event along with the Strokes and the Killers. Beck, Robyn, Haim and M83 are also on the lineup for the festival, scheduled for June 3-5 on Randalls Island.

title: Charles Koch Knocks Positions of Donald Trump and Ted Cruz
description: The billionaire Koch brothers have long been power brokers within the Republican Party, using their wealth to steer candidates and their policies. But this election season is turning out to be a different story, with a billionaire celebrity and a firebrand senator from Texas taking the political debate in directions that Charles G. Koch finds worrisome.

title: The London Mens Collections Start the Fall Fashion Season
description: LONDON  Fashion buyers and news media from around the world are arriving this weekend for London Collections Men, a four-day event that has become not just a curtain raiser for the traditional mens wear catwalk season but also a source of financial firepower that goes far beyond its runways.

title: Bernie Sanders Has Killer Mike in His Corner
description: In July, the Twitter account of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont sent a single tweet that convinced Michael Render that this was the most exciting candidate he had ever seen.

title: Obama Shifts Online Strategy on ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday announced an overhaul of its efforts to respond to online propaganda from the Islamic State after months of acknowledgments that it had largely failed in its attempts to counter extremist recruitment and exhortations to violence on social media.

title: Cooking Beans at Home, Leaving the Can Behind
description: Lets get one thing straight.

title: A Country House for a Family of Six
description: When Damian and Britt Zunino, the husband-and-wife principals of the New York design firm Studio DB, began conceiving their weekend house in Amenia, N.Y., they came to a surprising realization: designing a home for themselves was a lot more difficult than doing projects for clients.

title: St. Louis Leaders Dispute Rams Reasons to Leave
description: With days to go before the 32 N.F.L. owners are expected to vote on whether to allow one or two teams to relocate to the Los Angeles area, officials in St. Louis angrily disputed the arguments that the Rams owner E. Stanley Kroenke made to justify being allowed to move his team to Southern California.

title: On Location | Amenia, N.Y.
description: Damian and Britt Zunino, the husband-and-wife partners of the New York design firm Studio DB, designed and built a home for weekend getaways,

title: When Can Women Stop Trying to Look Perfect?
description: AS a lifelong devotee of fashion and tabloid magazines, Ive read dozens of Beautiful/Sexy at Any Age features. Youve probably seen these spreads, showcasing a bevy of lovely women whose faces, fashions, exercise routines and skin-care regimens are laid out to encourage imitation. For years, readers could stare at starlets and actresses and singers in their 20s, their 30s, their 40s and even edging bravely into their early 60s.

title: U.S. Sends Kuwaiti Detainee Home From Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  The United States on Friday repatriated the last Kuwaiti man it had held at its wartime prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, bringing an end to his 14 years in American military custody without trial.

title: No Making a Murderer Pardon From Obama, White House Says
description: President Obama will not be pardoning Steven Avery and Brendan Dassey, the subjects of the Netflix documentary series Making a Murderer.

title: Up for Auction: Real Art, Owned by a Seller of Forgeries
description: For years, the Gaston & Sheehan auction house, family-owned and located in Pflugerville, a small city in central Texas, has been a trusted place used by federal marshals to sell the many things seized in criminal cases.

title: 1205: Fall 2016
description: The latest designs from 1205.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Defender
description: This week, Brent Staples discusses The Defender and the history of the black press; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Maria Konnikova talks about The Confidence Game; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: A State of Mind
description: Photographs by Janet Delaney show New York in the mid-1980s, a time defined by yuppies, hip-hop and the emerging AIDS crisis.

title: Janet Delaney Photographs New York in the 1980s
description: New York in the mid-1980s was a city braced for powerful forces: the swaggering yuppiedom of Bonfire of the Vanities and Oliver Stones Wall Street (both 1987); the AIDS epidemic and the crack wars; the graffiti boom and the golden age of New York hip-hop. For the photographer Janet Delaney, who visited regularly from the West Coast, between trips to Nicaragua, New York in the mid-1980s was a street theater where people wore their anxieties on their faces, a city that looked you in the eye. It was also a tough place to break into as an outsider, she said.

title: Mandatory Union Fees Getting Hard Look by Supreme Court
description: FRESNO, Calif.  Harlan Elrich is a high school teacher in California, and that means he must pay about $970 a year to a labor union. He teaches math, and he said the system did not add up.

title: Its Raining Campaign Ads: Reporters Notebook
description: An endless stream of ads dropping into an email inbox is a waking nightmare for most regular people. For me, its one of the joys of the political-ad beat.

title: Popcast: Jazz Moments of 2015
description: New York Times music critics discuss the year in jazz.

title: Gunman Said He Shot Philadelphia Officer for ISIS, Police Say
description: PHILADELPHIA  A man who wounded a Philadelphia police officer in a patrol car, emptying his gun and even reaching through the car window to shoot the officer, told investigators that he did it in the name of Islam and the Islamic State, police officials said Friday.

title: In the Studio With Paula Gerbase of 1205
description: The designer presents her first mens runway show this week during London Collections: Men.

title: A Quiet Womens Label Focuses on Men
description: The fashion line 1205 is best known for its elegant, tailored womens wear, which has shown during London Fashion Week for six seasons  but today, its founder, the Brazilian designer Paula Gerbase, holds her first mens wear show as part of London Collections: Men.

title: Puerto Rico Pleads for Congressional Help as Lawsuits Are Filed
description: Puerto Ricos governor on Friday renewed his plea for Congress to provide bankruptcy protection for the debt-ridden island, after two bond insurers filed lawsuits over his decision to default on millions of dollars in bond payments last week.

title: For $26 Million, Terraces in Greenwich Village
description: A duplex penthouse at the Greenwich Lane condominium complex, which is rising at the site of the former St. Vincents Hospital campus in Greenwich Village, sold for $26,030,475.81 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Rooney Maras Sheer, Goth Look
description: The Star: Rooney Mara

title: Skin Whitener Ad Sparks Criticism in Thailand
description: A Thai beauty company that sells skin-whitening products pulled a recent video advertisement after viewers were offended that the ad showed an actress in blackface and compared her unfavorably to a light-skinned woman.

title: MAN: Fall 2016
description: MANs fall 2016 show.

title: Irene Neuwirths Perfect Mornings (and Smoothie Recipe)
description: In a perfect world I wake up early  which I always do  take my dog Teddy for a long walk, get coffee, work out and make my smoothie, says the jewelry designer Irene Neuwirth. Though she has a weakness for cheeseburgers, Neuwirth starts each day with a protein-packed shake that has evolved over the years. Its been a bit of trial and error. Ingredients come and go, but this is what Im really enjoying right now, she says of its current incarnation. The chia seeds give me energy, and the protein powder actually fills me up. And I always love fresh fruit. Its a solid balance of delicious and good for you.

title: Man Wrongly Convicted in 97 Brooklyn Killing Settles With City and State
description: A man who fought his murder conviction while he was behind bars for 17 years and ultimately won an exoneration without a lawyer has reached a $3.75 million settlement with New York City.

title: Test Your N.F.L. Knowledge
description: Have you spent the last 17 Sundays parked on a couch yelling at your flatscreen? How many of these questions about the N.F.L. league leaders can you answer correctly?

title: El Chapo, Escaped Mexican Drug Lord, Is Recaptured in Gun Battle
description: MEXICO CITY  He became a byword for government incompetence, a figure who seemed invincible after he burrowed his way out of the countrys most secure prison.

title: Mexicos Challenges
description: To the Editor:

title: Albert Watsons TriBeCa Penthouse Listed at $21.5 Million
description: The photographer Albert Watson, whose famous images of Alfred Hitchcock, Steve Jobs and other luminaries from various walks of life have graced magazine covers, movie posters, books and catalogs, is putting his duplex penthouse in TriBeCa on the market.

title: Exclusive | 101 Warren Street
description: The photographer Albert Watson and his wife, Elizabeth Watson, are selling their TriBeCa penthouse for $21.5 million.

title: Marco Rubios Made-For-TV Campaign
description: Marco Rubio didnt say much during his in-personinterview with the staff of the tiny Conway Daily Sunin New Hampshire  which said plenty about a new ripple in this years presidential campaign.

title: Haifa, Part 2:  Articles Author Responds to Complaints
description: I wrote earlier today about complaints, from all sides, about a Times feature story on the social scene in the Israeli city of Haifa. After my postwas written and edited, I heard from the articlesauthor, Diaa Hadid, who had been traveling and unavailable earlier.

title: Monkey Has No Rights to Its Selfie, Federal Judge Says
description: An Indonesian monkey that achieved Internet celebrity with a grinning selfie cannot own the photographs copyright, a federal judge said this week.

title: Oversight for New York Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: Ted Cruzs Iowa Bus Tour: A Prayer a Day Until the Caucuses
description: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These arethe places, faces and culinary selectionsof 2016s first proper bus tour.

title: Court Blocks Order That Officer Testify in Freddie Gray Case
description: WASHINGTON  A Maryland appeals court on Friday temporarily blocked a lower court order that required a Baltimore police officer, William G. Porter, to testify against a colleague set to go on trial next week on murder charges in the death of Freddie Gray.

title: In Insider Trading Settlement, Steven Cohen Will Be Free to Manage Outside Money in 2 Years
description: Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire investor, is walking away largely unscathed from nearly a decade of investigations by federal prosecutors and securities regulators into accusations of insider trading at his former hedge fund.

title: Old Mariner, With Rhymes and Love for East Village
description: It was after noon on Monday, so Phillip Giambri, 74, put on his pork-pie hat and walked from his apartment on St. Marks Place to Grassroots Tavern, a joint with low ceilings, cheap drinks and a pervasive tang of stale beer that smelled like tough, old New York.

title: European Starling, the Bards Bird
description: There are few birds as universally reviled as the European starling, and consequently, few with as interesting a story to tell. The bird is not the oily, crop-eating winged rat of legend. In fact, it is closer to an avian Horatio Alger: In human-altered environs, it gets my vote for the bird most likely to succeed.

title: Foot Fetishism
description: The business about Marco Rubios boots is, of course, incredibly stupid. But its part of a pattern  as David Roberts says,

title: N.F.L. Wild-Card Playoff Schedule and Picks
description: The N.F.L. playoffs begin this weekend with four wild-card games. Heres how they match up and who we think will win them:

title: How Would Mao Stack Up in New York?
description: A 120-foot-tall statue of Mao that was torn down Thursday certainly looked enormous in the fields of Henan Province in China. But it would have been pretty impressive in New York, too.

title: Stories of Brooklyn, From Gowanus to the Heights
description: The Gowanus Canal may never evoke Venice, but within a few decades, developers are betting, people will be paying a high premium to inhabit its banks. Until then, readers can get a historical view through Joseph Alexious edifying Gowanus: Brooklyns Curious Canal (New York University Press, $29.95).

title: Obama to Leave Empty Seat for Gun Victims in State of the Union Audience
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama plans to leave an empty seat in the House gallery next week when he delivers his final State of the Union address to symbolize the victims of gun violence in the United States, a senior administration official said Friday.

title: Finding Solutions Beyond Homeless Shelters
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama Vetoes Bill to Repeal Health Law and End Planned Parenthood Funding
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama vetoed legislation Friday that would have repealed the Affordable Care Act and stripped all federal funds from Planned Parenthood, writing in his veto message that the measure would reverse the significant progress we have made in improving health care in America.

title: Law Firms Risking Obsolescence, Report Says
description: As the legal industry faces sluggish demand for services, weakened pricing power and falling productivity, a new report is warning that the countrys law firms are failing to make bold, proactive changes.

title: Top Venezuelan Lawmaker Was Called Repellent by U.S. Official
description: The American government was thrilled by the landslide victory of the Venezuelan opposition in last Decembers parliamentary election. But Latin America hands at the State Department couldnt have been thrilled to learn the new speaker of Venezuelasassembly is the veteran opposition leader Henry Ramos Allup.

title: Attack at Hotel in Egypt Injures European Tourists
description: CAIRO  Two militants stormed into a hotel in the Egyptian Red Sea resort of Hurghada on Friday, stabbing and wounding three European tourists, Egypts Interior Ministry said.

title: Staying Put Amid Puerto Ricos Economic Crisis
description: With Puerto Ricos economic crisis forcing young professionals to seek opportunity on the American mainland, Joseph Rodriguez looked at those who have been left behind.

title: Sexual Harassment Allegations Add to a Florida Museums Troubles
description: MIAMI  After all of the drama at the Museum of Contemporary Art in the last few years, including the resignation in 2014 of the entire board, the firing last week of the museums director in the aftermath of sexual harassment allegations against him was a fresh blow to an institution struggling to remain relevant in a booming art scene here.

title: The Fashion News to Know This Week
description: Dolce & abaya

title: Kansas City Chiefs at Houston Texans Preview
description: Kansas City Chiefs (11-5) at Houston Texans (9-7)

title: Presidente de Mxico anuncia la captura del Chapo Guzmn
description: Por Azam Ahmed y Vernica Caldern

title: Young Moviemakers Meet Old Masters at the Frick
description: In the Gilded Age mansion of the Frick Collection, in a room devoted to Jean-Honor Fragonards bucolic wall panels called The Progress of Love, two young men meet and begin a flirtatious debate about the four stages of love illustrated in the 18th-century canvases, from a painted couples first pastoral encounter to their joyful reminiscing over old love letters. The more worldly of the two men suggests that actual love can be far more treacherous. Indeed, the arc of their relationship eventually bears this out: Far from Fragonards happily-ever-after scenario, it ends with a breakup devastating to one of the men. Years later, he advises his teenage niece that pain is a privilege of being human. Lifes little pleasures are worth rotting for, he says.

title: Saudi Aramco I.P.O. Prospect Reflects Kingdom Looking Beyond Oil
description: LONDON  Saudi Arabia, the worlds biggest petroleum exporter, is staring into a future in which its most valuable asset  the oil under its sands  is shrinking in value.

title: China Setting Up Fund for Its Electronics Industry
description: HONG KONG  A Chinese technology regulator said on Friday that it would cooperate with a bank to set up a $30 billion fund to support the countrys huge electronics supply chain.

title: Excerpts From Imagined Clinton-Blair Chats, Intended as Satire, Cause Confusion
description: In a now familiar ritual, the release on Thursday of hundreds of pages of transcribed phone calls and meetings between former President Bill Clinton and Tony Blair, then the British prime minister, from early 1997, to late 2000, was followed by journalists and political junkies sharing striking, funny or odd excerpts from the chats on social networks.

title: Ted Cruzs Iowa Bus Tour: Benny Youngman Was Before My Time
description: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These arethe places, faces and culinary selectionsof 2016s first proper bus tour.
