description: How far would you go to follow your moral beliefs if they conflicted with the laws of the state?

title: Claire Danes Joins Cast of Dry Powder Off Broadway
description: Claire Danes, taking a break from battling Americas enemies and her own demons in Homeland, will return to the New York stage this March in Dry Powder, a new play about the excesses of the American economy. She and Hank Azaria will join John Krasinski, whose casting had already been announced, in the comic drama written by Sarah Burgess.

title: LeBron James Is So Luminous, Yet So Trapped by the Publics Glare
description: With each locational move, celebrated or decried, the baggage has become a heavier burden. Glass has covered more and more of LeBron Jamess basketball house.

title: Jeb Bushs Brother, Quiet So Far, Could Re-emerge In February
description: NASHUA, N.H.  To W., or not to W., that is the question.

title: Cuomo Picks Maria Vullo as States Top Financial Watchdog
description: After a monthslong delay, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday named a new top financial regulator for New York State, nominating Maria T. Vullo, a prominent litigator with ties to his administration.

title: Nice Try! Is Not Enough
description: Among the most-uttered phrases of my generation of parents have to be these: Great effort! Nice try! I can tell you worked so hard!

title: Parents in Tow, Finding a Charming and Cheap Corner of Panama
description: The first Panamanian I met promptly handed me a baby.

title: A Public Health Crisis: The People of Flint Deserved Better
description: To the Editor:

title: De Blasio Presents $82.1 Billion Budget
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio presented his proposed budget for New York City on Thursday mostly devoid of new broad liberal initiatives that have been the hallmark of his tenure, underscoring a recognition that the city may be headed for an economic downturn.

title: Vibrant Lives of Afghan TV Crew, Erased in a Taliban Bombing
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  One was a young graphic designer planning a wedding. Another was an editor who made documentaries in his free time and dreamed of winning an Oscar. A third employee, whose child died of an illness last year, often posted pictures of his surviving child on Facebook in hopes of a brighter future.

title: The Republicans Downward Spiral
description: To the Editor:

title: Saul Leiters Fashion and Documentary Work
description: The photographer is the subject of a new retrospective, which opens tomorrow in London.

title: A Prolific New York Photographer Comes Back Into Focus
description: You could almost say he had a lifetime of being continually rediscovered, says Margit Erb, the director of the Saul Leiter Foundation. Leiter, who died in 2013, just shy of his 90th birthday  had a varied seven-decade career, and gained his most significant recognition in the last years of his life, with the 2006 publication of his book Early Color. I think his rise back to fame was because people just couldnt help stumbling over and over him, and realizing that the world needed to know him, Erb says.

title: Zika Virus May be Linked to Surge in Rare Syndrome in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A mosquito-borne virus that has been linked to severe brain damage in infants may be causing another serious health crisis as well, Brazilian officials and doctors warn: hundreds of cases of a rare syndrome in which patients can be almost completely paralyzed for weeks.

title: The Past Haunts Oxford Debate Over Rhodes Statue
description: LONDON  High above a main thoroughfare in the city of Oxford, in an alcove framed by twirly columns, a statue of Cecil John Rhodes, the archimperialist who shaped Britains empire and the destiny of its far-flung subjects in Africa, peers down inscrutably on the people below. If you werent looking for it, you might miss it.

title: Marco Rubio Steps Up Attacks On Ted Cruz, Calling Him a Flip-Flopper
description: BROOKLINE, N.H.  Senator Marco Rubio declared Thursday that his Senate colleague Ted Cruz is not who he says he is, challenging Mr. Cruzs sincerity and calling him a flip-flopper.

title: Nepal Police Fire on Madhesi Protesters, Killing at Least 3
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  The police fired on ethnic Madhesi protesters in eastern Nepal on Thursday, killing at least three of them in the latest flare-up of political tensions over Nepals Constitution.

title: Is a Single-Payer Health Insurance Program Feasible?
description: To the Editor:

title: Database Tracks Tigers and Flies Caught in Xi Jinpings Corruption Crackdown
description: Two days after taking control of the worlds most powerful political party in November 2012, Xi Jinping warned his fellow Chinese Communist Party members that their six decades of rule was in jeopardy because of what he saw as endemic corruption eating away at the partys authority and effectiveness.

title: Saoirse Ronans Red-Carpet Looks
description: At events, Ms. Ronan displays both mature silhouettes and whimsical touches.

title: Fired Police Chief and 2 Others Sue, Charging Racial Bias in Maryland
description: WASHINGTON  A fired black police chief and two black officers on Marylands Eastern Shore filed a civil rights lawsuit in federal court in Baltimore on Thursday, alleging the kind of Jim Crow-era racial discrimination that most Americans would have believed unthinkable in the second decade of the 21st century.

title: Saoirse Ronanof Brooklyn Masters Minis and Mixed Prints
description: The Irish-American actress Saoirse Ronan received her first Oscar nomination at age 13, and now, at a positively ancient 21, shes having another breakout year.

title: Pete Wellss Most Read Restaurant Reviews
description: Some of the restaurant reviews that have provided the most feedback.

title: Where Virtual Reality Takes Us
De Blasio Vows Better Coordination as New York Prepares for Snowstorm
description: One year ago, as New York braced for what many experts said would be one of the worst winter storms ever to hit the city, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo decided to shut down the subway system for the first time in its 110-year history because of the threat of snow.

title: Review: Aferim! Traverses an Unforgiving Romania in the 1800s
description: Do you need another reason to be mad about the Oscar nominations? Well heres one, expressed as tradition demands in the form of a hashtag: #WhataboutAferim! Aferim!  the title translates more or less as Attaboy!  is Radu Judes sublime new feature, a funny and brutal costume drama with a potent contemporary kick. Officially submitted for consideration as Romanias official entry in the best foreign-language film sweepstakes, it was omitted from the final list of five nominees.

title: Cow Is Captured by the Police After Running Loose in Queens
description: The cow in Queens was confused but determined.

title: Mustafa Koc, Leader of Turkish Conglomerate, Dies at 55
description: ISTANBUL  Mustafa Koc, a prominent Turkish businessman who succeeded his father and grandfather in running one of the worlds largest conglomerates, Koc Holding, died here on Thursday. He was 55.

title: Hillary Clinton Knocks Bernie Sanders on Iran
description: INDIANOLA, Iowa  With Senator Bernie Sanderss domestic message of tackling income inequality giving him momentum here, Hillary Clinton sought Thursday to shift the conversation to foreign policy, portraying her rival as inexperienced and ill-equipped to address the firestorms erupting in the Middle East.

title: Husband of Scarsdale Doctor Is Charged in Her Fatal Stabbing
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y.  Robin Goldman was a doctor who made a career caring for children, and a teacher who showed young doctors how to do the same. But her own children said it was her role as mother that she seemed to covet most.

title: Yohji Yamamoto: Fall 2016
description: Yohji Yamamotos fall 2016 show.

title: Pacino Leads China Doll to Broadway Profitability
description: China Doll, a critically panned but commercially successful new David Mamet play starring Al Pacino, has recouped its $3.7 million investment costs.

title: Review: Prescription Thugs, a Confessional Documentary on Substance Abuse
description: Even before a do as I say, not as I do twist costs it all credibility, Prescription Thugs is a not very good documentary about a very important subject.

title: Rate of Birth Defect of Abdominal Wall Increasing, C.D.C. Says
description: A serious birth defect is appearing in maternity wards with increasing frequency, and experts do not know why, federal researchers reported on Thursday.

title: Review: Vanessa Williams, Strong and Steady, Without Taking Chances
description: Vanessa Williams operates in so many arenas, it has always been difficult to figure out who she really is  beyond being an attractive, disciplined, highly competent singer and actor who seems equally comfortable in front of a camera, in a recording studio and on the stage. In her 90-minute concert on Wednesday evening at the Appel Room, which opened Lincoln Centers American Songbook series, the persona she projected was a hard-working, self-possessed entertainer with a clear perspective on her show business lineage.

title: Marc-Andr Hamelin Gradually Ups the Ante at Carnegie Hall
description: In a delightfully perverse bit of programming, the esteemed pianist Marc-Andr Hamelin opened his Carnegie Hall recital on Wednesday evening, after a heros welcome from the audience, with Mozarts unassuming Sonata in C (K. 545)  in the composers words, a little piano sonata for beginners.

title: U.S. Tightens Visa Rules for Some European Visitors
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Thursday announced changes to a visa-waiver program that would make it harder for travelers to enter the United States from Europe if they had dual citizenship from Iran, Iraq, Sudan or Syria, or had visited one of those countries in the last five years.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs: How the Four Conference Championship Teams Match Up
description: 3:05 p.m. Eastern, CBS. Line: Patriots by 3.

title: Review: Wet Ink Ensemble Pays Tribute to Anthony Braxton
description: A marching tune that dissolves into frenzy, a big-band jamboree with an ethereal voice hovering over it: The dense, wild, yet artfully controlled tribute to Anthony Braxton at National Sawdust on Wednesday evening bore a striking resemblance to his dense, wild, yet artfully controlled music.

title: Frank Lloyd Wright House in Los Angeles Will Be Auctioned
description: A 1,200-square-foot house that Frank Lloyd Wright designed to perch on a Los Angeles hillside will be auctioned next month, with most of its contents sold separately.

title: Review: Martyrs, a Slashing Remake, Centers on Two Friends
description: For those who care deeply about the provenance of their entertainment (and I am sometimes among them), the filmmaking brothers Kevin and Michael Goetz describe their new project, Martyrs, as a reimagining of Pascal Laugiers 2008 original of the same name. Without seeing the earlier movie, I cant comment; but after enduring this one, I can only wonder why the brothers would cop to any creative input at all.

title: This Time, Cheaper Oil Does Little for the U.S. Economy
description: WASHINGTON  It has been a truism of the American economy for decades: When oil prices rise, the economy suffers; when they fall, growth improves.

title: 36 Hours in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic
description: More than simply a base for the beaches, this energetic city combines a vibrant night life with graceful, centuries-old buildings.

title: The Italian Artist Enrico Baj at Luxembourg & Dayan
description: Enrico Baj at Luxembourg & Dayan is a hoot and an eye-opener. Surveying about 16 years of works in several modes, the exhibition reintroduces the Italian artist Enrico Baj (1924-2003) to New York after an absence of three or four decades. This townhouse gallery is overflowing with his works, which confirms quite emphatically that there is more to postwar Italian art than the relatively pure abstraction of artists like Lucio Fontana, Piero Manzoni and Alberto Burri.

title: Elisabeth Moss and Boyd Holbrooks Sundance Tips and Truths
description: Among the most anticipated titles in competition at the 2016 Sundance Film Festival, kicking off today and running through Jan. 31 in Park City, Utah, is The Free World, an atmospheric drama from first-time filmmaker Jason Lew. The film stars Boyd Holbrook as a man wrongfully imprisoned for a grisly crime he didnt commit who, upon his release, meets an equally scarred woman (played by Elisabeth Moss of Mad Men) who again turns his life upside down. The two actors and friends are no strangers to Sundance  Holbrook first attended in 2011 with the drama Higher Ground, directed by Vera Farmiga, and Moss made her first trip in 2013 for the Sundance Channel series Top of the Lake. Here, they share a few things theyve learned along the way.

title: Ann Veronica Janssens Casts Strong Beams at Bortolami
Freeport-McMoRan Battles the Oil Slump
description: For a look at the damage that the plunging price of commodities  especially oil  is inflicting on the global economy, consider the plight of the venerable Freeport-McMoRan.

title: Heres How an Artist Plays the Stock Market
description: In her first Manhattan solo exhibition, Sarah Meyohas inventively recycles the genre of the artist performing live in a gallery. Wearing her own elegant design of a businesswomans suit, with gold pinstripes on sheer gray fabric, Ms. Meyohas sits at a chic, all-glass desk in the middle of 303 Gallery. Hanging on the gallery walls around her are 10 blank white canvases.

title: Walking the Walk in Hamiltons Old Stomping Grounds
description: Jimmy Napoli is not throwing away his shot.

title: Dana DeGiulio and Molly Zuckerman-Hartung Make an Emphatic Statement in Queen
description: Two painters, long based in Chicago, have moved to New York, and Queen, their joint exhibition at Lyles & King, is a dramatic statement signaling their arrival. This is Dana DeGiulios first show in New York; Molly Zuckerman-Hartung, who was  in the last Whitney Biennial, had a solo here in 2011. For both, however, this is a notable group of works.

title: A Step Toward Measuring Californias Water
description: One of the biggest problems facing California during its drought has been its failure to accurately measure water use, especially by farms. New regulations adopted by the states water board on Tuesday are a big step toward a solution.

title: Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump Open Up Strong Leads in Iowa, Poll Shows
description: Senator Bernie Sanders and Donald J. Trump have opened up solid leads in Iowa less than two weeks before the states caucuses kick off the 2016 presidential nominating contests, according to a poll released Thursday.

title: And You Thought You Loved Broadway
description: Stories and photos from some of the several thousand enthusiasts set to attend the first BroadwayCon in New York.

title: Money Grows on Anniversary Trees
description: My daughter surprised my husband and me with an awesome 25th anniversary party. On her invitation, she asked guests to give money toward our second honeymoon instead of gifts. All gave generously. We know our daughter meant well, but we are so embarrassed. My husband wants me to return the money with notes of apology. But my friend says, Why steal peoples joy in giving? I dont know what to do.

title: Review: Tosca, From NYCO Renaissance, Puts a Grand Ambition to the Test
description: Seldom has so much ridden on a single production of Puccinis Tosca. After months of legal wrangling over the fate of the New York City Opera, which filed for bankruptcy protection in late 2013, a group called NYCO Renaissance won approval for its plan to reorganize the company. It began the effort Wednesday night with the opening of a six-performance run of Tosca at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center.

title: Dries Van Noten: Fall 2016
description: The fall 2016 mens collection from Dries Van Noten.

title: Brady vs. Manning
description: On Sunday in Denver, Tom Brady and Peyton Manning will face off in the N.F.L. playoffs for the fifth and possibly final time. Heres a look at their previous postseason meetings.

title: Threes a Trend: Big, Baggy Pants
description: Volume has been a big theme at the mens shows this season, with several collections featuring oversize silhouettes and exaggerated proportions. Big fur coats popped up in London, and already throughout the first two days of Paris Fashion Week, designers including Y/Project and Raf Simons have shown extra-large knits and coats with long, trailing sleeves. But perhaps the most practical interpretation of volume is evident in slouchy pants  which this season have been cut wide through the legs. At Rick Owens, the baggy style (complete with cargo pockets) resembled that of a 90s raver. Christophe Lemaire deftly balanced his creased-front trousers with tailored coats, while Dries Van Noten paired a double-breasted blazer with generous trousers. And at Gosha Rubchinskiy, sweatpants  worn high,  la Al Bundy  came with a tucked in T-shirt and military shirt. Finally, we may just see the demise of the bare ankle in 2016.

title: Ted Cruz Goes Local in Latest South Carolina Ad
description: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is appealing to potential voters in South Carolinas Midlands region in a new advertisement called, simply, Midlands.

title: Britax Car Seats Recalled After Handle Breaks
description: Britax Child Safety is recalling about 71,000 child car seats in the United States because the carrying handle may break, allowing the infant carrier to be dropped, the company reported on Thursday in a regulatory filing.

title: Review: Dark Suspicions in Jumps and Gestures in The Winters Tale
description: WASHINGTON  Christopher Wheeldons The Winters Tale  the first ballet to dramatize that Shakespeare play  achieves an extraordinary amount. Movingly, over three acts, it takes us on a great arc of emotion and experience, capturing the plays themes of death and regeneration, hostility and reconciliation. When it takes liberties with aspects of the story, it does so persuasively. Its five leading roles  three for women, two for men  are marvelously distinct, while never seeming like copies of other roles in the repertory.

title: Events That Led to Flints Water Crisis
description: Timeline of the critical moments leading to the public health emergency.

title: Review: David Parsons Shares the Stage at Joyce Theater
description: This season, David Parsons shares the wealth  or, at least, the stage of the Joyce Theater  by including dances by two former company members: Train (2008), by Robert Battle, now the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater  a percussive jolt of a dance, powered by raw, manic athleticism; and the world premiere of Almah, by Katarzyna Skarpetowska, a subtle look at her Polish roots.

title: New Biggest Prime Number = 2 to the 74 Mil ... Uh, Its Big
description: The largest known prime number, newly discovered, is almost five million digits longer than the previous record-holder.

title: A Multitude of Fans, With a High Regard for Broadway
description: THE intense global and commercial nature of contemporary pop culture fandom is catching up with Broadway, and with it comes people like the 19-year-old Helen Fredstam, who arrived from Sweden this week to meet face to face with those who share her passion.

title: U.S. Presses for Haiti Runoff Vote Amid Fears of Violence and Fraud
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  After spending more than $33 million on a widely discredited election in Haiti, the United States has been pressing the countrys leaders to go ahead with a presidential runoff election this Sunday, despite a growing chorus of warnings that the vote could lead to an explosion of violence.

title: Alexander Litvinenko and the Banality of Evil in Putins Russia
description: Today, a retired British High Court judge named Robert Owen published a 328-page report on the 2006 death in London of Alexander Litvinenko, a former agent of Russias Federal Security Service, the F.S.B. Nine years after Litvinenko went bald and wasted away in a London hospital bed, from poisoning with a rare radioactive isotope, Owens report found that there was strong circumstantial evidence of Russian state responsibility and that the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, and the head of the F.S.B. likely sanctioned the murder.

title: At the Outsider Art Fair, the Creative Impulse Is in Its Raw Glory
description: Now in its 24th year, the fair features works by familiar names like Henry Darger as well as lesser-known artists.

title: Court Rejects a Bid to Block Coal Plant Regulations
description: In a significant victory for President Obama, a federal appeals panel on Thursday rejected an effort by 27 states and dozens of corporations and industry groups to block the administrations signature regulation on emissions from coal-fired power plants while a lawsuit moves through the courts.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: Bernie Sanders,Alexander Litvinenko, Flint
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

description: The titanosaur that clomped into the American Museum of Natural History last week has big footprints to fill, and not just those of the Barosaurus it booted.

description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

description: JPMorgan Chase paid Jamie Dimon, its chairman and chief executive, 35 percent more in 2015 than the previous years compensation package, which was only narrowly approved by shareholders.

title: With These Cards, Every Hands a Winner
description: PICK up a deck of cards. Shuffle, cut, deal. Now, take a look at your hand. It may be a winner or a loser. Thats up to chance. But it is a dead certainty that the visual spectacle will be dull. Diamonds, clubs, spades and hearts are the same from deck to deck, printed uniformly. The king, queen and jack wear more or less the same costume. Boring.

title: Laszlo Nemes Narrates a Scene From Son of Saul
description: Son of Saul begins with a long, out-of-focus shot. A man (Geza Rohrig) walks toward the camera until hes suddenly in sharp close-up. And just as suddenly, the camera is following him through a chaotic outdoor scene.

title: We Asked, You Answered: Your Favorite Blizzard Things
description: Tell us three things you look forward to when youre planning to stay inside and watch the snow fall.

title: Saudi Arabias Top Cleric Forbids Chess, but Players Maneuver
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Saudi Arabias top cleric has declared the playing of chess forbidden, calling it a waste of time and money that creates hatred between players.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Jan. 22-28
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: After Delay, Janet DiFiore Is Confirmed as New Yorks Chief Judge
description: ALBANY  The morning after a procedural hiccup left New Yorks highest judicial post vacant for an extra day, the nominee, Janet DiFiore, was confirmed by a full vote of the State Senate.

title: Republicans Say Government Mismanaged Health Care Co-ops
description: WASHINGTON  Republican senators charged Thursday that the Obama administration had missed warning signs of financial distress at nonprofit health insurance cooperatives that failed last year, but a top federal official denied that the government had been negligent in its supervision.

title: Why Donald Trump Keeps Lying About Unemployment
description: Donald Trump received four Pinocchios this week from fact checkers at the Washington Post who vetted his claim that the unemployment rate in the United States is really 23 percent  which would be about as bad as it was in the depth of Great Depression of the 1930s.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 22-28
description: The winter storm forecast for Saturday may affect whether events will be held. Readers should check online or by phone for possible cancellations.

title: Refracting Race Through the Comic Lens of Richard Pryor
description: Much of the art that interests me most is art thats made under pressure: social, emotional, intellectual, spiritual, political. Pressure of a kind different from that required to land a gallery or make a sale.

title: Spare Times for Children Listings for Jan. 22-28
description: Wave Hill, the Bronx garden, would like to introduce you to some neighbors. They may not be the friendliest New Yorkers, but theyre still good citizens. And they do like to hang out at night.

title: U.S. Awards $281 Million to New York Region for Hurricane Protection
description: Federal housing officials will award about $281 million to the New York region, including the states of Connecticut and New Jersey, to better protect communities from natural disasters like Hurricane Sandy.

title: Verbatim: Donald Trump Says He Is No Longer Worried About Ted Cruz
description: Donald J. Trump, speaking at a rally in Las Vegas while listing the results of polls showing him ahead of Senator Ted Cruz.

title: As The X-Files Returns, Do We Still Want to Believe?
description: IN 2002, after 202 episodes of government conspiracies, bright lights in the sky, black oil, creepy monsters and sexual tension, The X-Files said goodbye. On Sunday on Fox, the F.B.I. agents Fox Mulder (David Duchovny) and Dana Scully (Gillian Anderson) return for a six-part mini-series.

title: Review: Rabid Dogs, a Road Trip With French Robbers
description: The illuminated title frames, laden with symbols and cast in a ruby light, promise thrills. And the first 10 minutes of the French film Rabid Dogs deliver nonstop action  and carnage  in an urban plaza, a shopping mall and a warehouse.

title: Lasting Beauty, Even in Shards
description: There is still a divide in the contemporary art worlds recent embrace of ceramics and glass. You will find, for the most part, many traditional wares at the New York Ceramics and Glass Fair, now in its 17th incarnation. And yet, among 30 vendors, there is a great range of work here, from sophisticated haut-craft and modernist vessels to objects that will please the seeker of oddities. There are also a handful of lectures with juicy titles like Demolition Man: Peter Voulkos, 1950-1970 and Ming Goes Bling and the Slightly Satirical Aroma of Eucalyptus. Here are some highlights.

title: The New Cherries on Top of the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden
description: When the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden opened in 1988  the first partnership of its kind between a city parks department and a museum  the architecture critic Paul Goldberger wrote that few things were as desirable to integrate with cities as sculpture, and as difficult. But the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis pulled it off, he said, creating the finest new outdoor space in the country for displaying sculpture, and a link in a complex chain of urban events, not an isolated place unto itself.

title: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Jan. 23 Through 31
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Synchronicity Plays With Time and Love
description: Every so often in the science-fiction movie Synchronicity, Michael Ironside enters a scene and promisingly begins roughing it up, like a guy whos had enough of whatever nonsense is on tap. The combustible Mr. Ironside vaulted into movie immortality as the antagonist in Scanners, David Cronenbergs down-and-dirty, exploding-head anti-classic. Synchronicity, a low-budget misfire about time and love, could use some exploding heads, dialogue and ideas.

title: Why Is It So Difficult for Syrian Refugees to Get Into the U.S.?
description: Of the 4.5 million people who have fled the Syrian war, only 2,647 have been taken in by the United States.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, Jan. 23 Through Jan. 31
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A Chance to Dance for Minority Ballerinas
description: The lack of female African-American dancers in ballet companies is a subject that both frustrates and galvanizes Denise Saunders Thompson, the chairwoman and executive director of the International Association of Blacks in Dance, an organization thats been around for 25 years.  On Sunday, in conjunction with the associations annual conference in Denver, Ms. Thompson is holding auditions  for minority women seeking contracts with American companies  the groups first such event. Ballet Memphis, Pennsylvania Ballet, San Francisco Ballet and Washington Ballet, among others, are sending representatives. Training institutions, including the Pacific Northwest Ballet School and the School of American Ballet, will also attend.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, Jan. 23 Through 31
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Review: To Be Young, Gay and Muslim in Bed-Stuy
description: The endearing title characters of Jay Dockendorfs film Naz & Maalik are 18-year-old best friends who recently became lovers, living in Bedford-Stuyvesant, a Brooklyn neighborhood in the throes of gentrification. Naz (Kerwin Johnson Jr.) and Maalik (Curtiss Cook Jr.) are closeted and Muslim, and especially for Naz, the Islamic taboo against homosexuality weighs heavily.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, Jan. 23 Through Jan. 31
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Movie Review: Naz & Maalik
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews Naz & Maalik.

title: Movie Review: Synchronicity
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Synchronicity.

title: Review: Wide Awake Hearts and the ABCs of Infidelity
description: Hes your oldest friend, the woman says to her husband.

title: Flash Factory, a New Techno Music Club, Takes a Populist Approach
description: Like much of Manhattans creative class, dance music purists have long moved their parties to Brooklyn or beyond  even as electronic dance music, or E.D.M., has grown into a multibillion dollar industry, reviving some New York club culture from the 90s.

title: Break Dancer Finds Footing While Trying to Heal a Rift
description: In the heyday of Jonathan Diazs break-dancing career, the A line from West 59th to 125th Street and its captive audience of riders made for a surefire source of income.

title: Off the Court, Justin Gimelstobs Life Is Still at 100 M.P.H.
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  As the sun rose Thursday morning, Justin Gimelstob was relaxing the only way he knows how, by sifting through more than 300 combined unread email and text messages on his smartphone while burning 857 calories riding a stationary bicycle for an hour.

title: Review: Monster Hunt Features a Baby Beast on the Run With Its Surrogate Parents
With The Seasons, Ben Wendel Redefines the Musical Encounter
description: The Seasons, a vividly imagined collection of duets by the saxophonist and bassoonist Ben Wendel, was one of the standout jazz records of 2015. But it was never released in album form, and took the entire year to hear in full.

title: A Former Mexican Governor Is Arrested, but Not by His Own Country
description: MEXICO CITY  The anticorruption police swooped in on Humberto Moreira, a former Mexican governor notorious for multiplying his states debt by 100 times in six years. The accusations were severe: among them, money laundering and misuse of public funds.

title: Georgia Police Officer Indicted for Murder of Unarmed Black Man
description: DECATUR, Ga.  A white police officer was indicted here Thursday on six counts, including felony murder, in the fatal shooting last year of an unarmed black man who was naked and described as acting in an erratic manner.

title: In Philadelphia, Batteries on Transit System Power More Than Just the Trains
description: Along Philadelphias busy Market-Frankford subway line, the trains behave like those of any transit system, slowing to halt at the platforms and picking up passengers.

title: Pedicab Operators See Loss of Livelihood in de Blasios Central Park Plan
description: If someone were going to lose in Mayor Bill de Blasios horse carriage deal, pedicab drivers were an easy mark.

title: Review: Mojave Looks at the Corrosive Effects of Hollywood
description: The dyspeptic amusement Mojave opens with a snapshot of Hollywood narcissism at its most unconscious. Thomas (Garrett Hedlund), a Los Angeles demigod with artfully tousled hair and the morals of, well, just wait, is talking into a camera as if for a celebrity interview. Ive been famous one way or another since I was 19, he says, shrugging the words off with the indifference that only years of stardom can bring. From his indolent delivery to his slouch (he cant bother to sit up), he comes off as supremely self-absorbed. Its all about him.

title: Staging Apartments: Before and After
description: See how apartments were professionally made over to attract bids.

title: Review: In All Mistakes Buried, an Addict Battles to Retrieve a Precious Necklace
description: All Mistakes Buried opens by following Sonny (Sam Trammell of True Blood), a once-respectable businessman now reduced to an addicts existence, on his busy schedule. He sleeps off the night before in a skanky motel, drinks heavily and smokes dope just to steady his nerves, hustles to his dealer for some crack and dimly remembers that theres something he needs to do.

title: Funds Roll In for Start-Up Harnessing Bitcoin Tech
description: A well-known former JPMorgan Chase executive, Blythe Masters, has raised $52 million from several big banks for a start-up built on the technology underlying the Bitcoin virtual currency.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Cable Acquisitions by Charter Communications Face Rising Opposition
description: Comcasts failed $45 billion merger with Time Warner Cable collapsed last year under pressure from regulators, who found that the combined company would have had both the power and incentive to inhibit the future of streaming video.

title: Edmonde Charles-Roux, Novelist and Editor of French Vogue, Dies at 95
description: Edmonde Charles-Roux, a longtime editor of French Vogue and the author of the novel To Forget Palermo, winner of the Prix Goncourt, Frances biggest literary prize, in 1966, died on Wednesday in Marseille. She was 95.

title: Raid on Militant Hide-Out Near Egypts Pyramids Ends in Deadly Blast
description: CAIRO  A large explosion in an apartment building near the Pyramids killed at least nine people on Thursday evening, including at least three police officers, during what the authorities said was a security raid on a suspected militant hide-out.

title: By Finding a New Home for Carriage Horses, Solving a Problem That Doesnt Exist
description: Friday is Day 751 of the Mayor Bill de Blasio era, and the City Council is prepared to take up a matter that he said would be dealt with on Day 1: driving the horse-carriage industry from the streets of Manhattan.

title: Twenty20, a Faster Variant of Cricket, Gets Players to Stay Home
description: Unlike most sports, cricket traditionally has revolved around international play, regarded as more prestigious and lucrative than domestic competition. It is not just glamour in which domestic play lags; it is often subsidized by the money received from international play, too.

title: U.N. Finds South Sudan Increasingly in Turmoil
description: GENEVA  The murderous struggle between the government and opposition forces in South Sudan has already resulted in widespread atrocities and left thousands of people on the brink of starvation, yet in the past year, both sides intensified and spread the conflict, the United Nations said Thursday.

title: This Weeks Movies | Jan. 22, 2016
description: The New York Times film critics review Naz & Maalik, Synchronicity and Prescription Thugs.

title: Review: In Ip Man 3, Donnie Yen Brawls With Mike Tyson and Others
description: In Bruce Lees unfinished film Game of Death, there is a classic bout between Lee and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar. Ip Man 3, the latest installment in a series  starring Donnie Yen as Lees fabled instructor, offers similar stunt casting, in a fight between Mr. Yen and the former pro boxer Mike Tyson, who plays a gang boss. As rewarding as the matchup is  pile-driver force meeting the graceful kung fu style wing chun  it is not the movies climax, and ends in a stalemate.

title: Taliban Attack Shows Limits of Pakistans Military Crackdown
description: CAIRO  Only a few months ago, Pakistans military leaders openly boasted they had the Taliban on the run. A punishing, yearlong offensive had ousted the insurgents from their most prized tribal sanctuary. The movements various factions were riven by violent rivalries, and attacks on Pakistans towns and cities had largely ceased.

title: Aroldis Chapman, the Yankees New Closer, Avoids Charges, but May Face Discipline
description: Aroldis Chapman will not face criminal charges that were brought against him by the state attorney in Broward County, Fla., but he could be disciplined by Major League Baseball, and the punishment could include a suspension.

title: Review: The Aliens Are Coming! The Aliens Are Coming!
description: Adapted from Rick Yanceys young adult novel, the glossy if muddled The 5th Wave blends the alien overlord airships of Independence Day, the natural disaster effects of The Day After Tomorrow and the auto-wreck-strewn highways of Zombieland with a dusting of Invasion of the Body Snatchers.

title: Russia and U.S., While Pushing for Peace Talks, Jockey for Position in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Russian military is expanding its footprint in Syria, setting up operations at an airfield in a northeastern, mostly Kurdish province across the country from its main coastal base. In an adjacent province, locals say the United States is intensifying its aid to Kurdish militias, even taking over a small agricultural airport; Pentagon officials denied this. And some Syrian fighters say Russia has reached out to Sunni tribes, offering to help them fight the Islamic State extremist group in the east after similar American efforts failed.

title: Lou Michaels, All-Purpose Player, Dies at 80; Missed Kicks in 69 Super Bowl
description: Lou Michaels, a former All-American, all-purpose football player whose two missed field goals for the Baltimore Colts helped the New York Jets win the Super Bowl in 1969 in a historic upset, died on Tuesday at his home in Swoyersville, Pa. He was 80.

title: Courses for a New Year
description: Only a few weeks into the new year and gyms across the city are thinning out, Powerball mania has spoiled prudent financial plans and the Misers attempt at more bookish pursuits has seen Crime and Punishment replaced by Making a Murderer.

title: McConnell Clears Path for Debate on Giving Obama Broad Powers to Combat ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and majority leader, has set the stage for debate on a bill that would give President Obama broad authority to use military force against the Islamic State.

title: Mr. Putin and the Poisonous London Tea Party
description: President Vladimir Putins deserved reputation as an autocrat willing to flirt with lawlessness in his global ventures has taken on a startling new aspect, with a finding by British authorities that he probably approved the poisoning of a former Russian spy and defector in London in 2006.

title: A Question of Environmental Racism in Flint
description: If Flint were rich and mostly white, would Michigans state government have responded more quickly and aggressively to complaints about its lead-polluted water?

title: New York City Marathon Challenged Over Lottery
description: Two Utah men claimed in a lawsuit filed Thursday that the annual drawing by the New York Marathon to qualify to enter the race constitutes an illegal lottery.

title: David Brock, Ally of Hillary Clinton, Skewers New Bernie Sanders Ad
description: The race between Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Hillary Clinton ramped up Thursday with a top Clinton ally criticizing a new Sanders ad as focused too much on white Americans.

title: Yemen: Airstrikes Kill 18, Including a Hospital Worker
description: Multiple airstrikes on a town in northern Yemen on Thursday killed at least 18 people, including civilian rescuers and an ambulance driver working at a hospital supported by Doctors Without Borders, according to a statement by the group and the hospital director. At least three hospitals supported by Doctors Without Borders have been destroyed or damaged since October in the war between Houthi rebels and government forces backed by Saudi Arabia. Muhammed Hajr, the director of the Jumhuriya Hospital in Saada Province, said that the ambulance had just picked up people wounded in an airstrike in the Dhayan district when another airstrike destroyed the ambulance, killing everyone inside. Other airstrikes killed at least 12 people who arrived to help, Mr. Hajr said.

title: At 22, Rangers Forward Is Already Having a Signature Season
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  J. T. Miller may be only 22, but he has already had a wealth of experience with the Rangers, who made him a first-round draft pick in 2011.

title: Flint Fallout: A Resignation, a Hearing and U.S. Aid
description: CHICAGO  Fallout from the drinking water crisis in Flint, Mich., spread Thursday as a high-ranking Environmental Protection Agency official resigned and the agencys chief administrator said it would take over monitoring of Flints water supply for lead contamination.

title: Postwar German Nickname
description: Administrivial New Feature Alert! Were trying something new  a separate, weekly place to gather and discuss the A Little Variety puzzles (which includes the Spelling Bee) that publish online on Thursdays and appear in the Sunday Magazine. If there seems to be enough interest and discussion, this will become a permanent part of the Wordplay rotation. Starting Saturday, January 23, a post for these puzzles will appear at 9:00 a.m. Eastern.

title: Review: The Glory of the World, About Thomas Merton
description: Whose birthday is this, anyway? Thomas Mertons? Or a gay circuit-party promoters?

title: Judge in Bill Cosby Case Dismisses Pittsburgh Womans Defamation Suit
description: Statements made by Bill Cosby, his wife and his lawyer at the time to counter accusations that he had sexually assaulted women were not defamatory, a federal judge ruled Thursday as he dismissed a Pittsburgh womans defamation lawsuit against the entertainer.

title: Bronx Priest Suspended in Abuse Case
description: A Roman Catholic priest also active in Bronx politics has been suspended from priestly duties because of allegations that he sexually abused minors three decades ago, church officials said on Thursday.

title: Hillary Clinton, With Help From Demi Lovato, Treads on Bernie Sanders Turf in Iowa
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa  Hillary Clinton campaigned with confidence in Bernie Sanders country on Thursday night, taking a couple of gentle jabs at her political rival during a rally with the singer Demi Lovato at the University of Iowa in this liberal hotbed.

title: Mississippi Republicans Face Hard Tax Cut Choices
description: ATLANTA  Blaine Eaton II, the Mississippi state representative who won a tie election by pulling a long green straw in a state-sanctioned ceremony  only to be removed from office by the Republican-controlled House  was back on his farm in Taylorsville on Thursday, feeding his cows and licking his wounds.

title: Family Recalls Concerns After Fatal Stabbing of Teenager
description: A bloody handprint stained the sidewalk on Lorimer Street in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, just across from Sternberg Park, where Jovani Cubias sometimes played basketball, his family said, outclassing his friends on the court as he grew lankier. Other red blotches marked the spot where Jovani, 17, was fatally stabbed on Wednesday afternoon. He was attacked, the police said, following an argument with another male.

title: Government to Reveal Colleges With Title IX Waivers
description: The Department of Education said on Wednesday that it would create a searchable database that reveals the names of colleges and universities that have received exemptions on religious grounds from federal civil rights protections.

title: Realization at Ziegfeld Theater: Only Name Is Constant
description: The Ziegfeld Theater opened 46 years ago with Marooned. It is closing marooned, though deserted is probably a better word. Not even Star Wars: The Force Awakens, which has packed movie theaters nationwide since it opened last month, drew much of a crowd at the Ziegfeld on Wednesday night.

title: Alabama: Judge Censured for Coercing Blood Donors
description: A Circuit Court judge was censured Thursday after he was accused last year of threatening defendants with jail time if they did not pay fines or participate in a blood drive. Judge Marvin Wiggins, whose jurisdiction includes five impoverished counties, accepted the punishment as part of a settlement with the State Judicial Inquiry Commission. More than 40 defendants donated blood after Judge Wiggins told them, Consider that as a discount rather than putting you in jail, if you do not have any money. The judges supporters said he had chosen his words poorly and that he did not intend to jail anyone, but critics like the state commission said his comments were so coercive as to be reprehensible and inexcusable.

title: Death of New York Officer Imperils Gun Case in Which He Was Crucial Witness
description: When a police officer dies in the line of duty, there is an often-unseen consequence: The cases the officer has pending before the courts are suddenly in jeopardy.

title: New Yorks Week in Pictures: Jan. 22
description: Photographs from the past week in New York and the region include the site of the New York City Farm Colony on Staten Island and mourners at Columbia University.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | unprepossessing
description: unprepossessing  \n-pri-p-zes-iN also -ses\  adjective

title: Forrest McDonald, Historian Who Punctured Liberal Notions, Dies at 89
description: Forrest McDonald, a presidential and constitutional scholar who challenged liberal shibboleths about early American history and lionized the founding fathers as uniquely intellectual, died on Tuesday in Tuscaloosa, Ala. He was 89.

title: Faint Praise for Bernie Sanders From Bill Clinton: His Slogans Are Easier to Say
description: LAS VEGAS  The last time a Hillary Clinton presidential campaign ran into trouble  in 2008, when she ran and ultimately lost to Barack Obama  she turned to Bill Clinton, her husband and the former president, as a campaign surrogate. And with polls suggesting Mrs. Clinton is struggling again, this time against Bernie Sanders, Mr. Clinton has returned to the place he likes best: the campaign trail.

title: What to Watch Friday
description: Feeling angsty? Check out Mad Dogs and breathe a sigh of relief that your week probably wasnt as bad as the one these guys are having. Meanwhile, Anna Netrebko makes a Met Opera debut. And the Marvel gang is back.

title: 1905: Bloody Sunday in Russia
description: On Jan. 22, 1905, soldiers of the Imperial Guard in St. Petersburg, Russia, fired upon demonstrators as they marched to the Winter Palace to petition Czar Nicholas II.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Theres a feedback between financial markets and the economy. You might think markets are irrational, but even if they are, that spills over into the real economy.

title: Corrections: January 22, 2016
description: SPORTS

title: Donald Trump Pushes Back Against Criticism by National Review
description: Donald J. Trump called an impromptu news conference on Thursday night in Nevada to criticize National Review, the conservative magazine that published a series of essays denouncing his candidacy.

title: Magic and Mystery on So Paulos Streets
description: Victor Dragonettis street scenes are colorful, and complex, with an air of mystery that evokes different responses from viewers.

title: Stance on Migrants Leaves Merkel Isolated at Home and in Europe
description: BERLIN  Dozens of lawmakers from her own conservative party signed open letters against her this week. A nationalist right-wing party is gaining in strength. Speculation, building since the fall, now runs rife that she should even be replaced. On Sunday, the top circulation Bild Zeitung headlined an eight-page spread on her political troubles: Is Merkel Still the Right One?

title: Magic and Mystery on So Paulos Streets
description: If you ever get cynical about photography, go talk to Victor Dragonetti. O.K., just going to where he lives  So Paulo  will lift anyones spirits given the weather in the Northeast. But this young photographers enthusiasm about photography is not just heartwarming, but also infectious. His smile is enough to remind you of the moment when you realized that taking pictures was magical.

title: Justin Trudeau Carries His Look to Canada Image to Davos
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The Davos man who attends the World Economic Forum here each year is a member of the global elite  say, a banker or a politician  whose status is reinforced by an exclusive white badge that gives him access to V.I.P. lounges away from the masses at this alpine resort.

title: Still Recovering From Hurricane Sandy
description: On the night of Oct. 29, 2012, Linda Vergara looked out the front door of her home in Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn, and thought: This is not good. We better get out of here. Hurricane Sandy had arrived a few hours earlier, and Ms. Vergara, like thousands of New Yorkers, assumed she was in a safe zone and would not need to evacuate. Then the surge came. By the time she got her coat on and headed out to the street, the water was up to her waist. She saw cars and other debris floating around and joined some of her neighbors as they struggled to reach higher ground.

title: Depraved Indifference Toward Flint
description: The 274 pages of emails released under pressure on Wednesday by Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan show a cynical and callous indifference to the plight of the mostly black, poverty-stricken residents of Flint, who have gone for more than a year with poisoned tap water that is unsafe to drink or bathe in. There is little doubt that an affluent, predominantly white community  say Grosse Pointe or Bloomfield Hills  would never face such a public health catastrophe, and if it had, the state government would have rushed in to help.

title: How Change Happens
description: There are still quite a few pundits determined to pretend that Americas two great parties are symmetric  equally unwilling to face reality, equally pushed into extreme positions by special interests and rabid partisans. Its nonsense, of course. Planned Parenthood isnt the same thing as the Koch brothers, nor is Bernie Sanders the moral equivalent of Ted Cruz. And theres no Democratic counterpart whatsoever to Donald Trump.

title: The Eight-Second Attention Span
description: This weekend, Im going to the Mojave Desert, deep into an arid wilderness of a half-million acres, for some stargazing, bouldering and January sunshine on my public lands. I wont be out of contact. I checked. If Sarah Palin says something stupid on Donald Trumps behalf  scratch that. When Sarah Palin says something stupid on Donald Trumps behalf, Ill get her speaking-in-tongues buffoonery in real time, along with the rest of the nation.

title: The Anxieties of Impotence
description: In 1936 George Orwell wrote a magnificent essay called Shooting an Elephant. Orwell had been working as a British police officer in Burma, enforcing colonial rule. An elephant had gone must, broken its chains, trampled some homes and killed a man.

title: When Will the Candidates Start Talking About the Economy?
description: SIDELINED by homeland security, foreign policy and immigration, the economy is about to become a major topic in the race for the White House. Since the start of the year we have seen precipitous drops in the stock market and oil prices, combined with the threat that a slowing global economy may drag the United States down with it.

title: Sanders Makes a Rare Pitch: More Taxes for More Government
description: Senator Bernie Sanderss health care plan is advancing a notion that has long been out of fashion in American politics: that the federal government should provide a new, expensive service to most Americans, and that it should levy significantly higher taxes on most Americans to provide that service.

title: Making Peace With Violence: Camus in Algeria
description: Sixty years ago today, Albert Camus gave the speech of his life. It was a speech, in fact, that nearly cost him his life, as well as one that failed in its goal of saving the lives of countless civilians, Arabs and French alike, caught in the vise of terrorism employed by both sides in Algerias war of independence. The reasoning behind the speech, as well as the reasons Camus gave it, cast important light on the war on terror now being fought in the West.

title: Japan Economy Minister Fights Accusations of Selling Favors
description: HONG KONG  The Japanese economy minister, Akira Amari, a high-profile supporter of Prime Minister Shinzo Abes policies on trade and the economy, is fighting potentially damaging accusations that he received funds from a construction company in return for political favors.

title: Global Markets Continue to Rally as Investors Seek Bargains
description: HONG KONG  Surging Japanese shares led a strong rebound in markets across Asia on Friday, and Europe had its second consecutive day of gains, as investors buffeted by days of volatility saw opportunity amid the recent sell-offs.

title: Philips Calls Off Sale of Controlling Stake in LED Business
description: LONDON  Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, said on Friday that it had terminated an agreement to sell a controlling stake in its automotive and LED components business because of regulatory concerns raised in the United States.

title: News Qs | How the N.B.A. 3-Point Shot Went From Gimmick to Game Changer
description: The following lesson activities are based on the article How the N.B.A. 3-Point Shot Went From Gimmick to Game Changer.

title: This Should Be Written in the Present Tense, by Helle Helle
description: For the last 20 years, Helle Helles novels and short stories have made her a star in her native Denmark, where she regularly receives awards and acclaim. Denmark is also where, according to her biography, Helle lives in a forest. What a fittingly magical dwelling for Helle, who  judging from her first novel to be translated into English, This Should Be Written in the Present Tense  has enchanting gifts as a storyteller.

title: Liberty and Coercion, by Gary Gerstle
description: Between 1913 and 1920, Americans amended the federal Constitution four times. Each amendment solidified a major reform: the direct election of senators, the first federal income tax, votes for women, the banning of alcohol nationwide. Taken together, they reflected the progressive view that the Constitution was a living document, able to be adapted to and updated for the nations needs. A century ago, most Americans seemed to agree that new circumstances required new tools, and that the federal government would have a key role to play in meeting the challenges of the modern age.

title: The Art of Home Staging
description: Like many sellers, Fran Sarro and David Waite were initially reluctant to stage their apartment.

title: From the Highway to the Great White Way
description: A rat abandoned on the West Side Highway last summer reaches the bright lights of Broadway.

title: Sheldon Silvers Lawyers Seek Acquittal or Retrial in Corruption Case
description: Lawyers for Sheldon Silver, the former New York State Assembly speaker convicted of federal corruption charges, asked a judge on Thursday to acquit their client or grant him a new trial, arguing that no rational juror could find that the charges had been proved beyond a reasonable doubt.

title: Student Question | Should Colleges Find a Better Way to Admit Students?
description: Concern has been growing about how the current admissions process at the nations most selective colleges warps the values of students, promotes a competitive frenzy and encourages an unhealthy piling on of Advanced Placement classes and extracurricular activities. Should colleges rethink their emphasis on applicants grade point averages, SAT and ACT scores, A.P. course loads and extracurricular participation?

title: Fugitive in Bronx Slasher Case Leaves a Trail of Fear and Taunts
description: The day after a man accused in a slashing episode jumped bail during his trial, the Bronx prosecutor handling the case was browsing the mans Instagram page when he came upon the stately, bearded face of Don Juancho Nieto Melndez, a 19th-century Venezuelan spirits connoisseur.

title: Older Drivers Hit the Road for Uber and Lyft
description: When Carol Sue Johnson, 73, wheels her silver Mazda S.U.V. out of her driveway in suburban Minneapolis, she doesnt know how much money she will make driving for the ride-hailing service Uber, but shes sure she will have an adventure.

title: Chris Christie and His Ambitions: A New Jersey Vanishing Act
description: Gov. Chris Christies return to New Jersey was swift and efficient: He flew to his home state on Monday night after a campaign trip to Iowa. The next day, he sliced through a towering pile of legislation awaiting his signature, approving 93 bills and blocking 62 others from becoming law.

title: A G.O.P. Majority in New Hampshire Pipes Up: Were Not for Donald Trump
description: BROOKLINE, N.H.  Jeanne Cleveland, a retired teacher, pursed her lips sourly at the mention of his name and tried to summarize her distaste in diplomatic terms.

title: A Late Love
description: Sonny and Cher costumes for a 1970s throwback party helped Sandy Jacobson and Paul Fischer move beyond the sadness.

title: Rose the Rat on Broadway
description: Rose, one of a group of white rats abandoned near the West Side Highway, was adopted by an animal trainer and has become an actor in a hit show.

title: From the Ashes of Loss, Love Grows
description: Sandy Jacobson calls it that terrible year, measured in doctors visits, chemotherapy treatments and funerals. It began in 2011.

title: Enter Rose, a Broadway Rat With a Past
description: This is the story of 500 rats on the West Side Highway and one who ventured east.

title: The Past, by Tessa Hadley
description: Pity poor Roland Crane, one of the central characters in Tessa Hadleys most recent novel, The Past. Like other males who populate Hadleys fiction, Roland grew up in a family of vivid, sexually flamboyant women who considered him slightly ridiculous. Today, however, he is a public intellectual, with a gratifying position writing about film for the national newspapers. When he shows up for a summer holiday with his three grown sisters, driving a vintage Jaguar and wearing a white linen suit, accompanied by his glamorous new wife and his lovely 16-year-old daughter by a previous marriage, you might expect Roland to have earned a little domestic peace and adulation. But no. Not only do his sisters, who could remember him in short trousers, when his glasses were mended with sticking plaster, still consider him a buttoned-up puritan, but his sway over his wife and daughter is about to be assailed from the most unexpected quarters. The point about the past, in Hadleys fiction, is that its always there to trip you up. Your parents (whether dead or alive), your siblings (whether successful or resentfully needy) will inevitably threaten to suck you back into that sticky-sweet limbo of childhood myth and trauma.

title: Snowstorm Bears Down on the East Coast
description: More than two feet of snow could hit the Washington region starting Friday. The storm is moving north, with a foot or more of snow expected in New York.

title: Letters: Ebans Eloquence
description: To the Editor:

title: When Alcohol Intrudes in the Workplace
description: I work at a nonprofit with fewer than 10 employees, where we all need to pull our weight. Recently, there have been several instances of a particular colleague getting so drunk on weeknights that he cant make it to work until the following afternoon, if at all. I know that he is hung over, not sick, because he has admitted it in emails canceling meetings with me.

title: North Korea Says Its Holding U.S. Student for Hostile Act
description: HONG KONG  North Korean state news media said Friday that a university student from the United States who had entered the country as a tourist was being held for a hostile act.

title: Hotel and Tour News: Watergate Makeover; Opera in Germany
description: A NEW LOOK  AND MENUS  AT THE WATERGATE HOTEL

title: Ask Well: The 10-20-30 Workout for Swimmers
description: Question:

title: Your Friday Briefing: Blizzard, Flint, New England Patriots
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Shabab Stage Deadly Attack on Beachfront Restaurant in Mogadishu
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  At least 14 civilians were killed and dozens were wounded after Islamist militants struck a popular beachside restaurant Thursday night in Somalias capital that had become a symbol of the citys struggling renaissance, officials said Friday.

title: Morning Agenda: Jamie Dimons Pay Rises to $27 Million
description: JAMIE DIMONS PAY RISES TO $27 MILLION | JPMorgan Chase paid Jamie Dimon, its chairman and chief executive, 35 percent more in 2015 than the year before,Liz Moyer reports in DealBook.

title: New York Today: Bracing for a Blizzard
description: Updated at 9:55 a.m.

title: For Prairie Voles, a Furry Shoulder to Cry On
description: Prairie voles console one another when distressed, researchers have found.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Foods for Him, Foods for Her and Living to 100
description: Take the Quiz

title: Storm Could Shutter Washington but Should Leave Campaign Trail Untouched
description: Washington is bracing for a potential shutdown this weekend, and, this time, it wont be Senator Ted Cruz of Texas fault.

title: 1996 | In Gamble, Newspapers Push Into On-Line Publishing
description: The Web, Peter H. Lewis explained to readers of The New York Times on Jan. 18, 1995, allows even computer novices to easily search the global Internet network for text, pictures  and, in some cases, sounds  and analysts say it is rapidly emerging as the point-and-click prototype for the information superhighway.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start your day.

title: The Dogs of Littlefield, by Suzanne Berne
description: Leafy, prosperous Littlefield sounds too good to be true. An idyllic Boston suburb, it ranks No.6 on The Wall Street Journals list of the 20 Best Places to Live in America. Band concerts, well-tended Victorian houses, enlightened citizens  what could go wrong?

title: Brief Bios
description: RONALD REAGANBy Jacob Weisberg185 pp. Times Books, $25.

title: Dozens of Migrants Drown as European Refugee Crisis Continues
description: LONDON  More than 40 people  including 17 children  died when two wooden boats full of migrants trying to reach Greece sank early Friday morning, as a continued flow of asylum seekers, even in dangerous winter weather, put new pressure on European leaders to address a crisis that seems likely to intensify again come spring.

title: Vietnams Sacred Turtle Dies at an Awkward, Some Say Ominous, Time
description: HANOI, Vietnam  A giant turtle, a mythic symbol of Vietnamese independence and longevity that had quietly paddled around Hanois central lake for decades  some say centuries  is dead, official state news media has reported.

title: The Sleep Garden, by Jim Krusoe
description: Jim Krusoes sixth novel, The Sleep Garden, is a labyrinth of different narratives. Or, to be exact, a burrow  the Burrow, as Krusoe calls the surreal underground apartment building where his five central characters dwell (part reality show setup, part Platos cave, part grave) in a state of stasis and frustrated ambition. Their aspirations  for sex, love, money, celebrity  are familiar, though their milieu is not: the claustrophobic Burrow, filled with mirrors that multiply the dark.

title: Q. and A.: Shawna Yang Ryan on the 1947 Incident That Shaped Taiwans Identity
description: BEIJING  In Green Island, the novelist Shawna Yang Ryan tells the story of how the Tsais, a Taiwanese family, survive the February 28 Incident of 1947 and precariously navigate the decades that follow as Chiang Kai-sheks Kuomintang, or Nationalist Party, rules the island under martial law.

title: The 1.10.16 Issue
description: RE:DUPONT

title: How to Get Squirrels Out of the Attic
description: The first thing youll notice is the noise, says David Seerveld, a wildlife-removal specialist in Orlando, Fla. If you hear daytime scratching, you probably have squirrels; most other rodent intruders are nocturnal. According to Seerveld, attic squirrels are the most common nuisance-wildlife problem. They can bite through plastic water pipes and cause leaks; gnaw at electrical wires and spark fires; and at times even chomp through the ceiling until they fall, panicked, into living quarters.

title: Transmission
description: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.

title: Paperback Row
description: TENNESSEE WILLIAMS: Mad Pilgrimage of the Flesh, by John Lahr. (Norton, $19.95.) This deeply researched biography opens at the 1945 Broadway premiere of The Glass Menagerie, the work that heralded an era of critical acclaim for Williams (1911-83). In Lahrs telling, Williams was an artist who flourished in spite of repression, a process that our reviewer, Blake Bailey, saw as the triumph of art over life  the alchemy whereby a miserable childhood, and the enduring alienation that followed, were made into something sublime.

title: Stamped for Posterity
description: This week, John Sutherland reviews the letters of Iris Murdoch. Publishing such collections has become a routine step in completing an authors legacy. In an email interview, Sutherland said the poet Alexander Pope, who published a book of his letters in 1737, was one of the first writers to realize that his correspondence would monumentalize his reputation for posterity.

title: The Tourist
description: A few weeks ago, while visiting my parents in Lucknow, India, I decided to go out and take pictures of the sights in the city. I lived there for the first 30 years of my life and never bothered to photograph these places, but now that I live in the States, I missed my home. In Lucknow, famous for its politeness, poetry, perfume and embroidery, there are many interesting buildings, built by both Mughal and British rulers. So I set out, strolling through a historic part of town with an SLR camera hanging from my neck, looking just like a tourist.

title: Salonen Makes Clear He Wont Lead New York Philharmonic
description: Esa-Pekka Salonen, the innovative Finnish conductor who is the composer in residence at the New York Philharmonic, will not be the orchestras next music director, disappointing some fans and a number of prominent critics who had favored him for the post.

title: In Fast Transition, Maryland Excels Under New Rules
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  Mark Turgeon, the mens basketball coach at Maryland, casually dribbled a ball between his legs during the Terrapins practice Monday at Xfinity Center. The team spent several minutes on a transition drill during which the shot clock was set to a parsimonious 20 seconds.

title: What Pegi Vail Knows About Backpackers
description: Pegi Vail, 53, an anthropologist and the associate director of the Center for Media, Culture and History at New York University, studies backpacker subculture and the impact of travel on communities and on biodiversity. Her documentary, Gringo Trails, has been shown at dozens of festivals and in more than 20 countries since 2014, and recently was released on DVD (it is also available on iTunes and Amazon Video). Here are edited excerpts from an interview with her.

title: A San Francisco Super Bowl Experience, With or Without a Ticket
description: Attending the Super Bowl in person is a bucket-list item for sports fans that seems to get more out of reach every year.

title: Editors Choice
description: CITY OF THORNS: Nine Lives in the Worlds Largest Refugee Camp, by Ben Rawlence. (Picador, $26.) The lives of forcibly displaced people the world over are illuminated in this disturbing portrait of a huge refugee camp in Kenya.

title: Jonathan Anderson for Loewe: A Purist Kind of Thing
description: PARIS  Jonathan Anderson, a.k.a. J. W. Anderson, the reigning British designer of the year for both womens wear and mens wear, is one busy guy.

title: Keeping Dr. Paul Kalanithis Voice Alive
description: On March 9, 2015, two years after learning he had metastatic lung cancer, Dr. Paul Kalanithi, 37, a neurosurgeon at Stanford University, died. He left behind his wife, Dr. Lucy Kalanithi, their 8-month-old daughter, Cady, and a file on his computer labeled Kalanithi-Ms-20Feb.docx. His wife took that document, shepherded its contents to publication, and the resulting book, When Breath Becomes Air, became an instant best-seller this month. Dr. Kalanithi, 36, is a general internist at Stanford, where she helps lead efforts to improve the quality and efficiency of care. She recently folded herself into a leather armchair in her home in the San Francisco Bay Area, the same spot where her husband sat while he wrote, and talked about her own experience  as a young widow in grief, as her husbands literary stand-in, and as a physician who witnessed at intensely personal range the end to an extraordinary mans life. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.

title: On the Edge, by Rafael Chirbes
description: On the Edge is not a book you want to read in fits and starts. It is an anti-tweet, a brick of dense prose, that 70-year-old uncle who corners you at a holiday party, grabs you by the lapels and demands you hear him out. Your eyes sometimes glaze over, and you occasionally have to wipe a fleck of whitish spit off your face, but once you give yourself over to his story, you find there are plenty of rewards.

title: Russell Kirk: American Conservative, by Bradley J. Birzer
description: Im so happy to find that youre little, too! the political philosopher Leo Strauss said when he first met Russell Kirk in Chicago in the mid-1950s. From your books, I had feared that you might be a great, tall, fierce man. Kirk can still seem great and fierce. It was his book The Conservative Mind (1953) that first used the word conservative to classify various currents of antiprogressive dissidence that ran from the French Revolution to the 20th-century heyday of social democracy. Kirks book was an event. After a recommendation from Whittaker Chambers, Time magazine devoted the entire book review section to it. And Kirk had other gifts. He was a capable writer of ghost and fantasy novels. He founded and edited two prestigious journals. Not just Strauss and Chambers but also T.S. Eliot and Ray Bradbury esteemed him. In 1955, Flannery OConnor, scarcely able to walk, traveled 340 miles in hopes of seeing him lecture in Tennessee.

title: Junya Watanabe: Fall 2016
description: The latest designs from Junya Watanabe.

title: Jason Rezaian Travels to U.S. on Washington Post Owners Plane
description: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post reporter who was among the American citizens freed by Iran last weekend in a prisoner deal, left an American military hospital in Germany on Friday bound for the United States, accompanied by his wife and mother aboard his bosss personal jetliner.

title: Under No Certain Search Terms
description: When youre writing a book based on archival research and you have two children who come home from school at 3, no matter how much you love libraries, you become grateful for Google. For three years, I sat down most mornings at my dining room table in my slippers and read newspapers printed in the 1870s. No need to travel to distant archives, or spend fruitless hours turning the wrong pages. I could open a browser, punch in a range of dates and a few search terms, and within seconds have a presorted queue of articles, every one of which was relevant. I could feel confident that when it came to coverage of, lets say, an embassy of Japanese statesmen arriving in San Francisco in 1872, I hadnt missed a single mention. I blessed the librarians who had digitized their holdings, and got to work.

title: Donald Trumps War With Ted Cruz Turns to the Airwaves
description: The waning alliance of convenience between Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas collapsed on Friday in a burst of negative advertisements and counterattacks, as Mr. Trump moved to try to derail Mr. Cruzs chances of winning the Iowa caucuses in 10 days.

title: G.E. Reports Strong Quarterly Profit but Sales Are Below Forecasts
description: Depressed oil prices, financial market worries and sluggish global growth threaten the industrial sector. But General Electric, the nations largest industrial company, seems to be weathering the challenges so far. The company on Friday reported solid fourth-quarter profit and delivered a cautiously optimistic outlook for 2016.

title: As Sharapova Reaches Milestone, Group of Young Russians Rises
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Maria Sharapova has been winning professional tennis matches for half her life, which makes her feel as if time is a passing shot whizzing by her. She was 14 years old when she won her first International Tennis Federation match, and she followed that less than a month later with her first WTA Tour victory.

title: Donald Trump and the Rivers of Blood
description: LONDON  Until recently, Donald J. Trump was best known in Britain for The Apprentice television series, the Miss Universe contest and a controversial golf course development in Scotland. And most Britons would probably have viewed his decision to enter the presidential race with no more than mild envy: Why cant British elections be as much fun as American ones?

title: Two Films, One Designer: The Costumes of Carol and Cinderella
description: With 12 Oscar nominations for costume design and three wins, Sandy Powell, is no stranger to awards season. This year is no exception as she finds herself in the remarkable position of getting nods for two films, Carol and Cinderella.

title: In the Martyrs Remake, French Punishment Is Done American Style
description: When horror fans dare horror rookies to watch a movie, its usually a classic frightfest like The Exorcist or a more recent white-knuckler like It Follows. When horror fans dare other horror fans to watch a movie, its Martyrs.

title: A Drug to Cure Fear
description: WHO among us hasnt wanted to let go of anxiety or forget about fear? Phobias, panic attacks and disorders like post-traumatic stress are extremely common: 29 percent of American adults will suffer from anxiety at some point in their lives.

title: Clinton-Sanders Battle in Iowa May Be Decided by OMalley Supporters
description: DES MOINES  Martin OMalley has rarely broken above 5 percent in Iowa polls, but on caucus night he could be the most popular person in the room  or, rather, his supporters will be, as activists for Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders desperately try to scoop them up.

title: Operation Thunderbolt, by Saul David
description: On June 27, 1976, an Air France plane took off from Ben-Gurion International Airport in Lod, Israel, heading for Paris with a stopover in Athens, carrying 228 passengers of Israeli, French and various other nationalities. Security at the Lod airport was famously tight  but in Athens, where security was lax, four hijackers boarded the Airbus carrying large black bags that held guns and hand grenades, took over the plane and forced the pilot to divert to Entebbe Airport, on the shore of Lake Victoria in Uganda. Six days later, a team of Israeli Special Forces personnel attacked the airport in a daring and ingenious raid, named Operation Thunderbolt, and freed the hostages.

title: Maison Margiela: Fall 2016
description: Fall 2016 mens wear designs from John Galliano.

title: Carefully Considering Pension Payment Options
description: Companies are increasingly offering retirees and former employees the option of taking their pensions in a lump-sum payment, rather than as a traditional monthly payment over a lifetime.

title: Sympathy Lies With the Pets
description: Dear Diary:

title: Living on Paper: Letters From Iris Murdoch, 1934-1995
description: At 17, Iris Murdoch was asked what she intended to do with her life. She gave a one-word answer: Write. Sixty years on, what may have been Dame Iris Murdochs last coherent words as she was sucked into the darkness of Alzheimers disease were: I wrote.

title: Hillary Clinton to Highlight Core Supporters on Anniversary of Roe v. Wade
description: As the Democratic presidential primary race has taken a harsher turn in the last few days, Hillary Clinton will try to focus on the group of supporters she hopes will lift her candidacy  women  as she campaigns in New Hampshire.

title: Fashion Wants Alber Elbaz to Start His Own Line
description: What should the former Lanvin designer Alber Elbaz do next? As mens wear goes into high gear in Paris and the city prepares for couture, that is a question that keeps coming up. Though there was a movement last fall, in the immediate wake of his firing, to draft him to be creative director of Christian Dior, the post left vacant by Raf Simons, that talk has died down, and there is now a groundswell of support for him starting his own line.

title: 1941: British Forces at 4 Million Men
description: LONDON  Declaring that the size of the army was at the root of all questions of man power, Prime Minister Winston Churchill revealed to the House of Commons today [Jan. 22] that the British Empires armed forces, including the Home Guard, now numbered 4,000,000 men. This army, he explained, was a very large and formidable force, both fighting overseas and for defense. Great Britains vast industrial establishment, he continued, had been set up in 1939 to provide the army with all the equipment it required in continuous action on the Continent of Europe against the German enemy.

title: Dire Warnings Along East Coast as Snow Piles Up
description: WASHINGTON  A massive winter storm that threatens to dump two feet of snow on the nations capital began pummeling the East Coast on Friday afternoon, as millions of people from the Carolinas to New York braced for a weekend of severe winds, power losses and coastal flooding.
