description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews Rabin: The Last Day.

title: Introducing the Upshots Encyclopedia of Donald Trumps Twitter Insults
description: The mixed martial arts fighter Ronda Rousey is not a nice person. The golf swing of the actor Samuel L. Jackson is not athletic. A lectern in the Oval Office looks odd, and the mobile carrier T-Mobiles service is terrible.

title: Movie Review: The Finest Hours
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews The Finest Hours.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Jan. 29-Feb. 4
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Chinese-Made Cars Arrive in U.S. Showrooms
description: A PEEK under the hood of three new cars from Volvo, Buick and Cadillac will not reveal a Made in China label. But those cars are breaking new ground in the auto industry, becoming the first to be manufactured in the Peoples Republic and exported to the United States.

title: Movie Review: Kung Fu Panda 3
description: The Times critic Neil Genzlinger reviews Kung Fu Panda 3.

title: A Letterpress Project That Spans a Continent
description: In the last half of the 19th century and in the early years of the 20th, back when printing was a trade, there was enough work to carve out a living for anyone with the skills and a union card almost anywhere in the U.S.  and some printers with a taste for travel found their work on the road. The peripatetic lives of these tramp printers, as they were known, are the inspiration for artist Chris Frittons crowdfunded Itinerant Printer Project. The campaign will take him to more than 100 letterpress shops across the country, creating postcards and prints to send his backers along the way. (So far hes visited 67.)

title: This Weeks Movies | Jan. 29, 2016
description: The New York Times film critics review Rabin: The Last Day, The Finest Hours and Kung Fu Panda 3.

title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Oregon, Rihanna
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Trump Tower to Remove Disputed Kiosks From Public Atrium
description: The hats and T-shirts for sale at two gift shops inside the Trump Tower may declare Make America Great Again, but New York City sent the Trump Organization a different message on Thursday: Make this atrium the same again.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 29-Feb. 4
description: American Museum of Natural History: Countdown to Zero (through early 2017) Smallpox is the only human disease to have been eradicated, but what about Guinea worm, polio, malaria and others? This exhibition, presented in collaboration with the Carter Center, examines international efforts to control and wipe out infection. Daily from 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., Central Park West and 79th Street, 212-769-5200, amnh.org.

title: In Cameron Rowlands 91020000, Disquieting Sculptures
description: The objects in Cameron Rowlands remarkable show at Artists Space offer a history lesson and an aesthetic experience, intricately fused. Accompanied by terse explanatory captions, they expose some of the troubling inequities in American society, especially concerning its prisons and their use of compulsory inmate labor. The process of grasping the meaning of this work equally involves looking, reading and feeling but its subject is one of the most urgent of our time.

title: Review: JeruZalem, Through Glasses, Darkly
description: JeruZalem is an intriguing variation on the found-footage horror genre, showing virtually the entire story through the perspective of a pair of smart glasses. But, as if losing faith in the gimmick, the directors, the brothers Doron and Yoav Paz, ultimately shackle it to a run-from-the-ghouls climax, and intriguing becomes ordinary.

title: Bernie Sanders Coaxes Young Iowans With 5-Second Videos
description: DES MOINES  It was no accident that Bernie Sanders campaigned in a high school here this morning.

title: New York City Officials Announce Efforts to Fight Zika Virus
description: With a growing number of countries throughout the Americas reporting increased transmission of the Zika virus, New York City heath officials announced plans on Thursday to try to prevent the pathogen from establishing a foothold in the city.

title: Single Payer Trouble
description: A week ago I worried about the Sanders health plan; it looked as if he was low-balling costs in an effort to obscure how hard making such a plan would be, and how many currently well-insured people would end up being losers. I wrote that his plan

title: Marco Rubios Camp Sees Opening if Donald Trump Wins in Iowa
description: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa  There are a lot of people in Iowa who want Donald J. Trump to win the caucuses on Monday. Marco Rubio is one of them.

title: Politico Will Lose Its Co-Founder and 4 Others
description: The Politico co-founder and chief executive, Jim VandeHei, and one of its best-known journalists, Mike Allen, plan to leave the publication after the November presidential election, its owner Robert Allbritton said in a memo to the staff on Thursday. Three other senior executives also plan to leave.

title: Review: In Lazer Team, Bickering Losers Try to Save the World
description: Lazer Team ends by setting itself up for a sequel, but thats mighty wishful thinking. Theres not a big demand for laugh-free comedies.

title: Family Band Performed at Oregon Refuge
description: The Sharp Family Band from Kansas sang at a pavilion in the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge on Saturday, watched by Ryan and Ammon Bundy and other protesters.

title: Family Gospel Band Provided Soundtrack for Oregon Refuge Standoff
description: PRINCETON, Ore.  They arrived last weekend to spread Scripture, song and good cheer to the armed group that had taken over the federal wildlife sanctuary here: a single mother from Kansas and eight of her 10 children, members of a family gospel band who brought their instruments in a Partridge Family-style bus bearing the slogan, Spirit Driven.

title: Things to Do in New Jersey, Jan. 30 Through Feb. 7
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Review: In Mountain Men, Two Brothers Are Forced to Work Things Out
description: There are three good laughs in Mountain Men and two modestly dramatic sections. That averages out to a decent moment every 18 minutes. While it may seem unfair to judge a movie using a calculation, its appropriate for a script that repeatedly falls back on formulas.

title: Things to Do on Long Island, Jan. 30 Through Feb. 7
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Review: Noam Chomsky Focuses on Financial Inequality in Requiem for the American Dream
description: Requiem for the American Dream is a timely 75-minute teach-in by Noam Chomsky, the M.I.T. linguistics professor who has been a leading leftist political analyst, critic and writer for six decades. Mr. Chomsky, already the subject of several documentaries, focuses here on an election-season theme: financial inequality in America and what he calls its corrosive effect on democracy. Assembling 10 Principles of Concentration of Wealth and Power, he lays out rules like Run the Regulators, Marginalize the Population and Manufacture Consent.

title: Seventh Republican Debate: Analysis

description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Xerox Planning Spinoff, Under Pressure From Carl Icahn
description: Another American corporate icon has decided that breaking up is the thing to do.

title: Acura Taps Van Halen for a Hard-Driving Super Bowl Commercial
description: Fleetwood Macs Landslide served as the perfect soundtrack for Budweisers heartwarming 2013 ad where a Clydesdale reunited with its former trainer. The composer John Williams Imperial March from Star Wars added just the right touch to Volkswagens humorous 2011 spot about a junior Darth Vader trying to use the Force.

title: Vincent A. Cianci Jr., Celebrated and Scorned Ex-Mayor of Providence, R.I., Dies at 74
description: His nickname of Buddy hovered in the murky middle between friendly engagement and whats-it-to-you aggression. Either way, it seemed to capture Vincent A. Cianci Jr., the former mayor of Providence, R.I., known for his finger-snap wit, protracted troubles with the law, and unfailing devotion to his city.

title: De Blasios Wife and Council Members Share Personal Stories at Mental Health Hearing
description: Amid the stats and figures, dot-driven maps of New York City and questions about the minutiae of neighborhood issues, a hearing at the City Council on Thursday included more than the usual amount of personal revelation from Council members.

title: PACs Backing Jeb Bush and Chris Christie Attack John Kasich in New Hampshire
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  First, Gov. John Kasichs rivals ignored him. Then a few gently criticized him.

title: Russia Dismisses German Warnings About Exploiting Teen Rape Claim
description: MOSCOW  The Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, on Thursday dismissed what he called Germanys accusations that Russia was exploiting the mysterious disappearance of a 13-year-old Russian-German girl, who lives in eastern Berlin, to pursue its political aims.

title: Review: Bruce Springsteen, Keeping an Eye on the Clock, at Madison Square Garden
description: The subtext to The River was time, Bruce Springsteen said as the E Street Band played a slow, shimmering vamp. Time slipping away. And once you enter that adult world, the clock starts ticking and youve got a limited amount of time to do your work, to raise your family, to try and do something good.

title: Review: Bruckner Rises and Stalls in Hands of Two Conductors
description: Thanks to the New York Philharmonics hiring of Jaap van Zweden to replace Alan Gilbert as music director in 2018, announced on Wednesday, it is again possible to welcome guest conductors without having to assess their immediate suitability for the permanent post. So the Spanish maestro Juanjo Mena, who is conducting the orchestras subscription concerts this week, may escape the closest scrutiny, as he did in his New York Philharmonic debut, late in 2014, when he led a snoozy program of standards more or less lost in the holiday bustle.

title: With Eye on Growth, Imagine Entertainment Seeks an Investment
description: Over three decades, Brian Grazer and Ron Howard have built Imagine Entertainment into a top film and television production company, with credits stretching from the movie Apollo 13 to the television show Empire.

title: Three Films by Richard Lester, a Yank in Britains 1960s New Wave
description: The director Richard Lester, now in his 80s, not only had a career but also a moment. No filmmaker in this decade appeared more punctually when his hour struck, the film critic Alexander Walker wrote in his history of 1960s British cinema.

title: California Votes to Retain System That Pays Solar Users Retail Rate for Excess Power
description: Regulators in California, home to more residential solar customers than any other state, agreed on Thursday to retain a system that compensates users of rooftop solar panels for their excess electricity.

title: Cosby Lawyers and Prosecutors Spar Ahead of Court Hearing
description: The war of words between lawyers for Bill Cosby and Pennsylvania prosecutors who have charged the entertainer with sexual assault continued on Thursday in advance of a hearing scheduled for next week.

title: Moderates Under Pressure in Iran
description: Next months elections in Iran do not bode well for Iranians eager for more political and social freedoms or for the promising new relationship with the West symbolized by the recent deal limiting Irans nuclear program. Even before any ballots are cast, the death-to-America hard-liners who bitterly opposed the deal are stacking the deck against moderates led by President Hassan Rouhani, who signed the agreement and is more open than others in the power structure to further engagement with Western nations as well as expanding rights and freedoms for Iranian citizens.

title: China to Try Canadian on Spying Charges
description: BEIJING  A Canadian man who ran a cafe near Chinas border with North Korea will be tried on charges of spying and stealing state secrets, prosecutors announced on Friday, nearly a year and a half after he and his wife were detained by the police.

title: Many Fertilizer Plants Are Poorly Located and Regulated, Says Report on 2013 Blast
description: HOUSTON  Nearly 20 fertilizer plants in Texas and others nationwide have the same dangerous proximity to schools, parks, nursing homes and housing as the one that exploded in the Central Texas town of West in 2013, federal officials said in releasing a final report on the blast Thursday.

title: New Details of Iran Ordeal Emerge From Former Prisoners
description: Two of the Americans freed by Iran this month in a prisoner deal have provided new detail about their time in captivity, saying they were told by Iranian interrogators that the United States had abandoned them and that they would never leave. One said he had been accused of plotting armed revolution.

title: Mentally Disturbed Man Killed Teacher at Harlem Shelter, Police Say
description: For at least a week, Anthony White, 21, a resident at a shelter in East Harlem, had frightened staff members and fellow residents with threats that he was going to kill someone, residents there said on Thursday.

title: What You Missed in the Debate
description: DES MOINES  Following is immediate real-time analysis of the seventh Republican debate. Read additional fact checks here.

title: Michael J. Kennedy, Lawyer for Underdogs and Pariahs, Dies at 78
description: Michael J. Kennedy, who as a criminal lawyer championed lost causes and deeply unpopular defendants  including John Gotti Sr., Huey P. Newton and Timothy Leary  and finally won freedom for Jean S. Harris, the convicted killer of Dr. Herman Tarnower, the Scarsdale Diet doctor, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: Plotters Talked of Planting Explosives on a Kangaroo in Australia
description: SYDNEY  A teenager accused of plotting to behead a police officer as part of a holiday terrorist attack also discussed planting explosives on a kangaroo, painting it with an Islamic State symbol and setting it upon the police, prosecutors said on Friday.

title: More Is Needed to Beat ISIS, Pentagon Officials Conclude
description: WASHINGTON  Pentagon officials have concluded that hundreds more trainers, advisers and commandos from the United States and its allies will need to be sent to Iraq and Syria in the coming months as the campaign to isolate the Islamic State intensifies.

title: Talking Out Their Problems, the Lightning Enter the Playoff Conversation
description: BRANDON, Fla.  A moment of truth hit the Tampa Bay Lightning deep in western Canada on Jan. 5. A galling, lackluster 3-1 loss to the Calgary Flames  their fourth defeat in six games  symbolized a slide from Stanley Cup contenders to slackers.

title: Officers Response After Shooting Is Scrutinized at Manslaughter Trial
description: A New York City police lieutenant who arrived at a housing project in Brooklyn where a man had been shot by a police officer said he had found the officer, Peter Liang, frozen on a fourth-floor landing. One level above him lay the man, Akai Gurley, mortally wounded and sprawled on the floor, said the lieutenant, Vitaliy Zelikov, who testified on Thursday at Officer Liangs trial in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Jose Calderon Hears Criticism, but Not From Knicks Teammates He Mentors
description: TORONTO  Whenever Jose Calderon visits Air Canada Centre, pieces of his past re-emerge. Calderon, a 34-year-old point guard, spent the first seven and a half seasons of his N.B.A. career with the Raptors. He honed his 3-point shot, jettisoning his chicken-wing release. He improved his English. And he quickly became a mentor to teammates who learned to listen.

title: One Last Debate Before the Caucuses
description: The Republican candidates met in Des Moines in the last debate before the Iowa caucuses on Monday.

title: Transcript of the Preliminary G.O.P. Presidential Debate
description: Following is a transcript of the preliminary Republican debate, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

title: A Move to End Transparency for New Yorks Jails
description: Here, courtesy of an obscure New York City agency, is a window into the unseen, a forum for matters of fallibility and trivia and also for outrages that have managed to become the business of the government.

title: Quest for Olympic Gold in Rio Makes Rugby Sevens a Priority
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand  A few years ago, seeing the New Zealand sevens rugby team in seventh place in the World Sevens Series would have been unthinkable.

title: Thunderous Noises on East Coast Were Sonic Booms, Navy Says
description: A series of earthshaking noises that left some residents on the East Coast wondering if they had lived through an earthquake on Thursday afternoon were sonic booms caused by the testing of a fighter jet, officials said.

title: In Spirit of Ryder Cup, a Competition to Honor Rod Laver
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It was Novak Djokovic against Roger Federer on Thursday night in Rod Laver Arena in the semifinals of the Australian Open, but if the organizers of a new tennis competition have their way, it will soon be Djokovic and Federer playing on the same European team for a trophy called the Laver Cup.

title: Review: Sojourners, About Nigerians Assimilating to Life in the U.S.
description: In Sojourners, an emotionally fervid and dramatically stolid play by Mfoniso Udofia for the Playwrights Realm, a Nigerian couple embrace and rebuff life in America. Ukpong (Hubert Point-Du Jour) and Abasiama (Chinasa Ogbuagu), joined in an ill-conceived arranged marriage, are student newlyweds in Houston in 1978.

title: Without a Doubt
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  If I had asked a Magic 8 Ball last week whether my part of the country was really going to be blanketed by nearly 30 inches of snow, I can only imagine that the answer would have been IT IS DECIDEDLY SO. That thought amused me as I was shoveling my way through the blizzard and it will continue to amuse me, at least until it is time for my next dose of Motrin.

title: California: Another Arrest in Jail Break
description: An employee at the Orange County Central Mens Jail was taken into custody on Thursday for aiding the escape of three inmates from the maximum security facility last week. The employee, Nooshafarin Ravaghi, had taught English as a second language at the jail since July. At least one of the escapees, Hossein Nayeri, attended her class, and the two developed some kind of relationship, said Lt. Jeff Hallock, a spokesman for the Orange County Sheriffs Department. Ms. Ravaghi, 44, provided Google maps and other help for the escape, Mr. Hallock said, but she has denied providing tools used in the escape. The three men cut through metal bars before rappelling from the jails roof using a makeshift rope. Investigators believe the three men may be in a white GMC utility van, which was stolen in Los Angeles on Saturday.

title: My Take on the Republican Debate, Minus Trump
description: The Republican candidates for president  with one big sulky orange-haired exception  dueled in a Fox News televised debate tonight. And my sense was that Trump was probably wise to skip it: He didnt pay much of a price for staying away, he avoided tough questions and attacks, and his rivals used the occasion to slash each other. Bush had a better night than usual, and Rubio wrapped himself in the Bible in ways that may be effective in Iowa. Instead of writing a column, Ive collected some of my tweets about the debate in this blog post. These are raw reflections, on the fly.

title: New York Council May Vote on Raise and Horse-Carriage Bill on Same Day
description: The City Council completed a package of bills on Thursday to give its members a raise for the first time since 2006, adopting provisions on outside income and financial disclosures called for by good-government groups while lifting their own pay far above the level recommended by a city commission.

title: Knicks Limp to a Defeat in Toronto
description: A depleted Knicks team tested the Raptors on Thursday before losing, 103-93, at Air Canada Centre.

title: U.S. Placed Immigrant Children With Traffickers, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Department of Health and Human Services placed more than a dozen immigrant children in the custody of human traffickers after it failed to conduct background checks of caregivers, according to a Senate report released on Thursday.

title: Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio Clash Harshly, Filling Void on G.O.P. Debate Stage
description: DES MOINES  The Republican presidential candidates competed vigorously to fill the vacuum created by Donald J. Trumps boycott of Thursday nights debate, with Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida trading ferocious attacks on immigration and taking fire from rivals seeking advantage in the Iowa caucuses on Monday.

title: Paul Kantner, a Founder of Jefferson Airplane, Dies at 74
description: Paul Kantner, a founding member of Jefferson Airplane, one of the definitive San Francisco psychedelic groups of the 1960s, and the guiding spirit of its successor, Jefferson Starship, died on Thursday in San Francisco. He was 74.

title: Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, Pakistani Diplomat, Dies at 95
description: Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, a former military leader, foreign minister and diplomat who was Pakistans public face in international affairs for three decades, died late Monday or early Tuesday in Islamabad. He was 95.

title: 3 Rights Advocates Are Sentenced to Prison in China
description: BEIJING  Three civil rights advocates were sentenced to prison in southern China on Friday, with the terms ranging from two and a half to five years, after a judge declared them guilty of inciting subversion.

title: G.O.P. Debate Stars the Ghost of Donald Trump
description: DES MOINES  Donald Trumps absence, of course, was the most compelling presence.

title: Bank of Japan, in a Surprise, Adopts Negative Interest Rate
description: As Japans economic doldrums have lingered, its leaders have tried a number of tricks over the years, from increasing government spending to flooding the financial system with cash.

title: Transcript of the Main Republican Presidential Debate
description: Following is a transcript of the main Republican debate, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

title: Latin America to Unite Against Zika
description: President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia announced that Latin American and Caribbean countries will come together to fight the Zika virus, with efforts such as fumigating against the disease-carrying mosquitos.

title: Flying After 45
description: The trapeze instructor Suzi Winson teaches a class for older students.

title: Obama Moves to Expand Rules Aimed at Closing Gender Pay Gap
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday moved to require companies to report to the federal government what they pay employees by race, gender and ethnicity, part of his push to crack down on firms that pay women less for doing the same work as men.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | dishearten
description: dishearten  \()dis-hr-tn\  verb

title: New Yorks Week in Pictures: Jan. 29
description: Photographs from the past week in New York and the region include images of the winters first snowstorm and the financially troubled Atlantic City.

title: Donald Trump Takes to Solo Stage Instead of G.O.P. Debate
description: DES MOINES  It was supposed to be about the veterans.

title: Analysis of the Seventh G.O.P. Debate
description: Jeremy W. Peters of The New York Times discusses key moments from the Republican presidential debate on Thursday in Des Moines, as the candidates sparred over immigration and other issues.

title: What to Watch Friday
description: Elaine May remembers her comedy partner Mike Nichols on American Masters. The Blind Side recounts the feel-good story of the football player Michael Oher, now headed to the Super Bowl with the Carolina Panthers. And Dateline takes on the case of Steven Avery.

title: Who Won the Republican Debate? Critics Call Ted Cruz Flat but Jeb Bush Better
description: With Donald J. Trump absent from the debate stage, critics had a chance to focus on the rest of the Republican field. While the verdicts varied, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas was seen as starting strong but fading late, while Senator Marco Rubio of Florida had his moments but grew testy at times when faced with tough questions. Some thought Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor, had one of his most energetic performances, while the retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson barely registered.

title: Beyond Stereotypes in California and Kentucky
description: Working in places like Appalachia and Northern California, William Gendey challenged preconceived notions to find enduring  and unexpected  images.

title: Beyond Stereotypes in California and Kentucky
description: Urban California and rural Appalachia were amply documented in the 1960s, even if the usual narratives were often polar opposites: the Bay Area, with its free-loving, psychedelic hippie counterculture or Kentucky with its gritty backwoods scenes of despair and poverty.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: He did a lot for the city and a lot to the city.

title: Corrections: January 29, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Problem With the Ethanol Mandate That Iowa Loves
description: IOWA is the nations top producer of corn, and nearly half of it ends up as ethanol, thanks to a government mandate that requires ethanol to be mixed into gasoline. The mandate is worth hundreds of millions of dollars to farmers there.

title: Intolerable Bias in Irelands Schools
description: The people of Ireland have shown a commendable willingness to strike anachronistic bias from the countrys laws, most emphatically in legalizing gay marriage last year in a referendum approved by three out of five voters. With a general election expected next month, a movement is underway in the rapidly changing nation to target another hurtful social condition by which non-Catholic children are legally denied seats at overcrowded state-financed primary schools, 97 percent of which are controlled by Catholic authorities.

title: Righting a Grave Injustice in Louisiana
description: The Supreme Court had people like Taurus Buchanan in mind this week when it reinforced a 2012 decision banning mandatory life-without-parole sentences for juveniles and found that people sentenced before that ruling had a constitutional right to seek parole.

title: How Stupid Is Iowa?
description: In the 44 years since the two major parties have allowed a small cohort of Midwesterners to decide the nations first presidential contest, the good people of Iowa have debated issues ranging from nuclear Armageddon to universal health care.

title: What Republicans Should Say
description: For a few decades, American and British conservatism marched in tandem. Thatcher was philosophically akin to Reagan. John Major was akin to George Bush.

title: Plutocrats and Prejudice
description: Every time you think that our political discourse cant get any worse, it does. The Republican primary fight has devolved into a race to the bottom, achieving something you might have thought impossible: making George W. Bush look like a beacon of tolerance and statesmanship. But where is all the nastiness coming from?

title: Elizabeth Warren: One Way to Rebuild Our Institutions
description: WASHINGTON  WHILE presidential candidates from both parties feverishly pitch their legislative agendas, voters should also consider what presidents can do without Congress. Agency rules, executive actions and decisions about how vigorously to enforce certain laws will have an impact on every American, without a single new bill introduced in Congress.

title: Stopping the Spread of Zika
Drug Shortages Forcing Hard Decisions on Rationing Treatments
description: CLEVELAND  In the operating room at the Cleveland Clinic, Dr. Brian Fitzsimons has long relied on a decades-old drug to prevent hemorrhages in patients undergoing open-heart surgery. The drug, aminocaproic acid, is widely used, cheap and safe. It never hurt, he said. It only helps.

title: Imagining Hong Kongs Future, Under Chinas Tightening Grasp
description: HONG KONG  What will Hong Kong be like a decade from now?

title: News Qs | Zika Virus Spreading Explosively in Americas, W.H.O. Says
description: The following lesson activities are based on the article Zika Virus Spreading Explosively in Americas, W.H.O. Says.

title: Student Question | What National or International Events That You Lived Through Do You Remember Best?
description: When the space shuttle Challenger exploded in 1986, it was among the nations worst space disasters ever. This particular launch had especially attracted national interest because it included a high school teacher from New Hampshire, Christa McAuliffe, who won a nationwide competition to broadcast two lessons from space to students. The Challenger disaster was one of those events that American children growing up in the 80s tend to remember  many of them watched it happen live on TV.

title: Look! Up Over the Hospital! Its Super Proxy!
description: We all entertain fantasies of being someone else, and mine lately is Super Proxy  a combination of Superwoman and a legally designated health care proxy, who can make medical decisions faster than a speeding bullet and leap over paperwork in a single bound. Id especially enjoy using my superhuman strength to dangle the hospital admissions person out a window.

title: Conquering the Midair Crisis at a Trapeze Class
description: Madeleine Hormann was 7 years old when she decided to run away from home and join the circus. But like the best-laid plans of many second graders, hers went awry. Instead, she grew up, moved to Arizona and found work in engineering. It wasnt until middle age that Ms. Hormann  fresh from losing a job and recovering from a broken leg  decided to give her childhood aspirations another shot.

title: Jehovahs Witnesses Brooklyn Headquarters for Sale
description: The giant red letters stand 15 feet tall, declaring Watchtower.

title: Finding a Common Tune
description: If you just looked at us on paper, said the bride, you wouldnt say that was a perfect fit.

title: Imperfect on Paper, Harmony in Practice
description: They owe it all to guitar lessons. Or maybe the Faberg Big Egg Hunt she talked him into. Or maybe just to proximity and timing.

title: Liz Pearce of LiquidPlanner: Solving the Rubiks Cube of Leadership
description: This interview with Liz Pearce, C.E.O. of LiquidPlanner, a project management software firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Film Club | Ivy League Trailblazers
description: Being the first in your family to attend college presents both opportunities and challenges. The short film Ivy League Trailblazers shares the stories of first-generation students attending some of the nations most prestigious universities.

title: Experiencing the Presidential Campaign: A Virtual Reality Film
description: The Times has produced a virtual reality film from footage of presidential campaign events taken over the last month. To view it, download the NYT VR app on your mobile device if you dont already have it. (Go here for Android and here for iPhone.) Here, a national political correspondent revels in covering the campaign.

title: Bernie Sanders Campaigns: Watch in Virtual Reality
description: Our newest virtual reality film takes you to presidential campaign events, including those of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, taken over the last month. Use the free NYT VR mobile app, with your headphones and optional cardboard viewing device, to experience it.

title: Hillary Clinton Campaigns: Watch in Virtual Reality
description: Our newest virtual reality film takes you to presidential campaign events, including those of Hillary Clinton, taken over the last month. Use the free NYT VR mobile app, with your headphones and optional cardboard viewing device, to experience it.

title: Donald Trump Campaigns: Watch in Virtual Reality
description: Our newest virtual reality film takes you to presidential campaign events, including those of Donald J. Trump, taken over the last month. Use the free NYT VR mobile app, with your headphones and optional cardboard viewing device, to experience it.

title: Ted Cruz Campaigns: Watch in Virtual Reality
description: Our newest virtual reality film takes you to presidential campaign events, including those of Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, using footage taken over the last month. Use the free NYT VR mobile app, with your headphones and optional cardboard viewing device, to experience it.

title: China Is Said to Force Closing of Womens Legal Aid Center
description: BEIJING  The Chinese authorities have ordered a leading womens legal aid center in Beijing to shut down operations, the centers founder said on Friday, another sign of a continuing crackdown on civil society.

title: Takata Denies Reports Its Chief Executive Will Resign
description: HONG KONG  Takata, the Japanese company whose faulty airbag inflaters have been linked to 10 deaths and led to the global recall of millions of cars, said on Friday that its chief executive had no current plans to resign.

title: Festival and Hotel News: Lights in Baltimore, Music in St. Martin
description: A KIMPTON IN AMSTERDAM

title: Morning Agenda: Xerox Planning Spinoff
description: XEROX PLANNING SPINOFF | Xerox has agreed to spin off its services business to its shareholders by the end of the year, separating it from the legacy hardware side,Leslie Picker and Liz Moyer report in DealBook. A person briefed on the decision said that a large part of the spinoff would incorporate Affiliated Computer Services, the business outsourcing company that Xerox bought for $6.4 billion in 2010.

title: Ask Well: More Sleep, Fewer Colds?
description: Question:

title: Your Friday Briefing: Donald Trump, Oregon, Flint
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Oxford University Will Keep Statue of Cecil Rhodes
description: LONDON  An outspoken group of students wanted to pull it down, and many alumni wanted it to stay. For months, the authorities at Oxford University have struggled with an awkward dilemma over the fate a statue of Cecil Rhodes, an imperialist benefactor seen by many as an architect of apartheid.

title: New York Today: Respect the Paw
description: Updated at 11:00 a.m.

title: Questioning the Evidence in the Making a Murderer Case
description: MANITOWOC, Wis.  The Netflix series Making a Murderer stirred up questions about the convictions of Steven Avery and Brendan Dassey in the 2005 murder of Teresa Halbach and spawned an army of amateur sleuths, who have taken to Reddit and other digital forums to analyze details of the case. Here are a few of the questions raised by the series, and responses from investigators and the lead prosecutor, Ken Kratz.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Zika, Back Pain and Knitting
description: Take the Quiz

title: Lee Wan-koo, Ex-Premier of South Korea, Guilty of Taking Illegal Funds
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A former prime minister of South Korea was convicted on Friday of receiving illegal political funds from a businessman who later committed suicide.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start your day.

title: Bird Watchers Help Science Fill Gaps in the Migratory Story
description: We all know birds in North America fly south for the winter and revisit us come spring, but have you ever wondered what their journey looks like once they leave our backyards?

title: Israel, Mired in Ideological Battles, Fights on Cultural Fronts
description: JERUSALEM  There have been fights over books, music, plays, funding for the arts and academic awards. This being Israel, they have been underpinned by fierce rhetorical exchanges about democracy, fascism and zealotry, identity, the future of the state and the fate of Jews.

title: In Philippines, World War IIs Lesser-Known Sex Slaves Speak Out
description: MANILA  The 89-year-old woman stood in the broiling sun this week outside the Philippine presidential palace hoping to make a point.

title: Our Man in Iowa: A Scramble to Turn Out Voters After the Debate
description: DES MOINES  Good morning from Iowa, where the day after the Republican debate candidates are flooding the state, with nine Republicans and three Democrats holding 41 public events. You can tell a lot about their last-minute strategies by looking at where they are going.

title: South Korea Sentences American to 20 Years in 1997 Murder
description: SEOUL, South Korea  An American man was convicted and sentenced here on Friday to 20 years in prison for a murder committed more than 18 years ago  a notorious case that has gripped South Korea for years.

title: The 1.17.16 Issue
description: RE: THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC AND HAITI

title: How to Skip a Stone
description: Throw at a 20-degree angle, says Lydric Bocquet, a physics professor at cole Normale Suprieure in Paris. Thats what he calls the magic angle for a maximum number of skips.

title: On the Way Home
description: Soon after I arrived in America in May 2010, Jewish Family Services found me a place to live, a room in the home of a retired nurse in Springfield, Mass. They also found me a bicycle, a backpack and a job working the second shift at a bakery in Agawam, a small town on the other side of the Connecticut River.

title: Drinking With Archibald Motley
description: Last fall, I went to the Whitney Museum of American Art to see the exhibition Archibald Motley: Jazz Age Modernist. I found myself spellbound by a nightclub scene: a vivid tableau of dancing couples, so close to the band  a trombones slide stretches out between three people  as to appear in a tangle. Another couple can be glimpsed seated at a table, a glass of wine in front of the woman and a cocktail (it looks like a Manhattan) set before her date. I was surprised to see that Motley named the painting Blues. The heavy-souled sadness I associate with that music seems at odds with the image  but Motley must have known it was in there, too.

title: Type 2
description: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.

title: An Online Magazine for Seniors Who Ski
description: Skiers above the age of 50 are like the Rodney Dangerfields of the ski world  at least according to Jon Weisberg, co-founder of the online magazine SeniorsSkiing.com. They dont get that much respect, he said.

title: U.S. and Britain Spied on Israeli Drone Flights, Documents Show
description: JERUSALEM  The United States and Britain have monitored secret drone flights and communications by the Israeli Air Force in a hacking operation dating to 1998, according to documents attributed to leaks by the former American intelligence contractor Edward J. Snowden.

title: Donald Trump, the Man Who Wasnt There
description: A debate without Donald J. Trump does not mean that Mr. Trump is really absent.

title: Trumps Solo Act Gets Cables Attention, but Not All of It
description: Cable news stations were fixated for two days over Donald J. Trumps decision to pull out of Fox Newss Republican debate, so much so that many anticipated he might provide stiff competition for Fox on Thursday night when he staged his own event in Iowa at the same time. But if Mr. Trump was hoping for uninterrupted live coverage of his event from Foxs cable news rivals, he did not get it, as both CNN and MSNBC broke away from his appearance about 15 minutes after it started.

title: Como o vrus Zika tem afetado voc?
description: A Organizao Mundial de Sade afirmou nesta semana que o vrus Zika pode atingir at quatro milhes de pessoas no continente americano em 2016. O vrus tem sido associado ao aumento exponencial de casos de microcefalia no Brasil.

title: Burundi Mass Grave Clues Seen in Satellite Photos, Group Says
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Satellite imagery of the outskirts of Burundis capital supports emerging accounts of graves holding at least 50 people who died during political violence last month, the human rights organization Amnesty International said on Friday.

title: Jacques Rivette, French New Wave Director of Enigmatic Films, Dies at 87
description: Jacques Rivette, a French director whose challenging and often enigmatic work was revered by film aficionados, died on Friday at his home in Paris. He was 87.

title: Chappatte on the E.U.s Migrant Crisis
description: Pay as you go: This country is no place for freeloaders.

title: Historical Figures, Campus Controversies
description: Around the world, student activists are demanding that building and statutes commemorating historically figures whose legacies are now seen as morally dubious.

title: Xerox, in Deal With Carl Icahn, to Split Company in Two
description: By late November, Ursula M. Burns had finally conceded that the biggest takeover in Xeroxs history was a $6.4 billion mistake, say people close to the company.

title: The Women Who Should Love Hillary Clinton
description: THERE is nothing more sexist than wanting Hillary Clinton as president because shes a woman.

title: Justin Peck Calmly Creates a Kingdom at City Ballet
description: In a 19th-century stone castle in Yonkers, the ballet choreographer Justin Peck tried something he had never tried before: directing a film. He did not look nervous. Nor did he seem intimidated by his surroundings: the ornate, centuries-old furnishings from Europe; the travel trunks left in the attic by the Ballets Russes choreographer Michel Fokine, who lived and taught in the castle in the 1930s. Gently making suggestions or demonstrating what he had in mind, the 28-year-old Mr. Peck appeared self-assured. If that doesnt work, he said at one point, I have a Plan B.

title: 1941: General Metaxas Dies at 69
description: ATHENS  In the midst of the struggle to preserve its national independence, Greece was forced today [Jan. 29] by the death of its ruler, Premier Gen. John Metaxas, to entrust its destiny to a new leader. The man named by King George II to take over the task of leading Greece to victory is fifty-five-year-old Alexander Korizis, former Minister of Public Welfare and president of the National Bank of Greece.

title: Bombing in Central Laos Kills 2 From China
description: BEIJING  Two people from China were killed and a third was wounded by a recent bomb blast near a military camp in Laos, according to the Chinese Foreign Ministry, state news reports and an article by Radio Free Asia.

title: Peacekeepers Accused of Sexual Abuse in Central African Republic
description: GENEVA  The United Nations reported on Friday extremely disturbing new accusations of sexual abuse by European peacekeepers in the Central African Republic, adding to a long-running scandal that has reverberated at the highest levels of the world body.

title: Against Djokovic, Believing and Achieving Arent the Same
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Popular usage to the contrary, the definition of insanity is not actually doing the same thing over and over again and expecting a different result.

title: Bank of England to Require More Buffers for Britains Biggest Banks
description: LONDON  Britains largest banks would have to hold an additional buffer of capital under newly proposed rules meant to protect their retail banking businesses in a financial crisis, the Bank of England said on Friday.

title: The Snow Market
description: Dear Diary:

title: U.S. Economy Barely Grew Last Quarter, Stoking Concerns About Momentum in 2016
description: The American economy finished the year on a flat note, much as it started 2015, stoking concern about its vulnerability in the months ahead to turmoil in China and elsewhere in the global economy.

title: Review: Joan Baez and Friends in a 75th-Birthday Celebration of Duets
description: Joan Baez is still the mother of us all. At the Beacon Theater, where she celebrated her 75th  birthday on Wednesday evening with an all-star concert of duets, she was a quietly magnetic woman in charge. Radiating her characteristic maternal strength and easygoing humor, she projected the welcoming empathy of someone you can turn to in times of trouble. She looked terrific: trim and fit, with short silver hair and a wonderfully goofy smile.

title: Attack on Mosque in Saudi Arabia Leaves 2 Worshipers Dead
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Two worshipers were killed and seven others were wounded when a suicide bomber and a gunman struck a mosque in eastern Saudi Arabia on Friday, the Interior Ministry said.

title: Shopping Guide: Dining Tables
description: Finding the right one is even harder in a city where most tables are expected to multitask. An event planner offers some advice.

title: Charlotte Gainsbourg, Jane Birkin and the Possibility of a Serge Gainsbourg Museum
description: As part of Jane and Charlotte Forever, a Film Society of Lincoln Center series starting Friday featuring the work of the mother-and-daughter actresses Jane Birkin and Charlotte Gainsbourg, the pair spoke about Charlottes father and Janes onetime lover, Serge Gainsbourg. The singer-songwriter, actor and director, who died in 1991, is still a subject of fascination, especially in Paris, where Ms. Gainsbourg, for a time, considered turning his house into a museum. Ultimately, she said no. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation with Ms. Birkin and Ms. Gainsbourg.

title: London Lost and Found
description: What happens when you leave a city and then return year after year, still not prepared to call yourself an ex but increasingly bewildered like a tourist?

title: Share Your Photos
description: Submit your Instagram images of a place you suddenly saw #ThroughFreshEyes.

title: London Lost and Found
description: LONDON  I LEFT London and moved to India in August 2008. Four weeks later, Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, and the global economy went into a tailspin. People who had known the word derivative only as an adjective in book reviews were now using it as a noun; subprime entered the vocabulary of the uninitiated. The City of London seemed to be at the heart of this disaster whose effects were surging out over the cobbled streets of the Square Mile and into the farthest corners of the world, including my new home in the small southern Indian city Mysore.

title: Cutting Off Those Recurring Charges You Forgot About
description: If you want newly invented ice cream flavors to show up at your home each month, you can get a subscription for that.

title: Berlin Show Features German Ethnologists Copies of Art From Prehistoric Times
description: BERLIN  Among the exhibitions at the fledgling Museum of Modern Art in New York in 1937 was a show of 150 watercolor copies of prehistoric rock paintings and engravings that, the museum noted, had been selected by its director, Alfred H. Barr Jr.

title: German Forest Ranger Finds That Trees Have Social Networks, Too
description: HMMEL, Germany  IN the deep stillness of a forest in winter, the sound of footsteps on a carpet of leaves died away. Peter Wohlleben had found what he was looking for: a pair of towering beeches. These trees are friends, he said, craning his neck to look at the leafless crowns, black against a gray sky. You see how the thick branches point away from each other? Thats so they dont block their buddys light.

title: Daily Report: Divergent Fortunes in Cloud Computing
description: If there is one conclusion to draw from the company earnings reported on Thursday, it is this: Cloud computing is a booming business.

title: The Anti-Fed Two-Step
description: Back when Ted Cruz first floated his claim that the Fed caused the Great Recession  and some neo-monetarists spoke up in support  I noted that this was a repeat of the old Milton Friedman two-step.

title: Replacing Windows Media Center
description: Q. I use Windows Media Center to watch DVDs and listen to music on my Windows 7 laptop. Although I do not intend to upgrade to Windows 10 anytime soon, I have heard that the new system does not include WMC. Is this really true, and what are the alternatives?

title: Princess Cristina of Spain Loses Bid to Avoid Tax-Fraud Trial
description: MADRID  Princess Cristina of Spain will face tax fraud charges next month after a court rejected a final attempt by her lawyers on Friday to exempt her from a corruption case that has badly damaged the reputation of Spains monarchy.

title: Last Call to Enroll for 2016 Insurance Under the Affordable Care Act
description: THIS weekend is the final deadline to sign up for health insurance coverage this year under the Affordable Care Act.

title: James Murdoch to Return as Sky Chairman
description: The British pay television group Sky said on Friday that James Murdoch was returning as chairman almost four years after his humiliating departure at the height of the News Corporation  phone-hacking scandal.

title: Senator John Cornyn Aims to Sway Fellow Republicans on Criminal Justice
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John Cornyn, a former Texas judge and attorney general, is a devoted believer in the criminal justice overhaul awaiting its moment in the Senate. Now, he just has to convert doubting Republican colleagues.

title: Kremlin Demands Explanation for Outrageous U.S. Remarks About Putin
description: MOSCOW  Statements by two senior American officials that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has enriched himself through corruption are outrageous and insulting, Dmitry S. Peskov, the presidents spokesman, said on Friday.

title: To Grade Presidents on the Economy, Look at Policies, Not Results
description: When unemployment falls, inflation is low and the economy grows briskly, we often give the president high marks for handling the economy. But is that really how the economic record of presidents should be judged? As we pick the next president, this question is useful to ponder, for it is central to how we understand our history. Yet most people take the wrong approach to answering it.

title: David Cameron Renews Push to Reach E.U. Membership Deal
description: LONDON  With time running out if Britain is to schedule an early referendum on European Union membership, Prime Minister David Cameron was fighting with renewed urgency on Friday to win concessions that he hopes will persuade Britons to stay in the bloc.

title: Letters: Reading With Bill Bryson
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: Paperback books of particular interest.

title: Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Stockholm

title: Flint Weighs Scope of Harm to Children Caused by Lead in Water
description: FLINT, Mich.  Quayana Townss 2-month-old daughter wriggled on an exam table last week as her pediatrician ticked off questions that have become essential for every parent of young children here.

title: Editors Choice
description: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.

title: Inside the List
description: Attack the Messenger: Jane Mayers Dark Money, about the influence of wealthy families in conservative politics, hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No.5. Mayers book has made news partly for its revelation that even as she was investigating the Koch brothers, they seemed to be investigating her: Dirt, dirt, dirt, one source told Mayer, describing the mission a team of operatives had to smear her name after The New Yorker published her first long article about the Kochs political efforts. (Mayer goes where the facts take her: She had previously written a similar article about George Soross influence on liberal causes.) Its uncommon for a private detective to be hired to conduct a retaliatory investigation into a reporters character, she writes in the book, adding that although its unclear how directly involved they were, clues leading back to the Kochs were everywhere.

title: More Is More, More, More
description: January is the month of resolutions, and in her Help Desk column this week, Molly Young tackles new books that promise to show us how to become our most productive selves. Writers  often known in our romantic parlance for being tortured, starving or blocked  can have a love-hate relationship with productivity, fearful that therein lies the road to hackdom. According to Guinness World Records, the most prolific author as measured by words published is the British writer Charles Harold St. John Hamilton (1876-1961), with a whopping 72 to 73 million words to his 25 pen names. But even Hamilton had his limits. In his autobiography, written in the third person (Like Stendhal, he declared, he dislikes the jes and the mois), he remembers responding to an urgent request by writing an 18,000-word story in one day, an experience he deemed a tour-de-force that he has never repeated or wanted to repeat.

title: Popcast: R&Bs New Identity
description: New York Times music critics discuss changes within the genre.

title: 1966: France Returns to Common Market
description: LUXEMBOURG  The six Common Market nations ended the crisis that has paralyzed their community for seven months. France agreed to return to the Common Market and drop the boycott it began July 1. The first meeting of the revived community at its Brussels headquarters is expected to take place in the second half of February. In a marathon bargaining session that ended early this morning, the ministers from the six nations patched up their differences by resorting to an artful dodge.

title: A Bosch Retrospective
description: The small Dutch city of s-Hertogenbosch, known as Den Bosch, is celebrating the virtual return of its native son Hieronymus Bosch, who died 500 years ago. Although the city doesnt own any of the artists paintings, this year it will present the largest retrospective of Boschs work ever, with all the works on loan from several leading museums. Jheronimus Bosch  Visions of Genius, displaying 20 paintings and 19 drawings, runs from Feb. 13 to May 8 at Het Noordbrabants Museum. Seven other museums in the province of North Brabant will present shows.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Greenwich Village, Hudson Square and South Slope, Brooklyn.

title: Tudors
description: THE LOST TUDOR PRINCESSThe Life of Lady Margaret DouglasBy Alison Weir537 pp. Ballantine, $30.

title: Green-Eyed Verbs
description: Sometimes, when I open a magazine and find yet another intelligently researched piece of journalism or brilliant social analysis in the form of a book review, I think: What beauty! And then, almost immediately afterward, I think, Could I offer the world something so useful and beautiful?

title: Not All Bastards Are From Vienna, by Andrea Molesini
description: Not All Bastards Are from Vienna, winner of Italys 2011 Campiello Prize, is Andrea Molesinis first novel for adults  though it still possesses the straightforward narrative line and colorful characters of a story for children. Set during World War I, events are related by 17-year-old Paolo Spada, recently orphaned and now living with a menagerie of relations and servants in the Villa Spada, in a small town north of Venice.

title: Thomas Murphy, by Roger Rosenblatt
description: Some novels delight their readers with an intricate and irresistible plot, in which pace and clues and the stumble of events offer an alluring puzzle. Others are wonderful at evoking a time, a place, an emotion. Still others are notable primarily for the way the author creates unforgettable characters  beings so real, so complex, so absorbing that you think about them long after you finish the book, and you cannot quite believe they will no longer be holding your attention, provoking that startled pang of understanding and fellow feeling.

title: The Castle Cross the Magnet Carter, by Kia Corthron
description: In February, a film biography of the Olympic runner Jesse Owens is scheduled to arrive in theaters. Whatever its other virtues or lack of same, the movie carries a title of brilliant duality.

title: Winter, by Christopher Nicholson
description: The male giants of English literature have often made bad real-life husbands, and the vindication of their suffering wives has taken various forms. Thomas Carlyle, and posterity, might never have realized what a difficult spouse he was without the diary of Jane Carlyle, which the historian read with dismay after her death. Mary Powell, Wife to Mr. Milton, had her youthful ordeal imagined by Robert Graves in a witty first-person novel carrying that title. Now, in Winter, the English novelist Christopher Nicholson sets out to avenge (up to a point) Florence Hardy, the decades-younger second wife of the aged Thomas, as she endures the fall and winter of 1924-25 inside a storm of sickness, jealousy and anger.

title: Richard A. Posners Divergent Paths: The Academy and the Judiciary
description: If Richard Posner did not exist, who would dare invent him? The most-cited legal scholar of all time, who is arguably Americas greatest living judge; a man who publishes a book a year while writing all his own judicial opinions; an icy rationalist who once confessed to unrequited love for his cat. ... Its all a bit too much to believe. Arthur Conan Doyles Sherlock Holmes and Gene Roddenberrys Mr. Spock are probably the closest anyone has come.

title: The Poetry of Yehuda Amichai, Edited by Robert Alter
description: I have one selfish quibble with the expansive, magnificent new book The Poetry of Yehuda Amichai, edited by Robert Alter. It excludes a personal favorite, The Eve of Rosh Hashanah. Every year, on the occasion of its title, I read the poem aloud. In Chana Bloch and Stephen Mitchells translation, it begins:

title: What Belongs to You, by Garth Greenwell
description: In a controversial 1999 New Yorker review of Alan Hollinghursts novel The Spell, John Updike summed up a common prejudice about gay stories: namely, that they have nothing to interest straight readers.

title: Charity Wine Auctions Are More Than Parties
description: DENISE COBB, a former CNN anchor, and her husband, Brian, a media executive, have had some great chefs in their kitchen over the years. Thomas Keller, the owner of the French Laundry in Napa Valley and Per Se in New York, has cooked there three times. Eric Ripert, the chef at Le Bernardin in New York, has been there, too.

title: La Tour dArgent, Paris Dining Temple, to Auction Furnishings and More
description: PARIS  La Tour dArgent, a Parisian shrine to the art of fine dining that traces its roots to the 16th century, is selling off tableware, furnishings and cooking implements as it seeks to reinvent itself for the 21st century.

title: Margaret Thatcher, by Charles Moore
description: In February 1984, during that period when a succession of decrepit Soviet leaders were dropping like flies, the British prime minister, Margaret Thatcher, traveled to Moscow to attend the funeral of Yuri Andropov. There she made an extremely positive impression on her hosts. Not only did she remain outside in frigid temperatures during the entire ceremony, but her personal security man, who shadowed her in his vast overcoat with immense bulging pockets, drew many admiring glances. Russian security were deeply impressed by this heavily armed man, one British official recalled. When, however, Thatcher returned to the Kremlin, she removed her own coat and unzipped her fur-lined boots, whereupon Detective Superintendent Parker produced a pair of high-heeled shoes from his pockets. A firearm or a stiletto: Both seemed to have potential in the hands of a leader the Soviets had once christened the Iron Lady. But the story is indicative of the way the matter of her gender would often surprise and unsettle Thatchers contemporaries.

title: The Lightkeepers, by Abby Geni
description: Anyone who has been traumatized by Alfred Hitchcocks The Birds  a high percentage of its viewers, Id guess  may hesitate to read beyond the early pages of Abby Genis first novel, The Lightkeepers. The heroine, a photographer named Miranda, is leaving the island where she has spent the previous year, where the sea gulls now seem to be trying to make sure that no one gets out alive. A gull slams against Mirandas temple, knocking her off balance. ... Wings thunder around her shoulders. But readers who persevere beyond this unnerving beginning will find themselves carried along by a sturdy, rather old-fashioned thriller ramped up by some modern, ecologically themed plot twists.

title: 13 Recipes for the Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Popcast: A New Identity for R&B
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

title: Art World Prepares for a Challenging Year
description: LONDON  So now its official: The art market boom has peaked, according to figures from Christies and Sothebys, the biggest international auction houses.

title: Why Good Governance Stock Index Lacks Expert Judgment
description: Jeff Gramm is the author of the forthcoming book Dear Chairman: Boardroom Battles and the Rise of Shareholder Activism (HarperBusiness). He is a hedge fund manager who teaches value investing at Columbia Business School.

title: Katie Fallon, Top Obama Aide, Leaving White House
description: WASHINGTON  Katie Beirne Fallon, the top legislative official who helped improve President Obamas dysfunctional relationship with Capitol Hill, will leave the White House in the coming weeks, a departure that reflects shrinking ambitions for lawmaking during Mr. Obamas final year in office.

title: Baked Cheesy Pasta With Wild Mushrooms
description: Melissa Clark updates the pasta casserole with fontina cheese and wild mushrooms.

title: A Child-Friendly Pasta Bake the Adults Will Love
description: Pasta with wild mushrooms and rosemary is an elegant dish, the kind of thing youd see at restaurants or maybe make yourself as dinner-party fare.

title: Ted Cruz Endures More Hits From Rivals After Tough Debate
description: DES MOINES  The Republican presidential field banded together on Friday against the man they now see as their common enemy, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, whose perceived front-runner status before the Iowa caucuses appeared to grow even more uncertain just three days before the voting begins.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Tribes Win in Fight for La Jolla Bones Clouds Hopes for DNA Studies
description: The San Diego Archaeology Center holds a pair of extraordinary skeletons. Dating back about 9,500 years, they are among the oldest human remains ever found in the Americas.

title: Republicans and Democrats Brace for a Reality Check
description: DES MOINES  American presidential campaigns have never been so thoroughly examined, probed and measured as in this election cycle. And the pollsters and pundits who cover them are about to get a reality check.

title: Maya Angelous Harlem Home for Sale
description: The century-old Harlem brownstone that served as the New York home of the memoirist, poet and civil rights activist Maya Angelou for almost a decade, and where she entertained scores of friends like Oprah Winfrey and Cicely Tyson with dance parties and competitive Boggle games and whipped up her signature smothered chicken, is about to enter the market.

title: Exclusive | Maya Angelous Harlem Home
description: The sprawling brownstone was home to the memoirist, poet and civil rights activist for almost a decade.

title: Michigan Officials Emails on Water Quality
description: State employees exchanged messages showing concern about the safety of the water at a state office building in Flint in January 2015, months before the Snyder administration acknowledged problems with the city's water.

title: Michigan Gave State Employees Purified Water as It Denied Crisis, Emails Show
description: Throughout most of 2015, the administration of Gov. Rick Snyder told the residents of Flint, Mich., that their tap water was safe to drink. But emails released on Thursday suggest the state was concerned about its own employees exposure to the citys water as early as January of last year, even arranging for purified water to be provided at a state office building there.

title: Getty Museum Acquires Dana, a 17th-Century Work, at Sothebys
description: The 17th-century painting Dana by Orazio Gentileschi, a peer of Caravaggio, which set an auction record for the artist at $30.5 million in a sale on Thursday at Sothebys in New York, was purchased by the J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles.

title: Super Bowl Referee Is No Stranger to Bizarre Episodes
description: Referees have made a lot of news this season, not all of it favorable, and the N.F.L. will hope that the Super Bowl is not remembered for another officiating blunder. Perhaps it is odd, then, that the league has chosen Clete Blakeman as the Super Bowl 50 referee. He struggled to flip a coin successfully earlier in the playoffs and also played a small but vital role in the Deflategate contretemps, a misadventure the league probably wants to forget.

title: Barclays Hires JPMorgan Chase Veteran as Chief Risk Officer
description: LONDON  James E. Staley, the new Barclays chief executive, has turned to a longtime veteran of JPMorgan Chase, his former employer, to fill out the banks executive ranks.

title: Madoffs Multibillion-Dollar Mirage Arrives on TV
description: At the McCarran airport in Las Vegas not long ago, I handed my ticket and drivers license to the T.S.A. agent, a woman who appeared to be in her mid-60s. She examined my return ticket to Newark and then, seemingly out of the blue, looked up and said, I wish I could move back to New York.

title: AMC Classics: Mad Men, Breaking Bad  Remember WENN?
description: A decade before AMC began to make its name as a home to highly rated and critically acclaimed TV shows, a tiny series set in a World War II-era radio station ran on the network from 1996 to 1998 before vanishing into the ether.

title: In Ghent, a Wood-Fired Oven With the Warmth of a Hearth
description: Kobe Desramaults may have earned cult-chef status and a Michelin star with his middle-of-nowhere restaurant In de Wulf (which he plans to close in December 2016), but by the Belgian chefs own admission, Im a pretty lousy baker.

title: Are You at Risk for Sexually Transmitted Infections?
description: If youre having sex, youre at risk for sexually transmitted infections. But what are the chances youll actually get one?

title: Case Sheds Light on Goldmans Role as Lender in Short Sales
description: It would be easy to overlook the case against Goldman Sachs filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Jan. 14. It involved a complex piece of Wall Street plumbing, led to a minuscule $15 million fine and came on the same day that Goldman agreed to pay up to $5 billion to settle prosecutors claims that it sold faulty mortgage securities to investors.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: David Benioff
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the novelist, producer and Game of Thrones co-creator David Benioff, who shares his list exclusively with T.

title: Top 8 Moments from the Paris Couture Shows
description: The top moments at couture week, including Karl Lagerfelds country-house set, Cara Delevingnes puppy and, of course, tulle and brocade galore.

title: A Day at the Bookstore for All Kids
description: The trouble with an event called Take Your Child to a Bookstore Day is obvious: The parents most likely to embrace it are the ones most likely to be bookstore regulars already, with children deeply familiar with the local stores shelves and other amenities, from the worn pillows and the Thomas the Tank Engine table to the cup of crayons on the child-size table.

title: Stuff We Liked: Blockbuster Articles and Insights Into Bear Markets
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Cam Newton Dances Around End Zones, Not Around Matters of Racism
description: As he prepares to take the greatest stage in American sports, Cam Newton has used the spotlight on him to discuss our countrys most persistent and vexing problem: racism.

title: Donald Trump Declares Victory Over Fox News, Then Takes On Newspaper
description: NASHUA, N.H.  Donald J. Trump declared victory in his standoff with Fox News on Friday, telling a packed hotel ballroom in New Hampshire that he had shown the world just how tough he could be when challenged.

title: #Match4Lara: Mixed-Race Marrow Search Thats Going Viral
description: Lara Casalotti, a 24-year-old global migration masters student in Britain, had a pain in her lower back. At first it didnt seem like much, but then when she was in Thailand researching migrant worker conditions, it grew worse and required hospitalization. On Dec. 14, the young human rights activist learned her pain wasnt from a pulled muscle: She was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia, a blood cancer that would require a stem cell transplant by April to save her life.

title: How Eileen Myles, Poet, Spends Her Sundays
description: Shes long been a figure in the counter culture, but recently the writer Eileen Myles has also become something of a household name. In 2015 she published two books: Chelsea Girls, a reissue of an autobiographical novel, and I Must Be Living Twice: New and Selected Poems 1975-2014. She also made it to television, where the hit series Transparent quoted her poetry and featured a character based on her. Ive had a lifelong waiting-for-the-other-shoe-to-drop feeling when something good happens, Ms. Myles said. But oddly, thats not happening. Ms. Myles, 66, splits her time between Marfa, Tex., and Manhattan, where she lives with her golden pit bull, Honey, in the rent-stabilized one-bedroom apartment in the East Village where she has lived since the 70s.

title: The Fashion News to Know This Week
description: Keeping up with Kanye

title: Theres Only Love and Fear: On Chers Twitter
description: Welcome to Social Capital, a series devoted to analyzing the social media presences of celebrities.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Bill Bryson on Britain
description: This week, Bill Bryson talks about The Road to Little Dribbling; Jennifer Schuessler has news from the literary world; Molly Young discusses new books about productivity; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Four Unfussy  and Totally Unexpected  Things We Saw at Couture Week
description: Haute couture week, fashions grandest event, ended on Wednesday in Paris. And while the garments we saw on the spring 2016 runways were as opulent and luxurious as ever, the season also ushered in a lighter, less serious way of dressing. Several houses showed unexpected  and downright unfussy  takes on couture. Here are four.

title: Pablo Larrans The Club:At Home With the Sins of the Fathers
description: The Academy Award-nominated film Spotlight brings viewers inside The Boston Globe reporting team that broke the story of a widespread cover-up of sexual abuse by Catholic priests. The Club, the latest film by the Chilean director Pablo Larran, takes a different angle. It brings viewers deep inside the home of four priests removed from ministry for a range of sins  or crimes.

title: Unions Lean Democratic, but Donald Trump Gets Members Attention
description: WASHINGTON  Of all the voters who might be expected to resist the charms of Donald J. Trump, the two million members of the Service Employees International Union would most likely be near the top of the list.

title: Bernie Sanders Trumpets Iowa Papers Praise. Unsaid? It Endorsed Hillary Clinton
description: The Des Moines Register has not endorsed Senator Bernie Sanders, but a new ad from his campaign that started running on Thursday in Iowa may lead viewers to think that it did.

title: New York-Area Ports Shut Down as Longshoremen Walk Off the Job
description: The East Coasts busiest port system ground to a halt on Friday as thousands of longshoremen in New York and New Jersey walked off the job, threatening to disrupt the delivery of goods throughout the region.

title: Creating Originality at Home and at Work
description: Adam Grant is a serious social scientist, master storyteller and infectious optimist.

title: How Scared Should You Be About Zika?
description: Every time there is a major infectious disease outbreak that scares us  Ebola in West Africa in 2014, Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) on the Arabian Peninsula in 2012 and in South Korea in 2015, and now the Zika virus in South and Central America and the Caribbean  government leaders, the public and the news media demand explanations, guidance and predictions, and often express indignation that not enough was done to prevent it. Today everyone is asking about Zika: How did this crisis happen, and what do we need to do to make it go away? We immediately forget about the outbreak that came before it, and dont plan for the ones we know are on the horizon. Almost no one wants to talk about Ebola or MERS now, or what we have or havent done to try to prevent an ugly recurrence.

title: The Perils of Political Dads
description: Thursdays debate was about immigration, Obamacare and who could come up with the most unspeakable thing to do to ISIS. But it was also about dads.

title: Ted Cruzs Negative Ads Go After Marco Rubio, Rather Than Donald Trump
description: DES MOINES  Senator Ted Cruz, scrambling to put down a growing threat in Iowa from Senator Marco Rubio, is shifting nearly all of his negative advertising from Donald J. Trump to Mr. Rubio for the final three days of the caucuses.

title: Man Is Charged in Death of His Daughter After Eviction Confrontation
description: A Pennsylvania man who the authorities say pointed a rifle at a state constable evicting him has been charged in the death of his 12-year-old daughter, who was accidentally shot when the officer fired his weapon in response.

title: A Renewable Feast
description: So you say you want a revolution? Politically, Im afraid youll be disappointed  unless the revolution you have in mind involves putting Donald Trumps finger on the button. But an environmental/energy revolution? Thats looking remarkably within reach.

title: Jane Birkin on a Half-Century of Collaboration
description: Jane Birkin doesnt watch her own films. I dont even know that I saw most of them when they came out, she says, laughing. There are a few I have seen and thank goodness never saw again. But when T sat down with Birkin ahead of Jane and Charlotte Forever, a series at the Film Society of Lincoln Center dedicated to the acting work of Birkin and daughter Charlotte Gainsbourg, she was eager to talk about her many collaborations  with former partners Serge Gainsbourg and Jacques Doillon, as well as Agns Varda  and whys she now more content doing her own thing.

title: A David Bowie Biography Coming From Paul Morley
description: After the death of David Bowie on Jan. 10 its time to start defining his posthumous legacy. The Simon & Schuster imprint Gallery Books has announced a new biography, The Age of Bowie, to be written by the rock journalist Paul Morley. Mr. Morley most recently worked as a writer on Grace Joness 2015 book, Ill Never Write My Memoirs.

title: G.O.P. Debate Without Trump Draws 12.5 Million Viewers
description: The Fox News Republican debate without Donald Trump on Thursday night drew 12.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen.

title: Making a Haute Couture Look: Chanel
description: On the above image, we take a closer look at the making of one Chanel haute couture look.

title: Ojen, a New Orleans Favorite, Is Back in the Liquor Cabinet
description: Probably more than any city in America, New Orleans loves anise-flavored liqueurs. Yet its had a hard time holding on to them.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Bill Bryson on Britain
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

title: Bloombergs Presidential Dreams, and Past Realities
description: For the past several months, it has been hard not to imagine Michael R. Bloomberg sitting in his East Side townhouse (or his compound in Bermuda, or his house in London, or his other house in London), throwing a pile of cashmere sweaters the color of citrus fruit at his television in outrage over the ascendancy of Donald J. Trump. If the world were fair, if the citizenry were sane, if cheap showmanship hadnt long ago triumphed over civic reason, then a different, smarter, better-dressed, more managerially efficient and less volcanically arrogant Manhattan billionaire would be on a course toward the White House.

title: Exploring Nepal and the Himalayas
description: A writer explores his native Nepal, more than 50 years after his parents moved to the country as Peace Corps volunteers.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties are in Garden City, N.Y., and Hillsdale, N.J.

title: Xerox Chief Removed Ego From Decision to Split Company
description: Chief executives usually have big egos. Ursula Burns, though, is handing bragging rights to the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn.

title: Seeking Strong Iowa Finish, Marco Rubio Targets Young Suburbanites
description: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa  Inside Marco Rubios presidential campaign, they are known as the perfect voter: middle-class, college-educated suburban moms and dads ages 30 to 45 with mortgages and car payments who live just outside Des Moines.

title: Two Bedrooms on Park Avenue for $18.9 Million
description: A spacious, light-filled aerie about midway up the recently completed 432 Park Avenue, currently the tallest residential tower in the Western Hemisphere, topping out at 1,396 feet, sold for $18,926,920.09 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.
